Our contributions in this study are as follows: we first
propose a method for classifying the normal weight or
the high weight using speech signals in age-and gender-
specific groups. Our method may apply to the development
of advanced and automatic methods for individual BMI
d i a g n o s i si nt e l e m e d i c i n ea n du - h e a l t h c a r ea n da s s i s ti nt h e
developmentofasimplersystemforBMImeasurement.Also,
our suggestion that is possible to support context awareness
mayprovidecluestoimprovetheoverallqualityofemergency
service via automatic support of patient BMI information
in remote healthcare systems with limited resources. We
find discriminatory and meaningful features for normal and
overweight diagnoses via a statistical analysis between BMI
andspeechfeaturesandidentifyacompactandusefulfeature
subset in accordance with the age-and gender-specific anal-
ysis. The results will serve to create a better discriminatory
featuresetandaccurateclassificationmodelsinthisfield.

sentence was recorded twice, and the value of each feature
was obtained by averaging the values of the 2 recordings for
morestablefeatures.
All features were extracted using 5 vowels (A, E, I,
O, U) and 1 sentence [38]. For speech feature extraction,
we extracted 65 features from the collected data set. The
extracted features consisted of pitch, average ratio of pitch
period, correlation coefficient between F0 and intensity
(CORR), absolute Jitter (Jita), and Mel frequency cepstral
coefficients (MFCC), among others [18, 23, 27]. The specific
content of the extracted features is described in Table 1,
and sample of speech signal recording of 5 vowels and one

2.1.2. Class Label Decision for Normal and Overweight Sta-
tuses. Obesity and BMI research is difficult due to different
ethnic groups and different national economic statuses [7].
Also, BMI values differ according to physiological factors
and environmental factors, such as residing in a city or a
rural area. For instance, BMI values of a population in an
Asian region tend to be lower than those of a population
in a Western region, whereas Asians have risk factors for
cardiovascular disease and diabetes related to obesity at
relatively low BMI values [9, 39]. The BMI cutoff values for
overweight and obesity depend on several factors including
ethnicity,rural/urbanresidence,andeconomicstatus[ 7,40].
Therefore, we decided that this studyâ€™s overweight cutoff
point of BMI value wasâ‰¥23kg/m
2, according to suggestions
by the World Health Organization and references [39, 41,
42]. We refer here to only 2 classes: the â€œnormalâ€ and the
â€œoverweight.â€ Subjects in the BMI who range from 18.5 to
22.9 were labeled normal, and subjects with a BMI of 23
or over were labeled as overweight. Underweight patients
were passed over due the lack of a minimum number of
subjects. Finally, we divided the data set into 6 groups for

Obesity is a serious public health problem because of the risk factors for diseases and psychological problems. The focus of this
studyistodiagnosethepatientBMI(bodymassindex)statuswithoutweightandheightmeasurementsfortheuseinfutureclinical
applications.Inthispaper,wefirstproposeamethodforclassifyingthenormalandtheoverweightusingonlyspeechsignals.Also,

subset selection. Our results showed that predicting BMI status is possible using a combination of speech features, even though
significantfeaturesarerareandweakinage-andgender-specificgroupsandthattheclassificationaccuracywithfeatureselection
was higher than that without feature selection. Our method has the potential to be used in future clinical applications such as
automaticBMIdiagnosisintelemedicineorremotehealthcare.
1. Introduction
Worldwide, increasing numbers of people are becoming
obese, including adults, adolescents, and children and both
menandwoman[ 1,2].Obesityreferstoexcessadiposetissue

question: Which data type is used in this study?

['.
include teeth cases images collection, the sample set building,
and model training to achieve this goal. The system ï¬‚owchart is
shown in Fig. 5 .
Due to the lack of dental diseases standard data sets, we
worked with some dental clinics (such as Beijing Mei-Xiao
dental clinics). With the consent of the subjects, 300 subjects
use dental image acquisition device to sample the dental diseases
video data, and the algorithm analyzes each frame of video, and
3835 images of dental cases are sampled ï¬nally. These clinics
already have 8,765 images of dental cases, with a total of 12,600
clinical images being collected. These images are classiï¬ed into
7 different types as shown in Table I, with the 7 types of dental
diseases as follows: dental caries, dental uorosis, periodontal
disease, cracked tooth, dental calculus, dental plaque, and tooth
loss. 4/5 of these data was used in training, while 1/5 of them was
in model testing, training data set and test data are respectively
from different objects, thus without overlap between the testing
dataset and the training dataset.
B. Build Sample Set
The semi-automatic labeling method is applied to establish
the training sample set to improve the efï¬ciency. The dental im-
ages were initially labeled by the design of detector for 7 types
of dental diseases, as shown in Fig. 5 , the functions of the de-
tector here include image enhancement, color texture matching,
coarse localization and classiï¬cation of disease. Followed by
the conï¬rmation of images with labeling error or classiï¬cation
error through manual screening method, the training samples
set were ï¬nally calibrated by 20 dental disease experts, with the
details as follows:
1) Image Enhancement: In some dental images, the features
of the tooth disease site without very high contrast are not very
obvious, thereby making it necessary to enhance the images
before designing the classiï¬cation algorithms. The Retinex al-
gorithm is used [17], which adaptively prompts various types
of images to achieve balance in dynamic range, edge, and color.
The image enhancement effect in Fig. 6 shows that the color
and texture details of the dental disease are highlighted after the
enhancement.
2) Coarse Localization and Classiï¬cation of Dental Disease
Target Area: It is just a preliminary detecting, and only the areas
close to the color and texture of the image to be matched will
be detected as samples. Firstly, a histogram matching method
with fast calculation speed is used to select the region of color
proximity, followed by the use of the Tamura texture feature

on X-ray. However, visual diagnosis serves as one of the most
important parts of dental health care.
The smart dental health IoT system, due to the lack of coor-
dinated IoT-based In-home dental health care services, is devel-
oped in this paper, which plays an important role in elaborating
its applications in home and private dental clinic scenarios. The
proposed system builds a home-centric, self-assisted, fully au-
tomatic intelligent In-home dental healthcare solution by taking
advantage of embedded intelligent hardware technology, articial
intelligence (AI), and the mobile terminal.
The system closely combines the personal self-service dental
health examination and dental resources through studying the
AI method to expand the scope and coverage of traditional
dental health care, which is the major contribution made by the
proposed iHome smart dental Health-IoT system. Patients can
choose medical resources online and receive an appointment for
medical treatment via self-service smart dental screening.
The rest parts of this paper are organized as follows.
Section II discusses smart In-home dentist system, followed
by Section III analyzing the intelligent dental diagnosis, intro-
ducing the algorithm ï¬‚ow and test results. Section IV presents
the integrated system and hardware prototype, and reports the
application results, and a conclusion is given in Section V
ï¬nally.
II. S MART IN-HOME DENTIST SYSTEM
The occurrence of dental disease can be well predictable. For
example, each stage from dental plaque, calculus to dental caries
and periodontal disease shows different characteristics and so-
lutions, thereby making it possible to monitor the whole body
and reduce the risk of sudden diseases effectively. It can reduce
pain, save time and reduce the cost of money for patients. How-
ever, most consumers lack the correct tooth awareness, thereby
making the timely treatment for tooth disease difï¬cult. More-
over, there is a relative shortage of dental resources in hospitals.
These main contradictions are explained in the following aspects
in details:
r First, there are a lot of patients with dental diseases, but
fewer people pay attention to the teeth. Many individ-
uals pay for treatment only when they have teeth with
problems, which may cause irreversible damage to the
long-term development of children.
r Second, the cost of dental treatment is relatively high.
r Third, dental disease, due to the characteristics of elective
treatment, is difï¬cult to get timely treatment.
Based on what is discussed above, a promising trend in health-
care is to move routine medical checks and other healthcare ser-
vices from hospital (Hospital-Centric) to the home environment
(Home-centric) [15], through which, the patients can get seam-
less health care at any time in a comfortable home environment.
Even more, it can ensure that the overall iHome dental health-
care system including three partspersonalized services, dental
services and intelligent and interactive service could be opti-
mized to a large extent. Based on this platform, the closed', '3, MARCH 2020

Fig. 6. Dental images enhancement comparison chart.
algorithm by this design [18], which is applied to ï¬nd the
image area blocks close to the sample image.
3) Artiï¬cial Screening Determines the Sample Library: For
the image areas after coarse location and classication, the anno-
tation information of each frame of data needs to be manually
conï¬rmed by dental disease experts. Labelme tool is used to gen-
erate mask data set, along with description of the segmentation
region of dental disease as accurate as possible with multiple key
points. We delete the wrong label positions and ï¬x the wrong
tags through articial selection, along with the possible adding of
the undetected target images. The nished data is applied as the
training sample data for the detection and classication of dental
diseases, ending up with the summary of the recorded frame
images to establish the dental training sample set.
C. Model Training
Common target detection algorithms including RCNN,
YOLO, SSD [19] only classify the target in the image. However,
the accurate target segmentation is benecial to the auxiliary med-
ical diagnosis, to achieve the aim of fast and accurate detection
of dental diseases and dental area accurate segmentation. Based
on the established dental sample library, the MASK R-CNN
method is chosen for the accurate detection and segmentation
of the dental target.
The designed MASK R-CNN network is shown in the left
of Fig. 6 , in which, MASK R-CNN adds a branch predicting
the segmentation mask in each interested area based on Faster
R-CNN [20]. In Faster R-CNN, region of interest (RoI) pool
is used to extract the small features from each RoI. Firstly,
RoIPool scales the RoI represented by oating point numbers to
Fig. 7. Left: MASK R-CNN network. Right: example detections using
MASK R-CNN on dental images test.
the granularity matching the feature graph, followed by parti-
tioning of the scaled ROI, ending up with the summary of the
characteristic value of each block coverage area. Such calcula-
tions misplace the ROI and the extracted features, which, though
possibly not affecting the classication, for the classication has
the certain robustness to the small amplitude transformation,
exerts a great negative impact on the prediction of the precise
mask of pixel level. Mask R-CNN proposes the RoI Align layer
to remove the dislocation of RoIPool and aligns the extracted
features with the input accurately. In RoI Align, a bilinear in-
terpolation is used to calculate the exact value of each position,
along with the summary of the results by using the maximum
or average pooling, and the extracted features and input can be
aligned with the pixel to pixel, thereby improving the segmen-
tation accuracy effectively. For the lower convolution network
used for feature extraction on the whole image, the ResNet-50-
C4 backbone [20], [21] is adopted with the depth of 50 layers,
and extract features from the nal convolution layer of the fourth
stage in the MASK R-CNN. For the upper network, we extend
the Faster R-CNN upper network proposed in ResNet, adding a
mask branch respectively. TensorFlow and Mask R-CNN open
source are adopted in the training model, along with modiï¬ca-
tion of ShapesCong class, and GPU COUNT and IMAGES PER
GPU are set to 1 according to the training server conguration.
At the same time, according to the training sample library, cate-
gories NUM CLASSES, image size IMAGE MIN DIM and the
size of the anchor RPN AN']

The occurrence of dental disease can be well predictable. For

give more priority to the improvement of the hardware design
and the efï¬ciency of image acquisition device, and further work
will focus on improving algorithm efï¬ciency and recognition
rate, reducing false alarm rate, and setting up a larger image
data set for dental diseases.
V. C ONCLUSION
This paper proposes an iHome smart dental Health-IoT sys-
tem based on intelligent hardware, deep learning and mobile
terminal, aiming to regulate as well as optimize the accessibil-
ity of dental treatment and provide home-based dental health
care service more efciently. The trained model was used to
realize the detection and classication of dental diseases, and
application software (Apps) on mobile terminal was designed
for client-side and dentist-side. The software platform with the
functions including pre-examination of dental disease, consulta-
tion, appointment, and evaluation, etc, made the service docking
between the patient and the dentist resources a reality. The AI
algorithm achieved more than 90% recognition rate for seven
dental diseases., which has greatly improved the patient rate and
the resource utilization rate of the dental clinic through a one-
month systematic testing in 10 private dental clinics, showing
high reliability in practical application.

C. Intelligent Hardware
Traditional dental image collection methods can bring about
the inconvenience as follows:
r Dentists are required to acquire knowledge on more shoot-
ing skills;
r It is necessary to expand the auxiliary equipment such as
the oral expander, along with high cost of the SLR camera.
r Only partial dental images can be obtained
Due to the peculiarity of oral structure, the general image
acquisition equipment (e.g. smart cell-phone) cant meet the im-
age data collection requirement of 6 surfaces of teeth, thereby
helping explain that an intelligent dental image acquisition de-
vice is designed to photograph dental images. As shown in the
Fig. 4 , the intelligent dental image acquisition device is mainly
composed of an image module and the control board, and the
micro exible packaging technology is applied to manufacture
the image module. On the exible printed circuit board, it is in-

The smart dental health IoT system, due to the lack of coor-
dinated IoT-based In-home dental health care services, is devel-
oped in this paper, which plays an important role in elaborating
its applications in home and private dental clinic scenarios. The
proposed system builds a home-centric, self-assisted, fully au-
tomatic intelligent In-home dental healthcare solution by taking
advantage of embedded intelligent hardware technology, articial
intelligence (AI), and the mobile terminal.
The system closely combines the personal self-service dental
health examination and dental resources through studying the
AI method to expand the scope and coverage of traditional
dental health care, which is the major contribution made by the
proposed iHome smart dental Health-IoT system. Patients can
choose medical resources online and receive an appointment for
medical treatment via self-service smart dental screening.
The rest parts of this paper are organized as follows.
Section II discusses smart In-home dentist system, followed
by Section III analyzing the intelligent dental diagnosis, intro-
ducing the algorithm ï¬‚ow and test results. Section IV presents
the integrated system and hardware prototype, and reports the
application results, and a conclusion is given in Section V
ï¬nally.
II. S MART IN-HOME DENTIST SYSTEM
The occurrence of dental disease can be well predictable. For
example, each stage from dental plaque, calculus to dental caries
and periodontal disease shows different characteristics and so-
lutions, thereby making it possible to monitor the whole body
and reduce the risk of sudden diseases effectively. It can reduce
pain, save time and reduce the cost of money for patients. How-
ever, most consumers lack the correct tooth awareness, thereby
making the timely treatment for tooth disease difï¬cult. More-
over, there is a relative shortage of dental resources in hospitals.
These main contradictions are explained in the following aspects
in details:
r First, there are a lot of patients with dental diseases, but
fewer people pay attention to the teeth. Many individ-
uals pay for treatment only when they have teeth with
problems, which may cause irreversible damage to the
long-term development of children.
r Second, the cost of dental treatment is relatively high.
r Third, dental disease, due to the characteristics of elective
treatment, is difï¬cult to get timely treatment.
Based on what is discussed above, a promising trend in health-
care is to move routine medical checks and other healthcare ser-
vices from hospital (Hospital-Centric) to the home environment
(Home-centric) [15], through which, the patients can get seam-
less health care at any time in a comfortable home environment.
Even more, it can ensure that the overall iHome dental health-
care system including three partspersonalized services, dental
services and intelligent and interactive service could be opti-
mized to a large extent. Based on this platform, the closed', ' seek
for low-price as well as time-saving medical treatment.
r Group purchase (E-MALL) service: It can classify the cus-

mote different group purchase & product services based
on AI diagnosis results.
r Large data customization service: It can classify the cus-
tomer needs and provide the customized or personalized
products as well as the services according to AI diagnosis
results.
Mainly consisting of dental image data acquisition devices
and the mobile terminal, local computing, and processing units,
wireless transmitting modules and display terminal, the dental
image data acquisition layer serves as the basis of the entire
platform. The dental image data is uploaded to the smart dental
service layer via the network (Wi-Fi, 3G/4G). A display terminal
is needed in this layer to meet the daily needs of the users in
dental health self-inspection service, thereby making it possible
for mobile terminal to satisfy this requirement very well. With
this three-layer iHome dental Health-IoT system, the interaction
between dentists and home-stay patients can easily take place
on demand or on a regular basis.
B. Apps on Mobile Terminal
The intelligent dental Health-IoT platform facilitates the in-
teraction between the patients and the dentists mainly through
the mobile terminal. As shown in Fig. 2 , the application soft-

layer, the cloud-end application programming interface (API)
layer, the server & service layer and the database layer.
Composed of Android, iOS, H5 and web programs, The front-

The server & service layer consists of the algorithm servo
middleware and the Apache server. The latter, undertaking
the basic HTTP service, completes the HTTP service resource
scheduling and allocation through the load balancing strategy,
and supports performance extensions and third-party access,

tication, notiï¬cation push), while the former, implementing
the connection between the cloud-end API layer and the algo-
rithms, is responsible for resource scheduling and allocation of
algorithms.
The database layer, mainly composed of MySQL database
and ï¬le storage services, is mainly applied to store basic data,

3) Artiï¬cial Screening Determines the Sample Library: For
the image areas after coarse location and classication, the anno-
tation information of each frame of data needs to be manually
conï¬rmed by dental disease experts. Labelme tool is used to gen-
erate mask data set, along with description of the segmentation
region of dental disease as accurate as possible with multiple key
points. We delete the wrong label positions and ï¬x the wrong
tags through articial selection, along with the possible adding of
the undetected target images. The nished data is applied as the
training sample data for the detection and classication of dental
diseases, ending up with the summary of the recorded frame
images to establish the dental training sample set.
C. Model Training
Common target detection algorithms including RCNN,
YOLO, SSD [19] only classify the target in the image. However,
the accurate target segmentation is benecial to the auxiliary med-
ical diagnosis, to achieve the aim of fast and accurate detection
of dental diseases and dental area accurate segmentation. Based
on the established dental sample library, the MASK R-CNN
method is chosen for the accurate detection and segmentation
of the dental target.
The designed MASK R-CNN network is shown in the left
of Fig. 6 , in which, MASK R-CNN adds a branch predicting
the segmentation mask in each interested area based on Faster
R-CNN [20]. In Faster R-CNN, region of interest (RoI) pool
is used to extract the small features from each RoI. Firstly,
RoIPool scales the RoI represented by oating point numbers to
Fig. 7. Left: MASK R-CNN network. Right: example detections using
MASK R-CNN on dental images test.
the granularity matching the feature graph, followed by parti-
tioning of the scaled ROI, ending up with the summary of the
characteristic value of each block coverage area. Such calcula-
tions misplace the ROI and the extracted features, which, though
possibly not affecting the classication, for the classication has
the certain robustness to the small amplitude transformation,
exerts a great negative impact on the prediction of the precise
mask of pixel level. Mask R-CNN proposes the RoI Align layer
to remove the dislocation of RoIPool and aligns the extracted
features with the input accurately. In RoI Align, a bilinear in-
terpolation is used to calculate the exact value of each position,
along with the summary of the results by using the maximum
or average pooling, and the extracted features and input can be
aligned with the pixel to pixel, thereby improving the segmen-
tation accuracy effectively. For the lower convolution network
used for feature extraction on the whole image, the ResNet-50-
C4 backbone [20], [21] is adopted with the depth of 50 layers,
and extract features from the nal convolution layer of the fourth
stage in the MASK R-CNN. For the upper network, we extend
the Faster R-CNN upper network proposed in ResNet, adding a
mask branch respectively. TensorFlow and Mask R-CNN open
source are adopted in the training model, along with modiï¬ca-
tion of ShapesCong class, and GPU COUNT and IMAGES PER
GPU are set to 1 according to the training server conguration.
At the same time, according to the training sample library, cate-
gories NUM CLASSES, image size IMAGE MIN DIM and the
size of the anchor RPN AN', ' image, the ResNet-50-

diseases can be correctly identiï¬ed in these testing image data.

[' device placed
on the finger that sampled PPG at 1000Hz. For our current
work, we will only focus on the PPG signal.
The study involved each subject completing a set of validated
tasks that induced stress, interspersed with tasks that help them
relax. The study started with a baseline-recording for 5 min-
utes where the subject sat idle. The subject then performed a
multiple object tracking task for 3 minutes (cognitive stressor),
followed by 3 minutes of progressive muscle relaxation. The
subject then underwent a â€œSpeechâ€ task; a research assistant,
playing the role of an interviewer, asked the subject to speak
on a challenging and personal topic (social stressor). The
subject was then given 3 minute time to prepare for the speech,
after which they entered a room consisting of evaluators. The
research assistant purposefully delayed the start of the speech
to increase the stress. After a 2-minute delay, the subject was
asked to leave without completing the task. Subsequently, the
subject listened to relaxing music for 4 minutes, followed
by exciting music. Finally, the subject was asked to rest and
recover. Between each task, the subject was given at least a
2-minute break to offset the effect of the previous task and
prepare for the next task. In Figure 1, we show the timeline
of the tasks and how the heart rate varies during these tasks
for a sample subject.
B. PPG signal-denoising
The raw PPG signals captured from the Earbud and Biopac
were first filtered by a third-order Butterworth bandpass filter
with cut-off frequencies set to 0.6-4 Hz. The filtered PPG
signal was then sliced into 30-second sliding windows with a
20-second overlap for the prediction of HRV parameters and
stress detection. Even after passing the PPG signal through a
bandpass filter, the signal still contained motion artifacts, shifts
in baseline wandering, and other high-frequency noises. To
address this, we estimated the quality of the PPG signal using
the PQR signal quality index [8]. In this method, we calculated
P/Q/R indexes representing the signal quality for each window
of PPG signal. The â€œPâ€ index indicated the degree of high-
frequency noise in the signal, calculated using the change in
the number of extremum points after bandpass filtering. The
â€œQâ€ index indicated the amount of baseline wandering, cal-
culated using the signalâ€™s maximum and minimum amplitude.
The â€Râ€ index represented the frequency of motion artifacts
by calculating the dispersion of peak and valley points. Using
these three indexes, the method calculated rSQI (relative signal
quality index) to compare the quality of the PPG signal against
a clean reference signal. In our case, we used the signal
collected from the baseline-recording as a reference signal.
The PPG-windowed signals whose rSQI â‰¥ 0, indicating the
signal was comparable or better in quality than the reference
signal, were considered for subsequent analysis. The PPG-
windowed signals with rSQI < 0 are removed. Finally, we
standardized the PPG signals of each subject to remove any
subject-dependent information. Due to poor contact on one
or more of the earbuds or Biopac finger sensor resulting in
signals too noisy to be usable, we excluded PPG data from
four subjects.

To extract HRV based features from the denoised earbud
PPG signal, we design a framework based on transfer learning
and using Temporal convolution network (TCN) [9]. The
framework consists of two steps: In the first step we pre-train

This demonstrates the impact of our proposed framework on
feature extraction in stress classification.
V. C ONCLUSION
Estimating HRV features using wearable sensors is critical
for stress management solutions. In our current work, we take
an initial step toward using earbud PPG signals to estimate
HRV features, employing a framework based on transfer
learning and TCN architecture. We have demonstrated that
our framework estimates these features more accurately than
the existing open-source library, HeartPy. Subsequently, we
observed that using our modelâ€™s predicted HRV features in
place of HeartPy for stress detection results in improved
performance. Encouraged by these initial results, we plan to
conduct our study on a larger and more diverse set of subjects
to corroborate our findings.

III. T RANSFER LEARNING BASED FRAMEWORK FOR
EXTRACTING HRV FEATURES
To extract HRV based features from the denoised earbud
PPG signal, we design a framework based on transfer learning
and using Temporal convolution network (TCN) [9]. The
framework consists of two steps: In the first step we pre-train
a TCN model on Biopac PPG to detect position of peaks.
For the latter step, we use this pre-trained TCN model for the
downstream task of predicting different HRV parameters. We
explain these steps in detail below.
A. Pre-training using Biopac PPG
The growing availability of ubiquitous and unobtrusive
wearable devices has made the collection of continuous sensor
data more convenient and accessible than ever. However,

B. Downstream HRV parameters estimation
The pre-trained TCN model from the previous step is fine-
tuned to predict different HRV-based features from the earbud
PPG signal. The trained TCN network is transferred here, with
only the final layer changed to predict various HRV parameters
instead of peaks. In our current work, we considered five

the following HRV features: root mean square of successive
differences between normal heartbeats (RMSSD), proportion
of the number of pairs of successive NN (R-R) intervals
that differ by more than 50 ms (pNN50), standard deviation
of normal to normal R-R intervals (SDNN), and normalized
high frequency power (HFnorm). We fine-tuned the pre-trained
model separately for each of these HRV parameters. As we
considered features that are continuous values, this required
changing only the loss function from the pre-trained model.
While our framework can be extended to predict any HRV-
based parameter, we chose these five as they were the most
predictive of stress in our prior empirical analysis [16]. An
overview of our framework is shown in Figure 2.
IV. R ESULTS
Using the framework described in the previous section, we
initially trained the upstream model to predict the peaks of the
input Biopac signal. This upstream model was subsequently
fine-tuned on earbud PPG signal to predict different features
separately: HR, RMSSD, pNN50, SDNN, and HFnorm. Ul-
timately, using these features, we predict whether the subject
is feeling stress or not for each PPG signal window. We con-
ducted all our analysis using Leave-One-Subject-Out Cross-
Validation (LOSOXV), where the data from a single subject
was held out for testing while the model was trained on the
remaining subjects. This process was repeated until all subjects
had been tested.

on the finger that sampled PPG at 1000Hz. For our current

The study involved each subject completing a set of validated
tasks that induced stress, interspersed with tasks that help them
relax. The study started with a baseline-recording for 5 min-
utes where the subject sat idle. The subject then performed a
multiple object tracking task for 3 minutes (cognitive stressor),
followed by 3 minutes of progressive muscle relaxation. The
subject then underwent a â€œSpeechâ€ task; a research assistant,
playing the role of an interviewer, asked the subject to speak
on a challenging and personal topic (social stressor). The
subject was then given 3 minute time to prepare for the speech,
after which they entered a room consisting of evaluators. The
research assistant purposefully delayed the start of the speech
to increase the stress. After a 2-minute delay, the subject was
asked to leave without completing the task. Subsequently, the
subject listened to relaxing music for 4 minutes, followed
by exciting music. Finally, the subject was asked to rest and
recover. Between each task, the subject was given at least a
2-minute break to offset the effect of the previous task and
prepare for the next task. In Figure 1, we show the timeline
of the tasks and how the heart rate varies during these tasks
for a sample subject.
B. PPG signal-denoising
The raw PPG signals captured from the Earbud and Biopac
were first filtered by a third-order Butterworth bandpass filter
with cut-off frequencies set to 0.6-4 Hz. The filtered PPG
signal was then sliced into 30-second sliding windows with a
20-second overlap for the prediction of HRV parameters and
stress detection. Even after passing the PPG signal through a
bandpass filter, the signal still contained motion artifacts, shifts
in baseline wandering, and other high-frequency noises. To
address this, we estimated the quality of the PPG signal using
the PQR signal quality index [8]. In this method, we calculated
P/Q/R indexes representing the signal quality for each window
of PPG signal. The â€œPâ€ index indicated the degree of high-
frequency noise in the signal, calculated using the change in
the number of extremum points after bandpass filtering. The
â€œQâ€ index indicated the amount of baseline wandering, cal-
culated using the signalâ€™s maximum and minimum amplitude.
The â€Râ€ index represented the frequency of motion artifacts
by calculating the dispersion of peak and valley points. Using
these three indexes, the method calculated rSQI (relative signal
quality index) to compare the quality of the PPG signal against
a clean reference signal. In our case, we used the signal
collected from the baseline-recording as a reference signal.
The PPG-windowed signals whose rSQI â‰¥ 0, indicating the
signal was comparable or better in quality than the reference
signal, were considered for subsequent analysis. The PPG-
windowed signals with rSQI < 0 are removed. Finally, we
standardized the PPG signals of each subject to remove any
subject-dependent information. Due to poor contact on one
or more of the earbuds or Biopac finger sensor resulting in
signals too noisy to be usable, we excluded PPG data from
four subjects.

III. T RANSFER LEARNING BASED FRAMEWORK FOR
EXTRACTING HRV FEATURES
To extract HRV based features from the denoised earbud
PPG signal, we design a framework based on transfer learning
and using Temporal convolution network (TCN) [9]. The
framework consists of two steps: In the first step we pre-train
a TCN model on Biopac PPG to detect position of peaks.
For the latter step, we use this pre-trained TCN model for the
downstream task of predicting different HRV parameters. We
explain these steps in detail below.
A. Pre-training using Biopac PPG
The growing availability of ubiquitous and unobtrusive
wearable devices has made the collection of continuous sensor
data more convenient and accessible than ever. However,
labeling this data requires significant effort and time. As a
result, the amount of labeled sensor data available is minimal
in comparison to the unlabeled data that can be collected. We
first pre-train a model with the reference PPG signals captured
from the Biopac finger sensor to detect peak positions of this
input signal. We chose this task because all the HRV-related
features extracted from the PPG signal are derived from the
position of peaks. The primary motivation for pre-training a
model on the PPG data is to increase data efficiency given the
relative scarcity of available earbud PPG data, and to acquaint
the model with the PPG signal. We use HeartPy [10], [11], an
open-source python library for extracting ground truth peak
positions. The idea of initiating models on hand-designed tasks
before deploying them for different downstream purposes is
not uncommon. In computer vision, models are often pre-
trained with image segmentation tasks [12], [13] and in natural
language processing to generate language models like BERT
[14] and GPT-3 [15], models are pre-trained with tasks of pre-
dicting of next word in a sentence. We used TCN as our choice
of model, while there are several choices for modeling contin-
uous time-series data TCNs are a type of convolution network
that convolve over a time-domain by combining properties of
Convolutional Neural Networks (CNN) and Recurrent Neural
Networks (RNN). They overcome the problem of exploding
and vanishing gradients by using causal dilated convolution

The increase/decrease in the performance of stress detection

II. We also experimented with stress detection by using all
the features as predicted by our framework. However, given
the prominent role of HR in estimating stress, this modelâ€™s
performance was relatively lower compared to ones reported
here. We evaluate the performance of stress detection using
Accuracy, Specificity, and Sensitivity. From this table, we can
see that using the HRV parameter predicted by our framework,
instead of the HeartPy prediction, has resulted in at least a 5%
improvement in all evaluation metrics for all HRV features.
This demonstrates the impact of our proposed framework on
feature extraction in stress classification.
V. C ONCLUSION
Estimating HRV features using wearable sensors is critical
for stress management solutions. In our current work, we take
an initial step toward using earbud PPG signals to estimate
HRV features, employing a framework based on transfer
learning and TCN architecture. We have demonstrated that
our framework estimates these features more accurately than
the existing open-source library, HeartPy. Subsequently, we
observed that using our modelâ€™s predicted HRV features in
place of HeartPy for stress detection results in improved
performance. Encouraged by these initial results, we plan to
conduct our study on a larger and more diverse set of subjects
to corroborate our findings.

A. Feature Estimation
The feature values predicted by our model are compared
against HeartPy predictions. To the best of our knowledge,
HeartPy is the most prominent and trusted public library to
provide HRV features from PPG signals. For the prediction
of all the HRV features, we use a 4-layer TCN to get the
input representation from the PPG signal that, in turn is
passed through 2 Fully Connected (FC) layers with hidden
sizes of 64 to get the output prediction. We train the model
using a learning rate of 5e-05 and a dropout value of 0.3.
We evaluate the performance of our model against HeartPy
using mean absolute error (MAE) with the estimates from the
Biopac sensor data considered the ground truth. We report
these results in Table I. Among all the parameters predicted,
we observe that for heart rate alone, HeartPy outperforms our
proposed framework. For the remaining HRV parameters, our
model performs better than HeartPy prediction. On average,
the improvement in HRV parameter estimation compared to
HeartPy is around 26%.
To highlight the significance of fine-tuning, we predicted
HRV features from the earbud PPG without any pre-training
step. The results of this experiment are shown in Table I.
With the exception of HR, we observe that transfer learning
improves performance for all the HRV features.
Throughout all our experiments, we consistently observed
relatively poorer performance in average HR estimation using
our proposed framework. This may be related to the fact that
heart rate estimation is fundamentally different from HRV
parameter estimation. While HRV estimation depends on the
specific sequence of individual peaks, HR is more of an
average of the distances between peaks. The framework was
not optimized for this averaging task and the removal of
outliers that would adversely affect the average. Nevertheless,
heart rate is an important feature and integrating its estimation
in a unified framework can be the focus of future work.
B. Stress detection
In this section, we report the performance of stress clas-
sification using HRV parameters obtained from HeartPy and
our model, respectively. The PPG window from a subject is
labeled as stress if it is sampled from the task that induces
stress, which in our case are Dot-tracking, Speech-Preparation,
Speech, and Exciting Music tasks (see Figure 1 for more
details), PPG windows from the remaining tasks are labeled

the model with the PPG signal. We use HeartPy [10], [11], an
open-source python library for extracting ground truth peak
positions. The idea of initiating models on hand-designed tasks
before deploying them for different downstream purposes is
not uncommon. In computer vision, models are often pre-
trained with image segmentation tasks [12], [13] and in natural
language processing to generate language models like BERT
[14] and GPT-3 [15], models are pre-trained with tasks of pre-
dicting of next word in a sentence. We used TCN as our choice
of model, while there are several choices for modeling contin-
uous time-series data TCNs are a type of convolution network
that convolve over a time-domain by combining properties of
Convolutional Neural Networks (CNN) and Recurrent Neural
Networks (RNN). They overcome the problem of exploding
and vanishing gradients by using causal dilated convolution

to diagnose 26 common skin conditions from clinical images
plus associated medical histories.25 During validation, Liuet al
achieved a 71% top-1 accuracy and their algorithm surpassed
dermatologists, PCPs and nurse practitioners in a clinical data-
set.
25 Our Top-1 accuracy was 77% and the mean AUC was 0.95
for algorithmic validation of 40 diseases.
There are no precedents for studies in which an AI-based, skin
disease diagnosis app has been tested in clinical settings. In our
work, a top-1 accuracy of 75% and a top-3 accuracy of 90% was
achieved by the app for 35 skin diseases and was largely similar to
our model validation results. Some differences in diagnostic per-
formance (in terms of disease AUCs) between model and app
were noted and may be attributable to either fewer clinical valida-
tion images for some diseases like Bowenâ€™s disease, anogenital
warts, tinea pedis, rosacea, candidiasis, herpes zoster (Fig. 4a and
Supplementary Figure S1) and/or differences in disease morphol-
ogy between white and pigmented skin. Eczema is a broad disease
category, incorporating diseases with varied morphology such as
lichen simplex chronicus, atopic dermatitis, nummular eczema
and contact dermatitis. Training of the model with speciï¬c dis-
ease classes rather than a broad category of eczema may improve
sensitivity. As shown in the confusion matrix, eczema was often
confused with psoriasis, lichen planus and tinea corporis, cruris
or faciei (Figs 4a, b). To some extent, this mirrors the diagnostic
confusion faced by many physicians as well.
2,25,26 A few melano-
cytic nevi lesions were mistaken for BCC possibly because of their
resemblance with pigmented BCC, which is more commonly seen
in skin of colour. Besides, it was observed that diseases with dis-
tinct morphology and predilection for certain sites (in a similar
recognizable background) such as melasma and tinea unguium
had better accuracies.
In this study, we found a high top-3 sensitivity for BCC
(97.58%, n = 124) and SCC (92.86%,n = 14', ' of the CNN model for the diagnosis of 40 skin
diseases showed a top-1 overall accuracy of 76.93/C6 0.88% and
AUC of 0.95/C6 0.02 (Table 1). High speciï¬cities and NPV were
observed for all disease classes (Table 1, Fig. 2a, and b). The sen-
sitivities and PPV were more varied but 34/40 skin diseases
showed high PPVs in 80â€“99% range. AUC values and ROC plots
for different diseases in model validation and clinical study are
given in Supplementary Figure S1.
Clinical validation
The app was tested on 5014 patients (3699 from tertiary care, 383
from urban private practice, and 932 from rural primary care).
Out of the 5014 patients, 760 patientsâ€™ images were in the nonspe-
ciï¬c (out-of-distribution) category. The mean AUC was
0.90 /C6 0.07, top-1 overall accuracy 75.07% (CI= 73.75â€“76.36)
and top-3 accuracy 89.62% (CI = 88.67â€“90.52) for combined
data from all centres (Table 2, Fig. 3a). The mean top-1 speciï¬city
was 99.11% (CI= 99.06â€“99.15). Small differences were noted in
the overall accuracies of urban, rural primary and tertiary hospital
patients, with the urban practice showing the highest and tertiary
care centres showing the lowest accuracy (Fig. 3a). We do not
present data for actinic keratosis, chickenpox, keratoacanthoma,
melanoma and tinea manuum because of less than 10 patients for
each of these disease classes. The most signiï¬cant sensitivities were
observed for diagnosis of hidradenitis suppurativa, BCC, vitiligo,
acne, alopecia, molluscum contagiosum, melasma, ichthyosis and
tinea corporis, cruris or faciei. Bowenâ€™s disease, bullous pem-
phigoid, candidiasis, ï¬xed drug eruption, eczema, lichen sclero-
sus, melanocytic naevus, rosacea and tinea pedis had lower
accuracy across all sites (Figs 3b and 4a and b). The sensitivity of
diseases with larger sample sizes was generally greater except for
eczema and melanocytic nevi (Fig. 3b).
The top-3 sensitivity of most diseases, including eczema, was
high (Figs 3b and 4b). Analyses of the confusion matrix showed
that many eczema lesions were misdiagnosed as psoriasis fol-
lowed by lichen planus and tinea corporis, cruris or faciei (Fig. 3
a). Most of the skin cancers were detected in top-3 diagnoses as
shown in the confusion matrix (Fig. 4b).
Discussion
This cross-sectional study is the ï¬rst, large-scale, clinical valida-
tion study of an AI-driven app involving a wide spectrum of
common dermatological diseases on the skin of colour. More-
over, this work shows the potential of an app to be successfully
incorporated into clinical workï¬‚ows by physicians using ordi-
nary smartphones.
Nearly all previously published work on automated skin dis-
ease detection has focused onin silico algorithmic validation.
21
There is also little published literature demonstrating high-efï¬-
ciency neural networks for multi-disease classiï¬cation. AI-based
algorithms, particularly CNN, have been successfully applied in
skin lesion classiï¬cation,']

15', ' validation studies of AI-
based algorithms related to dermatology in clinical settings.
Material and methods
The study aimed to develop a convolutional neural network
(CNN)-based algorithm trained with clinical images of 40 differ-
ent skin diseases. A user-friendly, smartphone app was also gen-
erated, and a clinical validation study on 5014 patients was done
by physicians in urban, rural primary care and tertiary care set-
tings. The appâ€™s analysis of a single image of the lesion was com-
pared to the consensus diagnosis made by two board-certiï¬ed
dermatologists. Only patients, for whom the treating board-cer-
tiï¬ed dermatologist was conï¬dent of the diagnosis and the diag-
nosis was cross-veriï¬ed by another board-certiï¬ed
dermatologist, were included. If there was no consensus then the
patient was excluded from the study.
Generation of the CNN-based algorithm
The CNN architecture used was a modiï¬ed version of Densenet-
161 with optimized augmentation and inference pipelines.
16
These optimizations were derived through rigorous experiments
and were attuned to clinical skin images. All training and testing
images were annotated and segmented so a bounding box sur-
rounded lesion of interest and irrelevant features such as rulers
and surgical markings were discarded. The 17 718 raw images
were sourced from public databases (http://www.hellenicderma
tlas.com/en and http://www.danderm.dk/atlas), after obtaining
permission from them, as well as images from dermatologists in
India. Of these, 310 images were discarded during the
preprocessing stage due to poor resolution or multiple lesions.
Out of the remaining 17 408 images, 1990 images belonged to
the non-speciï¬c category and 15 418 images were within the 40
selected disease categories (Table 1). These images were split
into ï¬ve equal parts (folds) and ï¬ve iterations of training and
validation were performed in a manner so that within each itera-
tion, a different fold of the data was held-out for validation while
the remaining fourfolds were used for learning. The training
images were 12 350 and testing images were 3068. Since the
dataset was imbalanced, a custom modiï¬ed version of the
weighted focal loss function was used to train the network. The
weights for each class were calculated using the inverse sample
size method. Our test images were either in-distribution images
i.e. images within 40 training classes or out-of-distribution sets
that we named as non-speciï¬c set.
We initially used Inception-v4, which was one of the most
popular CNN models at the time. For 10 diseases, a sensitivity of
around 85% was achieved, but for the 20-disease class model,
this fell to around 65%. We experimented with many parameters
like learning rate and choice of optimizer etc. with no signiï¬cant
improvements. It was felt that as the architectures became dee-
per, there could be problems related to over-ï¬tting. According
to Huanget al.,convolutional networks can be substantially dee-
per, more accurate and efï¬cient to train if they contain shorter
connections between layers close to the input and those close to
the output.
17 Their implementation of this architecture is called
DenseNet. In this architecture, to ensure maximum information
ï¬‚ow between layers, each layer obtains additional inputs from all
preceding layers and passes on its own feature-maps to all subse-
quent layers.
17 We found that the DenseNet architecture pro-
vided better results than the other contemporary architectures
such as Inception-Resnet-V2, Resnets-50, Resnet-101 and Res-
net-152. We tried several DenseNet variants', ' to calculate the true positive rate (same as
sensitivity) and the false-positive rate (1 â€“ speciï¬city). ROC
curve was the plot of the true positive rate versus the false-
positive rate.
Clinical validation study
We tested our mobile app against dermatologistsâ€™ diagnosis in
three different clinical settings, namely, at a tertiary care centre

improvements. It was felt that as the architectures became dee-
per, there could be problems related to over-ï¬tting. According
to Huanget al.,convolutional networks can be substantially dee-
per, more accurate and efï¬cient to train if they contain shorter
connections between layers close to the input and those close to
the output.
17 Their implementation of this architecture is called
DenseNet. In this architecture, to ensure maximum information
ï¬‚ow between layers, each layer obtains additional inputs from all
preceding layers and passes on its own feature-maps to all subse-
quent layers.
17 We found that the DenseNet architecture pro-
vided better results than the other contemporary architectures
such as Inception-Resnet-V2, Resnets-50, Resnet-101 and Res-
net-152. We tried several DenseNet variants']

[' of the CNN model for the diagnosis of 40 skin
diseases showed a top-1 overall accuracy of 76.93/C6 0.88% and
AUC of 0.95/C6 0.02 (Table 1). High speciï¬cities and NPV were
observed for all disease classes (Table 1, Fig. 2a, and b). The sen-
sitivities and PPV were more varied but 34/40 skin diseases
showed high PPVs in 80â€“99% range. AUC values and ROC plots
for different diseases in model validation and clinical study are
given in Supplementary Figure S1.
Clinical validation
The app was tested on 5014 patients (3699 from tertiary care, 383
from urban private practice, and 932 from rural primary care).
Out of the 5014 patients, 760 patientsâ€™ images were in the nonspe-
ciï¬c (out-of-distribution) category. The mean AUC was
0.90 /C6 0.07, top-1 overall accuracy 75.07% (CI= 73.75â€“76.36)
and top-3 accuracy 89.62% (CI = 88.67â€“90.52) for combined
data from all centres (Table 2, Fig. 3a). The mean top-1 speciï¬city
was 99.11% (CI= 99.06â€“99.15). Small differences were noted in
the overall accuracies of urban, rural primary and tertiary hospital
patients, with the urban practice showing the highest and tertiary
care centres showing the lowest accuracy (Fig. 3a). We do not
present data for actinic keratosis, chickenpox, keratoacanthoma,
melanoma and tinea manuum because of less than 10 patients for
each of these disease classes. The most signiï¬cant sensitivities were
observed for diagnosis of hidradenitis suppurativa, BCC, vitiligo,
acne, alopecia, molluscum contagiosum, melasma, ichthyosis and
tinea corporis, cruris or faciei. Bowenâ€™s disease, bullous pem-
phigoid, candidiasis, ï¬xed drug eruption, eczema, lichen sclero-
sus, melanocytic naevus, rosacea and tinea pedis had lower
accuracy across all sites (Figs 3b and 4a and b). The sensitivity of
diseases with larger sample sizes was generally greater except for
eczema and melanocytic nevi (Fig. 3b).
The top-3 sensitivity of most diseases, including eczema, was
high (Figs 3b and 4b). Analyses of the confusion matrix showed
that many eczema lesions were misdiagnosed as psoriasis fol-
lowed by lichen planus and tinea corporis, cruris or faciei (Fig. 3
a). Most of the skin cancers were detected in top-3 diagnoses as
shown in the confusion matrix (Fig. 4b).
Discussion
This cross-sectional study is the ï¬rst, large-scale, clinical valida-
tion study of an AI-driven app involving a wide spectrum of
common dermatological diseases on the skin of colour. More-
over, this work shows the potential of an app to be successfully
incorporated into clinical workï¬‚ows by physicians using ordi-
nary smartphones.
Nearly all previously published work on automated skin dis-
ease detection has focused onin silico algorithmic validation.
21
There is also little published literature demonstrating high-efï¬-
ciency neural networks for multi-disease classiï¬cation. AI-based
algorithms, particularly CNN, have been successfully applied in
skin lesion classiï¬cation,', ' to calculate the true positive rate (same as
sensitivity) and the false-positive rate (1 â€“ speciï¬city). ROC
curve was the plot of the true positive rate versus the false-
positive rate.

', 'ORIGINAL ARTICLE
A machine learning-based, decision support, mobile phone
application for diagnosis of common dermatological
diseases
R. Pangti,1 J. Mathur,2 V. Chouhan,2 S. Kumar,2 L. Rajput,1 S. Shah,1 A. Gupta,3 A. Dixit,1
D. Dholakia,4,5 S. Gupta,6 S. Gupta,1 M. George,7 V.K. Sharma,1 S. Gupta1,*
1Department of Dermatology and Venereology, All India Institute of Medical Science, New Delhi, India
2Nurithm Labs Private Limited, Noida, India
3Skin Aid Clinic, Cross Point Mall, Gurugram, India
4Genomics and Molecular Medicine Unit, Academy of Scientiï¬c and Innovative Research, New Delhi, India
5Academy of Scientiï¬c and Innovative Research, Ghaziabad, Uttar Pradesh, India
6Maharishi Markandeshwar Institute of Medical Sciences and Research, Mullana, Ambala, India
7Sahrudya Hospital, Alappuzha, India
*Correspondence: S. Gupta. E-mail: someshgupta@hotmail.com
Abstract
Background The integration of machine learning algorithms in decision support tools for physicians is gaining popular-
ity. These tools can tackle the disparities in healthcare access as the technology can be implemented on smartphones.
We present theï¬rst, large-scale study on patients with skin of colour, in which the feasibility of a novel mobile health
application (mHealth app) was investigated in actual clinical workï¬‚ows.
Objective To develop a mHealth app to diagnose 40 common skin diseases and test it in clinical settings.
Methods A convolutional neural network-based algorithm was trained with clinical images of 40 skin diseases. A
smartphone app was generated and validated on 5014 patients, attending rural and urban outpatient dermatology
departments in India. The results of this mHealth app were compared against the dermatologistsâ€™ diagnoses.
Results The machineâ€“learning model, in an in silico validation study, demonstrated an overall top-1 accuracy of
76.93 /C6 0.88% and mean area-under-curve of 0.95/C6 0.02 on a set of clinical images. In the clinical study, on patients
with skin of colour, the app achieved an overall top-1 accuracy of 75.07% (95% CI= 73.75â€“76.36), top-3 accuracy of
89.62% (95% CI= 88.67â€“90.52) and mean area-under-curve of 0.90/C6 0.07.
Conclusion This study underscores the utility of artiï¬cial intelligence-driven smartphone applications as a point-of-
care, clinical decision support tool for dermatological diagnosis for a wide spectrum of skin diseases in patients of the
skin of colour.

Introduction
Skin diseases are the fourth leading cause of non-fatal disease
burden across 188 countries in both low and high-income coun-
tries.
1,2 There is less than one dermatologist per 100 000 people
in India and less than three dermatologists per 100 000 of the
population in the United States and the ratios are expected to
decline further.

ever, response fatigue is a common problem that can result in
missing data due to an incomplete response from the subject,
resulting in misclassiï¬cation [16], [17]. Response fatigue can be
common when an administered survey is too long, or when a sur-
vey is short, but administered too frequently. Because of these
drawbacks, data collected from a less invasive method could
potentially provide more reliable estimates of patient health sta-
tus over time. Previous studies have shown high compliance
in activity trackers, indicating that they may be more reliable
methods for tracking continuous patient data [4], [18].

MENG et al.: MACHINE LEARNING APPROACH TO CLASSIFYING SELF-REPORTED HEALTH STATUS 879
In this study, we explore the use of machine learning methods
to classify PRO scores over time [14]. Machine learning algo-
rithms have been widely used in biomedical research for tasks
such as disease detection [19] and outcome prediction [20].
These methods traditionally use a set of demographic variables
and baseline data as a feature vector to make a classiï¬cation
using a machine learning algorithm such as gradient boosting
regression tree (GBRT) [21], AdaBoost [22], or random forests
(RF) [20], [23]. However, traditional machine learning meth-
ods are effective for making single decisions, but do not allow
for adjusting as more information is learned. Temporal mod-
els are appropriate in the case of sequential observations where
the value of the outcome may need to be adjusted over time. In
particular, hidden Markov models (HMMs) are well-established
temporal models that use sequential data to predict events such
as patient state changes, such as estimating mean sojourn time
of lung cancer patients using screening images [24], detecting
homologous protein sequences [25], and gene ï¬nding [26].
The goal of this study was to investigate the feasibility of using
machine learning models to classify PRO scores based on data
collected using one type of activity tracker, the Fitbit Charge 2.
In this study, we tested this goal within a population of patients
with stable ischemic heart disease (SIHD). The rest of this article
describes an approach for data preprocessing and constructing
a model that treats weeks independently, as well as an HMM
that takes temporal information into account. Performance of
the classiï¬cation algorithms is then evaluated for each PRO
measure and feature importance in classiï¬cation is analyzed.
Finally, we provide a discussion and analysis of the results and
suggest future directions for implementing such a classiï¬er in a
patient surveillance application.
II. D ATADESCRIPTION
A set of 200 patients with SIHD were recruited for a feasibil-
ity study conducted by Cedars-Sinai Medical Center from 2017
to 2018 to predict surrogate markers of major adverse cardiac
events (MACE), including myocardial infarction, arrhythmia,
and hospitalization due to heart failure, using biometrics, wear-
able sensors, patient-reported surveys, and other biochemical
markers. This study population size is similar to several pre-
vious studies that used activity trackers for patient monitoring
[27], [28]. The desired monitoring period was 12 weeks for
each subject, during which time subjects wore personal activity
trackers to record their physiological indices', 'iï¬cation
accuracy than treating weeks independently because they took
advantage of correlations in subjectsâ€™ survey scores from week
to week. In our data-driven approach, the model states were de-
termined based on the distribution of PRO scores in the clinical
study [41]. Score bins for the states were deï¬ned to limit the
sparsity during training and make the number or states consistent
across all of the PROMIS PROs tested. However, this may not be
the optimal way to deï¬ne the number of states for clinical rep-
resentation of health status. Future studies could conduct some
analysis to ï¬nd out the optimum number of states, which may
further increase the classiï¬cation accuracy. In addition, another
future direction would approach this as a regression problem to
predict actual PRO scores with high precision over time.
Sequential deep learning models, such as recurrent neural net-
works (RNNs) and long-short-term-memory (LSTM) networks
have also demonstrated strong performance when dealing with
sequential data [42], [43]. Therefore, these techniques may hold
potential for applications to sensor data to classify or predict
health status. However, such methods generally require a large
amount of training data, which was not available in the cur-
rent study. In future studies, deep learning methods could be
explored if a sufï¬ciently large data set were collected.
While activity trackers are able to produce patient informa-
tion within seconds or minutes, the sampling periods for PROs
like PROMIS [13] are on the order of weeks, requiring down-
sampling of the Fitbit data for comparison. Given that the PROs
measured in this study are unlikely to vary signiï¬cantly from day
to day, this temporal resolution is appropriate for the application
of PRO prediction. However, predicting more acute events might
require more temporal resolution, which could be addressed by
using the activity tracker data at a ï¬ner time scale. Long term
follow-up with patients including recordings of clinical events
such as rehospitalizations could also allow us to evaluate the
effect of mHealth monitoring on clinical outcome, an important
step in determining the efï¬cacy of such an intervention.
VI. C ONCLUSION
A temporal machine learning model can be used to classify
self-reported physical health in patients with SIHD using phys-
iological indices measured by activity trackers. By constructing
an HMM with feature selection and an RF classiï¬er, the result-
ing model can achieve an AUC of 0.79 for classifying Physical
Function. Our result indicates data generated from activity track-
ers may be used in a machine learning framework to classify

II. D ATADESCRIPTION
A set of 200 patients with SIHD were recruited for a feasibil-
ity study conducted by Cedars-Sinai Medical Center from 2017
to 2018 to predict surrogate markers of major adverse cardiac
events (MACE), including myocardial infarction, arrhythmia,
and hospitalization due to heart failure, using biometrics, wear-
able sensors, patient-reported surveys, and other biochemical
markers. This study population size is similar to several pre-
vious studies that used activity trackers for patient monitoring
[27], [28]. The desired monitoring period was 12 weeks for
each subject, during which time subjects wore personal activity
trackers to record their physiological indices, including steps,
heart rate, calories burned, and distance traveled. At the end
of each week, they were asked to ï¬ll out eight PROMIS short
forms as a self-report assessment of their health status [4].
A. Activity Data
The Fitbit Charge 2 (Fitbit Inc., San Francisco, CA, USA)
is a popular commercially available activity tracker that can
record a personâ€™s daily activities and health indices like heart
rate, steps, and sleep ( Table I ). Previous work has validated
the accuracy of heart rate monitoring speciï¬cally in the Fitbit
Charge 2 [29]. The Fitbit hardware and its computational algo-
rithms for calculating step counts and physical activity have been
T ABLE I
SUMMARY OF 17 T YPES OF FEA TURECOLLECTED FROM FITBIT PER DAY
âˆ—means that feature was eliminated for model input because it was highly sparse or redun-
dant.
validated using other Fitbit devices [30], [31]. The Fitbit Charge
2 estimates activity using metabolic equivalents (METs), which
are calculated based on heart rate and distance traveled [32].
Heart rate during activity is also provided, however it has been
shown to be inaccurate during activity [33]. Data quality was
assured by verifying that there were no extreme outliers based
on subject-speciï¬c inter-quartile range [34]. We aggregated the
data for each day to compensate for noise and redundancy. Af-
ter data preprocessing, tracker distance was eliminated because
it was identical to total distance, and logged activity distance
and sedentary active distance were also deleted because of high
sparsity. As a result, there were 14 features per day for each
patient in our model.
B. Patient-Reported Outcome Measures
Patient-Reported Outcomes Measurement Information Sys-
tems (PROMIS) questionnaires are a library of instruments
developed and validated to measure many domains of phys-
ical and mental health [15]. This analysis uses data from
eight PROMIS instruments: Global Physical Health and Global
Mental Health, which are two composite scores from the Global-
10 short form [35]; Fatigue-Short Form 4a; Physical Function-
Short Form 10a; Emotional Distress-Anxiety-Short Form 6a;
Depression-Short Form 4a; Social Isolation-Short Form 4a; and
Sleep Disturbance-Short Form 4a. Each questionnaire either
asks about current health or has a recall period of the previous
seven days, so they are appropriate for weekly administration.
The T metric method was used to standardize scores for each
type to a mean of 50 and a standard deviation of 10, with a
range between 0 and 100 [15], [36]. Symptom (i.e., Fatigue,
Anxiety, Depression, Social Isolation, and Sleep Disturbance)
scores of 60 or higher are one standard deviation above the av-
erage, which is deï¬ned as moderate to severe symptom severity.

For analysis, states were binarized according to the criteria

some information and precision, a regression analysis was con-

ate the accuracy of predicting PRO scores over time.
IV . R ESULTS
Table II shows the mean AUC for binary classiï¬cation of
PRO scores for the seven PROMIS measures using GBRT, Ad-
aBoost and RF. The highest mean AUC was 0.75 using RF for
classifying Physical Function, while the lowest was 0.47 using
AdaBoost for Depression. The results indicated that RF signif-
icantly outperformed other models in classiï¬cation of Anxiety
and Depression (p < 0.05), and it was also signiï¬cantly better
than GBRT for Global Physical Health and Mental Health (p =
0.01 and p = 0.01, respectively). The RF model was selected
for the remaining analyses because its performance was equiv-
alent to or better than the other methods for classifying all PRO
scores. Additionally, it was notable that the AUC related to self-
reported physical health PROs such as Global Physical Health,
Fatigue, and Physical Function were higher than those related
to mental health such as Global Mental Health, Anxiety, and
Depression.
We then looked at the importance factor of each feature con-
tributing to the classiï¬cation in the RF model. Table III displays
the importance factor for the 14 feature types summed over
seven days. Features that were signiï¬cantly higher (p < 0.05)
than the average value for each classiï¬cation were determined.

For function (i.e., Global Physical Health, Global Mental
Health, and Physical Function), scores less than 40 are classi-

normal. For this study, PRO scores were predicted in two ways:
regression was used to predict PRO scores from patient activity
tracker data, and classiï¬cation was used to determine whether

isolation (<2%), this variable was eliminated for analysis in our

III. M ETHODS
Missing data is a common concern when dealing with activity
tracker data and can result from subjects either forgetting to wear
their devices or removing them for charging. Patients were asked
to ï¬ll out eight PROMIS questionnaires at the end of each week
for a 12-week monitoring period. In total, 19.1 percent of weeks
had missing PRO data and 16.6 percent of weeks had missing
values from the activity tracker in four or more days. If data was
available for at least four days in a week, missing values were
permuted by using the average value of the rest of the week for
steps or resting heart rate. Weeks with missing survey scores, as
well as those without step and resting heart rate data for more
than three days, were removed from the analysis.
A correlation analysis between subjectsâ€™ missing Fitbit data
and their average Global Physical Health and Global Mental
Health scores shows a slight negative relationship ( âˆ’0.11 and
âˆ’0.09, respectively) that was not statistically signiï¬cant (p =
0.13 and p = 0.23, respectively). The correlation coefï¬cient be-
tween number of missing PROs and the average global health
scores are âˆ’0.17 (p = 0.018) to âˆ’0.14 (p = 0.048), respec-
tively, indicating that the missing PROs are signiï¬cantly related
to patient health. Another correlation analysis was performed
between subjectâ€™s age and number of missing values with
r2 <0.001, which demonstrates no trend of more missing values
for elder subjects. Finally, subjects with only one week of data
were eliminated in order to ensure the continuity of transition
of states from week to week when building the HMM model.

for the remaining analyses because its performance was equiv-

scores. Additionally, it was notable that the AUC related to self-
reported physical health PROs such as Global Physical Health,
Fatigue, and Physical Function were higher than those related
to mental health such as Global Mental Health, Anxiety, and
Depression.
We then looked at the importance factor of each feature con-
tributing to the classiï¬cation in the RF model. Table III displays
the importance factor for the 14 feature types summed over
seven days. Features that were signiï¬cantly higher (p < 0.05)
than the average value for each classiï¬cation were determined.
Steps, total distance, calories, and calories BMR contributed to
most of the PRO scores. The importance factor of light active
distance was signiï¬cantly better than other features for classify-
ing Global Physical Health and Physical Function, which were
both related to a subjectâ€™s physical health. On the other hand,
resting heart rate contributed signiï¬cantly more than other fea-
tures for classiï¬cation of mental health PROs such as Anxiety
and Depression, while its importance factor was not signiï¬cantly
higher than other features in classiï¬cation of PROs related to
physical health.
The analysis was repeated using the RF classiï¬er and only the
signiï¬cant features from Table III and are shown in Table IV .
Because some studies such as [38] only used steps data to assess
userâ€™s health status, we also compared the model performance
in the same manner. The result suggested that the RF model
can generate signiï¬cantly better classiï¬cation accuracy with the
selected features than all features from Fitbit for all PROMIS
short form survey scores except for Global Mental Health (p =
0.37), with the highest AUC of 0.76 for classiï¬cation of Physical
Function.

Table V displayed the comparison of means and standard
deviations of the AUC for each PRO measure using the inde-
pendent model and HMM. AUCs derived using the HMM were
signiï¬cantly', ' used in this study, which lacks pre-
cision as mental health is a broad and complicated ï¬eld. More
thorough evaluations of subjectsâ€™ mental states could provide
more descriptive labels for training machine learning models,
which could further improve performance in predicting mental
health status.
Our highest AUC was 0.79 from classiï¬cation of Physical
Function, which demonstrated the correlation between data col-
lected from Fitbit and PROs. However, the AUC values also
indicated that PROs cannot be completely determined by activ-
ity tracker data alone, suggesting that PROs, particularly those
pertaining to mental health such as depression, contain addi-
tional information that was not captured in the tracking devices.
While the current study demonstrates the use of activity track-
ers to capture information about patientâ€™s health status, in some
cases PROs could be a preferable method. Internet access en-
ables PRO data collection to be done outside of clinic through
web or mobile apps, which provides convenience and reduces
time commitment for patients.
According to Table III , steps and total distance have signiï¬-
cantly higher importance for classifying the majority of survey
scores, while calories BMR signiï¬cantly contributes to mental
health scores, like Anxiety and Depression. Their importance
factor may due to data quality, as previous studies [5]â€“[7] have
validated the data accuracy for step counts, distance travelled,
and energy expenditure for activity trackers, while other fea-
tures have not been validated in scientiï¬c work. As Fitbits are
not sold as medical devices, many of their features are not val-
idated or regulated like other medical devices. In our study, we
found inconsistency in sleep data and sleeping stages for sub-
jects. It was likely that Fitbit was taken off for charging during
nights. Therefore, future studies should notice user not always
charge it during nights to collect sleep data. Moreover, the data
elements that have been validated are generally only tested in
speciï¬c devices, rather than across all activity trackers, so it is
not clear how these validation results translate to other devices.
Future studies should be conducted to validate these features.
As indicated by the correlation between subjectâ€™s average
PRO scores and the number of missing PRO values, patients
with moderate to severe health status were less likely to com-
plete PRO questionnaires routinely, which may have introduced
bias for data collection in this study. Future studies could try
to provide incentives for continued participation, which may
mitigate study attrition. Eight PROMIS instruments were used
in this study, and some redundancy existed between the speciï¬c
short forms such as Fatigue or Anxiety to the general Global-10
short form. Our current approach treated each score indepen-
dently without considering this overlap. A possible future study
could predict PRO scores simultaneously in a joint model such
as Bayesian network, which considers the correlations between
PRO scores.
In our dataset of patients with SIHD based on adjudicated
clinical data, HMMs achieved signiï¬cantly higher classiï¬cation
accuracy than treating weeks independently because they took
advantage of correlations in subjectsâ€™ survey scores from week
to week. In our data-driven approach, the model states were de-
termined based on the distribution of PRO scores in the clinical
study [41]. Score bins for the states were deï¬ned to limit the
sparsity during training and make the number or states consistent
across all of the PROMIS PROs tested. However, this may not be
the optimal way to deï¬ne the number of states for clinical rep-
resentation of health status. Future studies could conduct some
analysis to ï¬nd out the optimum number of states, which may
further increase the classiï¬cation accuracy. In addition, another
future direction would approach', 'iï¬cation
accuracy than treating weeks independently because they took
advantage of correlations in subjectsâ€™ survey scores from week
to week. In our data-driven approach, the model states were de-
termined based on the distribution of PRO scores in the clinical
study [41]. Score bins for the states were deï¬ned to limit the
sparsity during training and make the number or states consistent
across all of the PROMIS PROs tested. However, this may not be
the optimal way to deï¬ne the number of states for clinical rep-
resentation of health status. Future studies could conduct some
analysis to ï¬nd out the optimum number of states, which may
further increase the classiï¬cation accuracy. In addition, another
future direction would approach this as a regression problem to
predict actual PRO scores with high precision over time.
Sequential deep learning models, such as recurrent neural net-
works (RNNs) and long-short-term-memory (LSTM) networks
have also demonstrated strong performance when dealing with
sequential data [42], [43]. Therefore, these techniques may hold
potential for applications to sensor data to classify or predict
health status. However, such methods generally require a large
amount of training data, which was not available in the cur-
rent study. In future studies, deep learning methods could be
explored if a sufï¬ciently large data set were collected.
While activity trackers are able to produce patient informa-
tion within seconds or minutes, the sampling periods for PROs
like PROMIS [13] are on the order of weeks, requiring down-
sampling of the Fitbit data for comparison. Given that the PROs
measured in this study are unlikely to vary signiï¬cantly from day
to day, this temporal resolution is appropriate for the application
of PRO prediction. However, predicting more acute events might
require more temporal resolution, which could be addressed by
using the activity tracker data at a ï¬ner time scale. Long term
follow-up with patients including recordings of clinical events
such as rehospitalizations could also allow us to evaluate the
effect of mHealth monitoring on clinical outcome, an important
step in determining the efï¬cacy of such an intervention.
VI. C ONCLUSION
A temporal machine learning model can be used to classify
self-reported physical health in patients with SIHD using phys-
iological indices measured by activity trackers. By constructing
an HMM with feature selection and an RF classiï¬er, the result-
ing model can achieve an AUC of 0.79 for classifying Physical
Function. Our result indicates data generated from activity track-
ers may be used in a machine learning framework to classify

could play a future role in larger frameworks for remotely moni-
