is made collectively on a group of samples (known as a
â€œbagâ€) instead of predicting on individual samples (known
as â€œinstancesâ€). MIL techniques align well with our time se-
ries data, where during the training phase only 1 label related
to the subject (bag label) is known while the individual labels
of the compressed windows (instance labels) remain un-
known. In the testing phase the primary objective is to predict
1 clinical outcome for each subject. The key concept in MIL
Naseri et al ME-TIME: CVD Detection Using Smartwatches and AI 167

is that each bag of instances is labeled as positive (heart dis-
ease) if it contains a certain amount of positive instances and
negative (healthy) if it contains no positive instances (only
negative instances). Although traditional MIL approaches
often classify a bag as positive even with just 1 positive
instance, we aim to minimize false-positives by setting a
threshold on the number of positive instances required to la-
bel a bag as positive. This threshold will be determined
through hyperparameter tuning. Thus, instead of learning a
model that predicts the cardiovascular outcome of individual
instances, we are learning a model that predicts the outcome
of a bag of instances.
Algorithm validation
In our speciï¬c setting where the model encounters data from
previously unseen subjects without any prior knowledge, we
use leave-p-subjects-out cross-validation (LPSOCV). This
approach, shown inFigure 4, ensures a more accurate reï¬‚ec-
tion of real-world situations. LPSOCV involves multiple iter-
ations, or folds, during which data from distinct subjects are
used for training and validation purposes (ie, the model is
validated on data from subjects that the model is not trained
on), mitigating observation bias.
Machine learning models are sensitive to the distribution
of classes. To mitigate potential bias owing to different class
distributions in each fold, we incorporate stratiï¬cation during
the cross-validation process. This ensures that the ratio of
nonarrhythmic, atrial ï¬brillation, and heart failure subjects
remains approximately consistent and that the inï¬‚uence of
inconsistent class distribution across different folds is mini-
mized.
However, Fitbit time series data exhibit inter-subject vari-
ability resulting from individualsâ€™ distinct physical attri-
butes,
10 making the development of a universally effective
model for â€œnewâ€ subjects challenging. In order to examine
the effect of inter-subject variability, we will assess the model
on 2 distinct test sets. Theï¬rst is an external test set that con-
sists of subjects not previously encountered, randomly
selected to make up 20% of the total subjects, with an equal
number from each class. This allows us to evaluate the
modelâ€™s generalization capabilities. The second test set is
an internal one, encompassing theï¬nal 20% of data from

Initial setup Under traditional supervised learning,
each window must be annotated to train a machine
learning model. However, in our MIL setting (Figure 3),
only the bag label is known for the entire set of windows
related to a subject. A bag label is considered negative if', ' learning is used, where each observation of the data has
a class label. This must be done with ECGs, since photople-
thysmography or derived signals are difï¬cult to interpret by a
clinician. This so-called labeling or annotating of signals by
physicians is infeasible for the large amounts of (continuous)
data required, and therefore semi-automated
4,5 and fully
automated2,3 ECG labeling systems6 have been developed.
However, these still require a lot of manual labor from contin-
uously monitored users.
Therefore, the objective of the ME-TIME is (early) detec-
tion and prevention of heart disease by leveraging time series
data from smartwatches, a cloud-based infrastructure, and
machine learning algorithms speciï¬cally designed to func-
tion effectively with minimal labeling efforts.
Methods
Study design and data collection
ME-TIME (registered at ClinicalTrials.gov; ID:
NCT05802563) is designed as an observational cohort study
consisting of 3 data subject groups, as depicted inFigure 1.
The ï¬rst group consists of patients with systolic heart failure
(HF group); the second group consists of patients with docu-
mented atrial ï¬brillation (AF group); and the third group,
serving as a reference, consists of healthy volunteers. The
rationale for creating distinct AF and HF groups comes
from their unique pathophysiological characteristics. Conse-
quently, heart rate patterns that are indicative of these dis-
eases might also be different. The HF group consists of 50
study participants with systolic heart failure, deï¬ned as a
left ventricular ejection fraction,35% without documented
atrial ï¬brillation. The AF group consists of 50 patients with
documented atrialï¬brillation (paroxysmal, persistent, or per-
manent) without systolic heart failure. Ejection fractions will
be assessed from echocardiograms that are made within 1
year of inclusion, and if this is not available an echocardio-
gram will be performed. The reference group consists of
100 participants without any prior medical history and
without medication use. Potential study subjects that meet

Introduction
Cardiovascular disease is one of the leading causes of mortal-
ity globally1 and cardiovascular healthcare accounts for a
large portion of global healthcare costs and expenses. Early
detection and prevention will decrease the burden of cardio-
vascular disease and will therefore decrease mortality,
morbidity, and costs. Cardiovascular monitoring using big
data from wearables and machine learning can drastically in-
crease the availability and ef ï¬ciency of cardiovascular
healthcare globally, at the fraction of the costs of conven-
tional medical-grade devices.
Electrocardiogram (ECG) monitoring, such as Holters or
implantable loop recorders, are the gold standard for moni-
toring of outpatients with known or suspected arrhythmias.
However, they are burdensome, can only be used for a
limited period of time, and are expensive. Implantable loop
recorders are invasive and have to be manually activated
and analyzed in the hospital. This severely limits the use of
these devices for long-term home monitoring of patients,
and they have suboptimal patient comfort. For patients with
chronic cardiovascular diseases, such as atrial ï¬brillation
and heart failure, this implies frequent hospital visits and

With the widespread availability of reliable, consumer-
grade wearables such as smartwatches, continuous moni-
toring of, for example, heart rate with photoplethysmography
and step counting with accelerometers is possible. This moni-
toring is easy, patient friendly, and cost effective. Combining
the power of large amounts of data (big data) and novel ma-
chine learning techniques, these time series can be used to
detect and perhaps even predict cardiovascular disease, there-

er, as not all wearables have the same characteristics and
quality. Consequently, they have been used with moderate
success.
2,3 They also provide less informative diagnostic sig-
nals as compared to, for example, electrocardiography or
other commonly used cardiologic diagnostic modalities.
The challenge but also the strength of machine learning
models is that they learn by example and therefore large
amounts of data are needed for which the cardiovascular
outcome (class label) has been determined. Typically, super-
vised learning is used, where each observation of the data has
a class label. This must be done with ECGs, since photople-
thysmography or derived signals are difï¬cult to interpret by a
clinician. This so-called labeling or annotating of signals by
physicians is infeasible for the large amounts of (continuous)
data required, and therefore semi-automated
4,5 and fully
automated2,3 ECG labeling systems6 have been developed.
However, these still require a lot of manual labor from contin-
uously monitored users.
Therefore, the objective of the ME-TIME is (early) detec-
tion and prevention of heart disease by leveraging time series
data from smartwatches, a cloud-based infrastructure, and
machine learning algorithms']

Introduction
Cardiovascular disease is one of the leading causes of mortal-
ity globally1 and cardiovascular healthcare accounts for a
large portion of global healthcare costs and expenses. Early
detection and prevention will decrease the burden of cardio-
vascular disease and will therefore decrease mortality,
morbidity, and costs. Cardiovascular monitoring using big
data from wearables and machine learning can drastically in-
crease the availability and ef ï¬ciency of cardiovascular
healthcare globally, at the fraction of the costs of conven-
tional medical-grade devices.
Electrocardiogram (ECG) monitoring, such as Holters or
implantable loop recorders, are the gold standard for moni-
toring of outpatients with known or suspected arrhythmias.
However, they are burdensome, can only be used for a
limited period of time, and are expensive. Implantable loop
recorders are invasive and have to be manually activated
and analyzed in the hospital. This severely limits the use of
these devices for long-term home monitoring of patients,
and they have suboptimal patient comfort. For patients with
chronic cardiovascular diseases, such as atrial ï¬brillation
and heart failure, this implies frequent hospital visits and

Patients will be asked by their treating physician if they
may be approached by an investigator to inform them about
the study and potential participation. Healthy participants are
recruited through local advertising. Anyone that is interested
will then receive an information brochure and informed con-
sent form. At least 2 days after the patientâ€™s receipt of the
brochure, the research team will call the patient to schedule
an appointment. During this visit, the patient submits the
signed consent form and will undergo an ECG and blood
pressure measurement that will be analyzed by an experi-
enced cardiologist (I.B.). Participants can use their own Fitbit
and are otherwise provided with a Fitbit Inspire 2 or Fitbit
Charge 5 smartwatch. The device type is assigned to a partic-
ipant at random to prevent device sampling bias. This will
also help to investigate the effect of device type on the perfor-
mance of theï¬nal model. A Fitbit account will be created for
all participants which will be connected to a custom-built
data platform using the Google Cloud Platform. Our platform
features a data portal for research staff to easily register or de-
register participants by authorizing a connection to their Fit-
bit data. Data are extracted daily from Fitbits until the
observation period ends and can be analyzed either in the
cloud or locally.
All participants will be asked toï¬ll out a survey regarding
their health. All participants are monitored for a period of 3
months. After written consent from the 200 subjects, heart
rate, step counter, and sleep time series data are extracted
from the data platform. Clinical metadata such as age, height,
weight, blood pressure at baseline, health survey, and medi-
cation use are saved in the Castor (Ciwit BV, Amsterdam,
The Netherlands) electronic database.
Data privacy
After performing a thorough data protection impact assess-
ment, the local hospital security information and privacy of-
ï¬cers granted permission to perform the study. This was also
validated by the ethics review board. The data protection

forming to the European General Data Protection Regulation.
To protect the data privacy of the participants, all data are
pseudonymized. Only the researchers have access to the
sensor data, and only the Principal Investigator has access
to personal information of participants (ie, names, contact in-
formation, etc). They have all signed processing agreements.
Second, the Google servers storing the data are only located
within the Netherlands; hence the data does not leave the
country, therefore conforming to Dutch law. This is done
to have a clear data infrastructure both legally and technically
to explain to participants.

Data characteristics and preparation
The dataï¬rst undergoes a process involving resampling and
artifact removal. In our experience with Fitbit smartwatches,
the heart rate is nonuniformly sampled, with a prevalent rate
of 0.2 Hz. Therefore, the heart rate is resampled to once per 5
seconds. The step counter is sampled once per minute.
Artifacts involving samples with numerous consecutive
constant values are removed, if more than 12 consecutive
constant values (equivalent to 1 minute of heart rate samples)
are detected. This 1-minute threshold was chosen based on
visual inspection, which revealed that heart rate patterns typi-
cally occur in the order of minutes, often spanning 10â€“20 mi-
nutes. For sequences with fewer than 12 consecutive missing
values, linear interpolation is applied. From the cleaned time
series, smaller segments, denoted as windows, are extracted
and employed as input for a machine learning model. This
process involves a sliding window and windows containing
time gaps are excluded. Windows have 2 design consider-
ations: the window size, which determines the number of
samples within a window and deï¬nes its dimensionality,
and the stride, which establishes the step size dictating the
shift between windows.
Although the cardiovascular condition of each subject is
known, it is unknown in which speciï¬c windows these con-
ditions manifest themselves. This is owing to the paroxysmal
nature of atrialï¬brillation and the variable symptoms of heart
failure, which can be inï¬‚uenced by factors like medication
adjustments, dietary changes, and the diseaseâ€™s progressive
course. In other words, the subject label is known, but the in-
dividual window labels are unknown. This is visually repre-
sented inFigure 2a, where the subject label is depicted by the
blue/red colors and the unknown window labels are indicated
by black dotted lines.

Our planned machine learning approach is tailored to operate
in this setting through a 2-stage process. To learn informative
patterns/features directly from the input data, despite the lack

supervised learning. A commonly used self-supervised

to a lower-dimensional representation and then reconstruct-

Discussion
By building a suitable infrastructure with Cloud technology,
big data acquired in the study is used to develop data-efï¬cient
models using methods from multiple instance and self-
supervised learning.
We aim to examine the inï¬‚uence of inter-subject vari-
ability on predicting cardiovascular disease and will explore
potential methods to mitigate these variabilities.
13,14 We
expect that patterns indicative of cardiovascular disease
become apparent within a timeframe of minutes, hours, or
more, considering that consumer-grade wearables have a
slower sampling rate compared to the gold standard. We
have shown 1 example of such a pattern: the acceleration-
deceleration curve. Preselecting windows based on such

lag show a different proï¬le for healthy and AF group individ-
uals, showing that it is meaningful to analyze step counter
and heart rate together. Big data for heart disease detection
requires substantial labeling efforts from physicians.
Using self-supervised learning and MIL, a model can be
trained with much fewer labels. Ourï¬ndings demonstrate
this by employing MILES to achieve high speciï¬city, which
can aid in ruling out heart disease in individuals experiencing
symptoms similar to heart disease but without the condition
(ie, false-positives).
Conclusion
The ongoing ME-TIME study is a longitudinal observational
study that uses machine learning with time series data from
consumer-grade smartwatches to detect atrial ï¬brillation
and heart failure. This will contribute to cost-effective cardio-
vascular monitoring of outpatients, thereby reducing exacer-
bation of cardiovascular disease and effectively increasing
capacity of global cardiovascular healthcare.

often classify a bag as positive even with just 1 positive
instance, we aim to minimize false-positives by setting a
threshold on the number of positive instances required to la-
bel a bag as positive. This threshold will be determined
through hyperparameter tuning. Thus, instead of learning a
model that predicts the cardiovascular outcome of individual
instances, we are learning a model that predicts the outcome
of a bag of instances.
Algorithm validation
In our speciï¬c setting where the model encounters data from
previously unseen subjects without any prior knowledge, we
use leave-p-subjects-out cross-validation (LPSOCV). This
approach, shown inFigure 4, ensures a more accurate reï¬‚ec-
tion of real-world situations. LPSOCV involves multiple iter-
ations, or folds, during which data from distinct subjects are
used for training and validation purposes (ie, the model is
validated on data from subjects that the model is not trained
on), mitigating observation bias.
Machine learning models are sensitive to the distribution
of classes. To mitigate potential bias owing to different class
distributions in each fold, we incorporate stratiï¬cation during
the cross-validation process. This ensures that the ratio of
nonarrhythmic, atrial ï¬brillation, and heart failure subjects
remains approximately consistent and that the inï¬‚uence of
inconsistent class distribution across different folds is mini-
mized.
However, Fitbit time series data exhibit inter-subject vari-

selected to make up 20% of the total subjects, with an equal
number from each class. This allows us to evaluate the

ME-TIME (registered at ClinicalTrials.gov; ID:
NCT05802563) is designed as an observational cohort study
consisting of 3 data subject groups, as depicted inFigure 1.
The ï¬rst group consists of patients with systolic heart failure
(HF group); the second group consists of patients with docu-
mented atrial ï¬brillation (AF group); and the third group,
serving as a reference, consists of healthy volunteers. The
rationale for creating distinct AF and HF groups comes
from their unique pathophysiological characteristics. Conse-
quently, heart rate patterns that are indicative of these dis-
eases might also be different. The HF group consists of 50
study participants with systolic heart failure, deï¬ned as a
left ventricular ejection fraction,35% without documented
atrial ï¬brillation. The AF group consists of 50 patients with
documented atrialï¬brillation (paroxysmal, persistent, or per-
manent) without systolic heart failure. Ejection fractions will
be assessed from echocardiograms that are made within 1
year of inclusion, and if this is not available an echocardio-
gram will be performed. The reference group consists of
100 participants without any prior medical history and
without medication use. Potential study subjects that meet

is becoming a more prevailing condition, affecting about 25 to

Also, it is observed that the developed classiï¬cation model

However, it is observed that in most of the cases, the latency
does not exceed 150 ms with moderate network connectivity
(approximately 2 Mbps bandwidth). We strongly feel that this
paper can aid future researchers for improving the state of
the art research in the development of scalable and low-cost
eHealth applications.
V. CONCLUSION
In this paper, we proposed and developed a low-cost and
easily scalable eHealth architecture comprising of a web
application for automatic classiï¬cation of fatty liver using
ultrasound images. The developed web application is easy to
use and requires no change in the current infrastructure. The
ultrasound images obtained using the traditional ultrasound
scanners can be uploaded to the developed web application
using moderate network connectivity and the web application
then classiï¬es the image into either normal or abnormal using
a CNN based framework. The performance of the proposed
framework is tested with with 58 ultrasound images, we have
developed a custom database comprising of 58 ultrasound
images with liver information of which 36 correspond to liver
images are normal conditions and the rest correspond to a fatty
liver condition. It is observed that the proposed framework
achieves an average accuracy of 91.37%. Also, the latency
analysis shows that the proposed CNN model predicts within
20 ms when running on a PC with Intel i7 processor and 16 GB
RAM. Also when considered along with the network latency
the total latency observed is approximately 150 ms when used
with moderate network connectivity. Hence, we strongly feel
that the proposed eHealth framework will help future research
in developing low-cost, easily scalable and ubiquitous eHealth
frameworks. Our future scope of this work is to develop a more
robust classiï¬cation framework which can eliminate the false
negatives. Also, we would like to consider real-time trials in
coordination with hospitals to analyze the performance in real
constraints.

III. D EVELOPED CNN BASED ACCURATE FATTY LIVER
CLASSIFICATION FRAMEWORK
In [19], we have developed a novel CNN based accurate
fatty liver classiï¬cation model using ultrasound images. The
same model is adopted in this paper for the classiï¬cation of
fatty liver using ultrasound images. The architecture comprises
of a pre-trained VGG-16 model along with the transfer learn-
ing and ï¬ne-tuning. VGGNet using CNN is initially designed
with different layer depths aiming for image recognition tasks.
Preliminary analysis of VGGNet offered a promising accuracy
of 92.7% when validated using the ImagNet dataset com-
prising of 14 million images from 1000 classes [20]. In this
paper, we make use the 16 layers VGG-16 with convolution
blocks(including convolution layers and max-pooling layers)
and a fully connected classiï¬er. The ï¬ne-tuning is carried out
using the pre-trained VGG-16 model in Keras. Traditionally,
the convolution 2D layers in VGG-16 consists of 512 nodes for
convolution layers, however, in our experiment we ï¬ne-tuned
the network from using 512 nodes to 256 nodes. Also, we ï¬ne-
tuned fully connected layers having 4096 nodes to 256 nodes,
and the output layer comprises two neurons whose output
corresponds to the two classes (normal and abnormal) in this
study. During the training of the model, the weight parameters
of the output layer are initialized using random Gaussian
distribution, and the training is performed over 100 epochs.
Since the development of the CNN based accurate fatty liver
classiï¬cation framework is not our primary contribution in this
paper, we would like to advise the readers to kindly refer [19]
for more details on the developed model. However, we would
like to highlight that the database used for validation in [19]
is different from what we used here.
IV. R ESULTS
The publicly available datasets for ultrasound images of the
liver are very few. Hence, due to the unavailability of the
public datasets, we acquired and developed our own dataset
using a GE LOGIQ F6 ultrasound scanner in collaboration
with MNR Medical College, Sangareddy, Hyderabad, India.
The dataset consisted of 58 representative liver images com-
prising of both fatty liver (22 images) and normal conditions
(36 images). We cropped the images which does not convey
any diagnostic information such as hospital name, time of the
diagnosis, etc. Also, since the pre-trained models are trained
with an input image size of 224Ã—224 pixels, the images of
our dataset were also resized to 224Ã—224 pixels for compat-
ibility. The performance of the proposed model is analyzed
considering classiï¬cation accuracy, confusion matrix, Fscore,
Precision, and Recall as the key performance metrics. The

Abstractâ€”Medical imaging techniques are being profoundly
used for diagnosis of many diseases. In many of the remote areas
in the developing nations, patients who live in rural areas are
facing vital health disparities compared to the general population.
In such scenarios, eHealth can offer promising solutions. The
eHealth especially aims at developing digital applications for
offering high accuracy diagnosis even in remote areas. Also,
the integration of eHealth with advanced technologies such as
deep learning and artiï¬cial intelligence will further improve
the diagnostic accuracy and also reduces the duration. In this
paper, we develop a novel low-cost and easily scalable eHealth
architecture comprising of a web application which enables
clinicians in fatty liver classiï¬cation using ultrasound images.
The developed web application framework uses a deep learning
model (using CNN) for accurate classiï¬cation of fatty liver
using ultrasound images. The clinician in a remote location
with a moderate internet connectivity can upload the scanned
ultrasound image to the developed web application and the
application identiï¬es if any abnormality is present. From the
performance analysis, it is observed that the developed model
achieves an accuracy of 91.37%. Also, regarding latency the
developed classiï¬cation model predicts the abnormality presence
in less than 20 ms. However, including the network latency, it is
observed that the developed eHealth architecture predicts with a
latency of less than 150 ms using moderate network connectivity.
Index Termsâ€”eHealth, Artiï¬cial Intelligence, Fatty liver clas-
siï¬cation, Ultrasound, CAD, IoT Architecture
I. I NTRODUCTION
The Internet of Things (IoT) is rapidly proliferating into
many sectors including healthcare. Today most of the health-
care services starting from in-hospital patient care to remote
healthcare are utilizing IoT technologies to improve the af-
fordability and reachability [1]. Especially in the developing
countries where healthcare providers are inadequate compared
to the total population, this can be a promising solution [2].
In the recent past many technologies such as wearables for
automated electrocardiogram monitoring, glucose and blood
pressure monitoring, and epilepsy detection have been devel-
oped at low cost using IoT technologies [3], [4]. However,
there is a long way to go before the healthcare becomes truly
pervasive and ubiquitous, especially in the developing nations.
Importantly, in the case of medical imaging technologies, the
high cost of the infrastructure is hindering the adoption of
IoT technologies which realizes the telemedicine or remote
healthcare delivery [5]. Due to the lack of skilled sonographers
or physicians in the rural areas, the majority of people are
suffering from inaccurate diagnosis being offered by the semi-
skilled clinicians. Especially, the ultrasound imaging which
is a widely used modality for diagnosing various diseases
pertaining to multiple organs requires skilled clinicians for
offering accurate diagnosis [6]. Hence, we strongly feel that
the usage of IoT and artiï¬cial intelligence based technologies
will signiï¬cantly improve the current state of the healthcare.
In this paper, our primary contributions include:
1) Developed a novel low-cost and scalable eHealth archi-
tecture for classifying the fatty liver using ultrasound
images.
2) Developed a web application that enables sonographers
in the remote areas for classifying the fatty liver by
uploading the scanned ultrasound images.
3) The web application developed using a convolution', ' are
suffering from inaccurate diagnosis being offered by the semi-
skilled clinicians. Especially, the ultrasound imaging which
is a widely used modality for diagnosing various diseases
pertaining to multiple organs requires skilled clinicians for
offering accurate diagnosis [6]. Hence, we strongly feel that
the usage of IoT and artiï¬cial intelligence based technologies
will signiï¬cantly improve the current state of the healthcare.
In this paper, our primary contributions include:
1) Developed a novel low-cost and scalable eHealth archi-
tecture for classifying the fatty liver using ultrasound
images.
2) Developed a web application that enables sonographers
in the remote areas for classifying the fatty liver by
uploading the scanned ultrasound images.
3) The web application developed using a convolutional
neural network (CNN) along with ï¬ne-tuning and trans-
fer learning based framework for the classiï¬cation of the
fatty liver using ultrasound images.
4) Development of dataset comprising of 58 liver ultra-
sound images (of which 22 correspond to fatty liver)
for analyzing the performance of the proposed eHealth
framework.
5) Performance analysis considering latency and classiï¬ca-
tion accuracy as the key performance metrics.
The usage of information and communication technology
(ICT) or more broadly IoT technologies in healthcare delivery
is generally referred to as eHealth [7]. In promoting universal
health coverage, eHealth plays an important role by provid-
ing low cost healthcare services to remote and under-served
populations. It improves the accuracy of diagnosis by uti-
lizing IoT and artiï¬cial intelligence technologies. Ultrasound
scanners are usually located in well-established hospitals due
to their huge form factor, cost and need for a person who
is well trained in sonography. With the advancements in
computing technology, conventional ultrasound scanner are
reduced to portable ultrasound scanners for improving the
ease of scanning in rural and emergency locations [8], [9].
Also, they support IoT technologies wherein a doctor situated978-1-5386-4980-0/19/$31.00 Â©2019 IEEE

III. D EVELOPED CNN BASED ACCURATE FATTY LIVER
CLASSIFICATION FRAMEWORK
In [19], we have developed a novel CNN based accurate
fatty liver classiï¬cation model using ultrasound images. The
same model is adopted in this paper for the classiï¬cation of
fatty liver using ultrasound images. The architecture comprises
of a pre-trained VGG-16 model along with the transfer learn-
ing and ï¬ne-tuning. VGGNet using CNN is initially designed
with different layer depths aiming for image recognition tasks.
Preliminary analysis of VGGNet offered a promising accuracy
of 92.7% when validated using the ImagNet dataset com-
prising of 14 million images from 1000 classes [20]. In this
paper, we make use the 16 layers VGG-16 with convolution
blocks(including convolution layers and max-pooling layers)
and a fully connected classiï¬er. The ï¬ne-tuning is carried out
using the pre-trained VGG-16 model in Keras. Traditionally,
the convolution 2D layers in VGG-16 consists of 512 nodes for
convolution layers, however, in our experiment we ï¬ne-tuned
the network from using 512 nodes to 256 nodes. Also, we ï¬ne-
tuned fully connected layers having 4096 nodes to 256 nodes,
and the output layer comprises two neurons whose output
corresponds to the two classes (normal and abnormal) in this
study. During the training of the model, the weight parameters
of the output layer are initialized using random Gaussian
distribution, and the training is performed over 100 epochs.
Since the development of the CNN based accurate fatty liver
classiï¬cation framework is not our primary contribution in this
paper, we would like to advise the readers to kindly refer [19]
for more details on the developed model. However, we would
like to highlight that the database used for validation in [19]
is different from what we used here.
IV. R ESULTS
The publicly available datasets for ultrasound images of the
liver are very few. Hence, due to the unavailability of the
public datasets, we acquired and developed our own dataset
using a GE LOGIQ F6 ultrasound scanner in collaboration
with MNR Medical College, Sangareddy, Hyderabad, India.
The dataset consisted of 58 representative liver images com-
prising of both fatty liver (22 images) and normal conditions
(36 images). We cropped the images which does not convey
any diagnostic information such as hospital name, time of the
diagnosis, etc. Also, since the pre-trained models are trained
with an input image size of 224Ã—224 pixels, the images of
our dataset were also resized to 224Ã—224 pixels for compat-
ibility. The performance of the proposed model is analyzed

Also, it is observed that the developed classiï¬cation model

when running on an Intel i7 processor with 16 GB RAM.
However, it is observed that in most of the cases, the latency
does not exceed 150 ms with moderate network connectivity
(approximately 2 Mbps bandwidth). We strongly feel that this
paper can aid future researchers for improving the state of
the art research in the development of scalable and low-cost
eHealth applications.
V. CONCLUSION
In this paper, we proposed and developed a low-cost and
easily scalable eHealth architecture comprising of a web
application for automatic classiï¬cation of fatty liver using
ultrasound images. The developed web application is easy to
use and requires no change in the current infrastructure. The
ultrasound images obtained using the traditional ultrasound
scanners can be uploaded to the developed web application
using moderate network connectivity and the web application
then classiï¬es the image into either normal or abnormal using
a CNN based framework. The performance of the proposed
framework is tested with with 58 ultrasound images, we have
developed a custom database comprising of 58 ultrasound
images with liver information of which 36 correspond to liver
images are normal conditions and the rest correspond to a fatty
liver condition. It is observed that the proposed framework
achieves an average accuracy of 91.37%. Also, the latency
analysis shows that the proposed CNN model predicts within
20 ms when running on a PC with Intel i7 processor and 16 GB
RAM. Also when considered along with the network latency
the total latency observed is approximately 150 ms when used
with moderate network connectivity. Hence, we strongly feel
that the proposed eHealth framework will help future research
in developing low-cost, easily scalable and ubiquitous eHealth
frameworks. Our future scope of this work is to develop a more
robust classiï¬cation framework which can eliminate the false
negatives. Also, we would like to consider real-time trials in
coordination with hospitals to analyze the performance in real
constraints.
VI. ACKNOWLEDGMENT

of Gastroenterology and MNR Medical College & Hospital,

3) Data Enhancement: In the context of the small number
of participants in this rare disease, a need arose to improve
the model during training performance. This data enhance-
ment was performed using frame difference and image-cutting
methods.
a) Frame difference method: the frame difference
method was used [45] for data augmentation, by adding images
with significant differences between consecutive frames to the
dataset. Therefore, high-quality images could be more effec-
tively used by the model. Specifically, the frame difference
method is a method of obtaining the contour of a mov-
ing object by performing differential operations on adjacent
frames in a video image sequence. When there is abnor-
mal object movement in the video, there will be significant
differences between frames. Subtract two frames [I (x, y, t)
and I (x, y, t âˆ’ 1)] to obtain the absolute value of the pixel
difference [D(x, y, t)] between the two images and determine
whether it is greater than the threshold to determine whether
there is object motion in the image sequence, as shown in the
following formula:
D(x, y, t) = |I (x, y, t) âˆ’ I (x, y, t âˆ’ 1)|. (8)
First, we performed median filtering, binarization, and dila-
tion corrosion on the grayscale image to extract the contour of
the object. Second, a motion selection frame was performed
by comparing the difference D(x, y, t) between the front
and back frames, the area with a motion difference value
is greater than the set motion threshold was selected. As
shown in Fig. 5, using the frame difference method allows
not only to distinguish the characters from the background
but also to extract the parts of the human body that have
undergone obvious changes. It should be noted that the motion
selection boxes will have a large number of overlapping areas.
In this study, the representative motion selection boxes were
selected according to the nonmaximum-suppression (NMS)
algorithm [46]. The principle of the NMS algorithm is to retain
the detection box with the highest confidence score for the
same object among multiple detection boxes while suppressing
other boxes with lower confidence scores. Finally, according to
the relationship between the number of motion-selected boxes
in the image and the set threshold k, it is determined whether
the frame image needs to be copied. According to the ablation
experimental results, we determine the value of k to be 1,
which can maximize the gain of model performance.
b) Image cutting method: After processing by using the
frame difference method, we could obtain a large amount
of effective image data, and then, these data were subjected

1) Data Description: HD patients were recruited from the

Yat-sen University. Patients and their family provided their

patientâ€™s privacy. The clinical data of patients, including the

25 males and 23 females. The mean age of participants

population groups: 1) family members of patients (such as
asymptomatic partners or gene-negative family members); 2)
volunteers recruited through the â€œone-stop medical serviceâ€
WeChat public account platform; and 3) volunteers recruited
through the online platform of the Department of Neurology,
The First Affiliated Hospital, Sun Yat-sen University.
We obtained 1511 video data sets from patients and controls
by using mobile phones 30 frames/s. The videos were mainly
taken by family members after appropriate instructions and by
staff from the First Affiliated Hospital, Sun Yat-sen University.
Each participant provided 6â€“50 videos, including in standing
posture, from front, side, and back; and sitting posture, walk-
ing, and from the face.
2) Data Processing: First of all, due to interference in the
shooting process, it was necessary to manually filter out higher
quality video samples with clear shooting and less background
interference. After the screening, the total number of video
data per patient was reduced to approximately six segments,
the average length of these videos was 60â€“80 s.
Next, the video data were then converted into image matri-
ces for processing. We frame sample the video at a rate of one
image every second. Afterward, the image was converted into

and reduce the learning burden of the 3D-CNN network. After

3) Data Enhancement: In the context of the small number
of participants in this rare disease, a need arose to improve

ment was performed using frame difference and image-cut', ' However,
shortcomings are to be mentioned. Clinical scoring scales [4],
[5] require well-trained neurologists to obtain reliable data, and
they are not easily adaptable for remote clinical assessment
1) Although the reliability of biological marker-based [3]
diagnostic methods is good, these methods require
expensive instruments with inherent issues to be used
on a large scale. Use of wearable devices [7], [8] can
generate data at a low cost. However, this method is a
contact method, which is not convenient for long-term
tracking and analysis of patients, and the probability of
inhomogeneous assessment is relatively high.
2) Previously, several machine learning models [13], [17]
have been used in HD assessment, including the anal-
ysis models of wearable devices and voice. However,
some obvious defects hinder their application in clinical
practice. For example, voice-based methods need to first
extract voice features and then use statistics or machine
learning models for analysis. This two-stage method
may lead to unstable analysis results.
3) HD is rare disease and the prevalence is low as 0.38 per
100 000 person-years. Therefore, it is difficult to obtain
a large number of HD video data for traditional machine
learning models. Indeed, data scarcity usually results
in unstable analysis of traditional machine learning
model [22]. How to obtain accurate assessment results
through few-shot data is very important to model devel-
opment and clinical application.

an end-to-end few-shot video analysis model. The proposed

To extract HD features from limited data, our model integrates
more effective attention modules [44], allowing it to perform
better on HD evaluation tasks.
As shown in Fig. 2, our solution includes three steps. First,
we design an upstream feature extraction module, where input
video samples receive data enhancement and feature extraction
(Fi ) using the frame difference method and convolutional
network module, respectively. Subsequently, multihead atten-
tion, including channel and spatial attention, is leveraged to
improve the modelâ€™s generalization and robustness. Second,
we used a 3-D ResNet-based backbone network module to
initially collaboratively learn spatialâ€“temporal characteristics
and then capture the correspondence between the features
of the two modalities at the pixel level. Third, to better
extract the spatial, temporal, and channel features from the
feature maps, we employed attention modules to optimize
the 3DResNet module. Specifically, we designed two bottle-
neck modules: squeeze excitation (SE) attention modules and
spatialâ€“temporal excitation (STE) attention modules. By rea-
sonably cross-embedding different bottleneck modules into
the 3DRes-Net model, our model can learn the interdepen-
dencies among different dimensions, promote useful features,
and suppress redundant features. Finally, all features were
processed using a fully connected layer, and a softmax layer
was employed to obtain the probability output for each disease
type.

II. R ELATED WORKS
A. Biological Markers-Based Model
Biomarkers are very common detection methods in the clin-
ical assessment of HD [24]. Currently, several new biomarkers
have been developed [3] to detect symptoms of ND diseases.
For example, blood-based assessments have been reported as
possible biomarkers for the evaluation of HD [25]. Given that
lipid composition and disturbances in lipoprotein metabolism
may be associated with the pathogenesis of HD, the plasma
lipoprotein profile has been proposed as predictive biomark-
ers for HD progression [3]. In addition, MRI [26] and
EEG [27], [28] have been explored biomarkers for HD. Based
on EEG features associated with disease progression in HD,
an automatic classifier has been developed to distinguish
healthy controls (HCs) from HD gene carriers. Similarly, MRI-
based [26] imaging biomarkers have been used to determine
the degree of morphological changes.
B. Wearable Device-Based Clinical Assessment Model
Unlike biomarker-based methods, wearable device-based
methods are less costly and more straightforward measure-
ments for disease evaluation. Indeed, wearable or portable
sensors have been shown to be effective in HD signs assess-
ment signs [7], [29]. Based on the data collected by sensors,
such as stride frequency, stride length, and walking speed,
several algorithms have been used for classifier training to
determine the progression of ND diseases such as Parkinsonâ€™s
disease (PD) [30], HD [13], and other hereditary disorders
(HA) [31], [32]. For example, machine learning classification
models have been applied to analyze gait datasets from wear-
able devices in PD [16], [33], including neural network (NN),
support vector machine (SVM), k-nearest neighbors (kNNs),
decision tree (DT), random forest (RF), and logistic regres-
sion (LR) [34]. These models were further optimized through
the comparison with the Movement Disorder Society Unified
PD Rating Scale (MDS-UPDRS) III [35]. As a result, these
models can assess the severity of ND diseases through', ' larger batch size. Here, IM âˆˆ RT âˆ—Câˆ—Hâˆ—W represents

represents the stacked cut images in the channel dimension. In

Specifically, we use indicators, such as recall rate and accu-
racy, to evaluate the model [47]. Among them, the recall rate
is of great significance for medical disease clinical assessment
because it can reflect the situation of missed assessment in a
model when diagnosing diseases. In medical disease clinical
assessment, if a model fails to diagnose a disease, the patient
may miss the optimal treatment opportunity, leading to the
deterioration of the disease. Specifically, HD, as a relatively
rare ND disease, has a high probability of missed assessment
in clinical practice. However, our model has a high recall
rate and high accuracy, which can reduce the risk of missed
assessment to a certain extent, and accurately target clinical
pain points.

1) Comparison With Other Models:First, the main meth-
ods for evaluating HD previously included scale analysis,
facial muscle group analysis model, and gait analysis for
comparison. Their shortcomings are very obvious. The scale
analysis uses the UHDRS diagnostic confidence level (DCL),
which is based on the evaluation of motor signs is relatively
limited. The facial muscle group analysis uses methods, such
as coordinate analysis and SVM, to analyze the amplitude
characteristics of facial expressions and the shaking of facial
small muscle groups. It is a non-end-to-end model with weak
generalization ability. The gait analysis measures the severity
of a patientâ€™s illness based on high-level gait characteristics,
requiring patients to wear', ', which could
effectively guarantee the robustness and stability of our model.
1) SE Block: As shown in Fig. 4(a), as a kind of channel
excitation, the SE block can explicitly model the interde-
pendencies between feature channels. It can access global
information and determine the importance of each feature
channel in two steps. This allows the network to promote
useful features and suppress irrelevant ones, enhancing its
sensitivity to informative features.
The squeeze operation performs feature compression along
the spatial dimension, turning each 2-D feature channel into a
real number that somehow has a global perceptual field. The
output dimension matches the number of input feature chan-
nels. It characterizes the global distribution of the response
over the feature channels and makes the global perceptual field
available to the layers close to the input. This was accom-
plished by performing global average pooling (GPooling) on
the original feature map C âˆ—W âˆ—H and obtaining a feature map
of size 1âˆ—1âˆ—C with a global perceptual field. The processing of
our channel attention module can be summarized as follows:

[' for classifier training to
determine the progression of ND diseases such as Parkinsonâ€™s
disease (PD) [30], HD [13], and other hereditary disorders
(HA) [31], [32]. For example, machine learning classification
models have been applied to analyze gait datasets from wear-
able devices in PD [16], [33], including neural network (NN),
support vector machine (SVM), k-nearest neighbors (kNNs),
decision tree (DT), random forest (RF), and logistic regres-
sion (LR) [34]. These models were further optimized through
the comparison with the Movement Disorder Society Unified
PD Rating Scale (MDS-UPDRS) III [35]. As a result, these
models can assess the severity of ND diseases through gait
analysis [36], thereby showing great potential as a clinical
tool for movement disorders.
C. Machine Learning-Based Model
Artificial intelligence models are used in the clinical
assessment of ND diseases [37], [38], [39]. In addition to
the above-mentioned biomarker-based models and gait-based
models that use artificial intelligence models, audio and
video-based diagnostic models have recently emerged. Given
that these audio and video data are often easier and more direct
to obtain, audio-based and video-based diagnostic models can
generate higher diagnostic accuracy.
For example, in a recent study, researchers first extracted
60 speech features from voice samples of in-affected and
presymptomatic gene carriers. After training the model in a
sample 51, they could predict the clinical HD characteristics in
the independent set [19]. These variables were associated with
the standard grades for training according to the rating scale.
By doing so, an accurate prediction model can be obtained.
Similarly, a video-based machine learning model has been
developed to analyze the relationship between hand motion
and MDS-UPDRS III score [40]. This study analyzed 272 PD
and non-PD hand movement videos with DeepLabCut was
used to identify joint points of the joints in the 2-D images
of the video. HandGraphCNN was then applied to predict
the 2-D and 3-D point positions of points. Finally, linear
regression (LR) and DT were used to analyze finger tapping
and hand movements, and pronation-supination movements of
the hands to get a highly significant correlation of the result
with the MDS-UPDRS scores. A clinical assessment model
based on facial landmark [41] has used face feature extractors
to get key points of a facial landmark of 176 video recordings
from 33 PD patients and 31 HCs. Machine learning algorithms,
such as LR, SVM, DT, RF, and LSTM, were used to analyze
the variation of the relative coordinates variation to distinguish
between patients and HCs.
III. O UR SOLUTION
This section describes our 3-D residual and attention
enhancement joint network (RAJNet) in detail. Unlike large
dataset available in [42] and [43], the scarcity of medical data
significantly limits the performance of deep learning models.
To extract HD features from limited data, our model integrates
more effective attention modules [44], allowing it to perform
better on HD evaluation tasks.
As shown in Fig. 2, our solution includes three steps. First,
we design an upstream feature extraction module, where input
video samples receive data enhancement and feature extraction
(Fi ) using the frame difference method and convolutional
network module, respectively. Subsequently, multihead atten-
tion, including channel and spatial attention, is leveraged to
improve the modelâ€™s generalization and robustness. Second,
we used a 3-D ResNet-based backbone network module to
initially collaboratively learn spatialâ€“temporal characteristics
and then capture the correspondence between the features
of the two modalities at the pixel', ' the y-axis represents
the true rate, and the area under curve (AUC) area is the
area enclosed by the ROC curve and the coordinate axis,
which is an important indicator of model performance [47].

The difference between set A and set B is only that set

Since the medication information plays a role in the MetS
diagnostic criteria as well we wanted to test the models with
and without it. More importantly, since we want our models
to be operable on a wide variety of cohorts and we do
recognize that reliable medication information can be difï¬cult
to obtain in some scenarios (e.g. electronic health records), it is
necessary to have a model without medications. Set C is the
best performing feature set as reported by Romero-Salda Ëœna
et al. [17]. Set D includes the anthropometric features that
we directly take from the diagnostic criteria of MetS. It is
important to note that unlike some previous work, we avoid
dichotomising any continuous feature variables. The most
noteworthy drawback of dichotomising continuous features is
that individuals close to but on opposite sides of the cutoff
are often characterized as being dissimilar rather than very
similar [21]. Although, since we use the currently established
dichotomous deï¬nition of MetS as the target variable, it
is possible that our models implicitly learn the thresholds,
specially for the features that were directly taken from the
diagnostic criteria.
D. Classiï¬cation Methods
Here we brieï¬‚y describe the classiï¬cation algorithms we
evaluated in this work.
1) Logistic Regression (LR): LR works similar to linear
regression, but with a binomial response variable. To avoid
overï¬tting we use L2 regularization (also known as ridge
regression).
2) Random F orest (RF):RF is an ensemble of randomly
constructed independent decision trees [22]. It usually exhibits
considerable performance improvements over single-tree clas-
siï¬er algorithms such as CART [23].
3) Gradient Boosting Machines (GBMs):In GBMs the al-
gorithm consecutively ï¬ts new models (in this case regression
trees) to provide a more accurate estimate of the target variable
[24]. Gradient boosting trains many models in an additive
and sequential manner. Gradient boosting of regression trees
usually produce highly robust and interpretable procedures for
classiï¬cation, even in situations when the training data are not
so clean [24].
4) Ensemble Classiï¬er: Finally we also built an ensemble
classiï¬er by combining the outputs from the three methods
mentioned above (LR, RF and GBM). Instead of the more
popular hard voting approach which selects the target label
which was predicted by the majority of the classiï¬ers, here we
use a soft voting ensemble technique which takes an average
of output probabilities of the base classiï¬ers and based on
the average value it decides on the target label. The primary
difference between the two approaches is that soft voting also
takes into account how certain each classiï¬er is about the
prediction.
E. Evaluation
The experiment was designed to compare each feature set
and classiï¬cation algorithm combination against each other.

The models are evaluated based on two main criteria, namely
the discriminative performance and the model calibration.
1) Dis', ' calibrated [28]. There are different ways to check for
model calibration, calibration plot usually being the preferred
approach [27], [29]. To evaluate the calibration performance
we also report the Brier score for each classiï¬er [30]. Brier
score measures the mean squared difference between the
predicted probability assigned to the possible outcomes for
an observation and the actual outcome. Lower the Brier score,
the better the predictions from the model are calibrated. The
calibration plots and the Brier scores were generated using a
test set of 463 observations (20% of the whole data) and the
remaining data were used to train the models (using features
from set A).
After investigating the distortion characteristic (or calibra-
tion) of each learning algorithm, calibration methods (e.g.
isotonic regression, Plattâ€™s scaling) are used to correct this
distortions [31], [32]. Isotonic regression in general is more
powerful calibrator than Plattâ€™s scaling as it can correct any
monotonic distortion and also unlike Plattâ€™s, isotonic regres-
sion is a non-parametric method. On the downside isotonic
regression is more prone to overï¬tting when the dataset is
small [28]. We report Brier scores of all the classiï¬ers, both
before and after the calibrations are performed.
The results from the experiments are discussed it details in
the next section.
IV . RESULTS AND DISCUSSION
We start this section by comparing the discriminative perfor-
mance of the different classiï¬er and feature set combinations.
Table III shows the mean and the standard deviation (in
brackets) of all the performance metrics that were described
in section III-E1, obtained from 5-fold cross validation for the
combinations. For every feature set, the algorithm with the
best average validation metric is highlighted with bold. When
the mean value is same for multiple algorithms (considering
up to 2 decimal places) preference is given to classiï¬ers with a
low standard deviation. The entire machine learning pipeline
was implemented in python using scikit-learn and the plots
were generated using matplotlib [33], [34].
A. Comparing the Feature sets
It can be observed from Table III that set A clearly outper-
forms the other feature sets both in terms of AUC, balanced
accuracy and recall. This clearly supports our claim of the
need for models encompassing more features. Set B without
incorporating any medicine intake information still manages to
outperform set C and set D. Set C which is reported as the best
performing feature set in [17], performs poorly compared to
the other feature sets, most noticeably sometimes even worse
than set D which only comprises of the 3 features that we
directly incorporate from the diagnostic criteria. Observing
the performance of set D it can be concluded that most of
the information already resides in these 3 variables. As they
directly contribute to the diagnostic deï¬nition this observation
is anticipated and self-explanatory. But comparing set D to
set A and set B it can also be concluded that by adding more
features to the model signiï¬cant performance gains can be
observed. It should be noted, the recall drops sharply as the
number of features are reduced.
The ROC curves for the different feature sets can also be
visualized in ï¬g. 1. The ROC curves in this case was generated
on a test dataset with 463 observations (20% of the whole data)
and the rest of the data were used to train the models with the
ensemble classiï¬er.
A comparison between our models and the rule-based
approach from Romero-SaldaËœna et al. was also performed [17].
The ï¬xed rule approach demonstrates', ' obtain their
MetS risk and undergo further diagnostic steps if necessary.
In recent years, machine learning has frequently been uti-
lized to predict and aid medical diagnosis. Machine learning
algorithms especially non linear classiï¬ers such as random
forests, gradient boosting trees have often exhibited better
performance in predicting clinical outcomes than traditional
approaches like logistic regression [9], [10]. But even with a
strong algorithm, the model can only be as good as the relevant
information in the training dataset. Selecting the set of relevant
features that fully describes all concepts in a given dataset
can be equally important as selecting the right algorithm. In
this paper we not only compare the different algorithms with
each other but also different feature subsets for predicting the
presence of MetS.
Additionally, we do recognize the need of providing a con-
tinuous risk score along with the diagnosis for MetS. There-
fore, we also investigate the probability estimates obtained
from the different classiï¬ers and test if they are well calibrated
in order to achieve the best individual risk predictions.
II. P REVIOUS WORK
For the purpose of early detection of MetS a lot of work
has been done to discover novel biomarkers of metabolic
risk such as leukocyte and its sub-types, serum bilirubin,
plasminogen activator inhibitor-1, adiponectin, resistin, C-
reactive protein [11]â€“[13]. Some work also exists in identify-
ing anthropological features such as body mass index (BMI),
waist circumference, waist-hip ratio, waist-height ratio etc.
[14], [15]. The discrepancy in the results reported in these
papers points to the need of predictive models that are more
robust and generalize better to unseen data.
Hsiung, Liu, Cheng and Ma proposed a novel method
to predict the presence of MetS using heart rate variability
(HRV) and some other non-invasive measures such as BMI,
body fat, waist circumference, neck circumference [16]. The
work shows that data collected from cardiac bio-signals such

The models are evaluated based on two main criteria, namely
the discriminative performance and the model calibration.
1) Discriminative Performance: The primary metric that
we use to judge the discriminative power of a model is
the Area Under the Curve (AUC) of the receiver operating
characteristic (ROC) curve. Models with ideal discrimination
power have an AUC of 1.0 and the ones with no discrimi-
natory ability have AUC equal 0.5. Along with AUC we also
report balanced accuracy (or average class accuracy), precision
(or positive predictive value) and recall (or true positive
rate). Balanced accuracy is calculated as the average of the
proportion of correct predictions for each class individually.
Balanced accuracy is chosen ahead of regular accuracy as it
provides a better overview of the model performance than the
classiï¬cation accuracy when the classes are not balanced [25].
Precision is the proportion of positive identiï¬cations by the
model that were actually correct. Recall is the proportion of
actual positives that were identiï¬ed correctly.
It should be noted, that AUC is the strongest indicator of the
model performance among all the discriminative performance
metrics that we report here. AUC is statistically consistent and
more discriminating than accuracy [26]. Balanced accuracy,
precision and recall are all dependent on the threshold we
choose to apply on the probability estimations of the class
prediction to get the class labels. Choosing an appropriate
decision threshold is highly dependent on the desired outcome
of the predictive model (high speciï¬city or high sensitivity).
Since our goal is to give a probability score for MetS, AUC
is more relevant for us. For computing balanced accuracy,
precision and recall, a decision threshold of 0.5 is assumed.
A 5-fold cross-validation was performed to get a more robust
estimate of the validation metrics. The hyper-parameters for
the different classiï¬ers were optimized empirically.
2) Model Calibration: Model calibration refers to the
agreement between subgroups of predicted probabilities and
their observed frequencies [27]. For predictive models in
medicine, usually the predicted probabilities of the different
class labels are important as they show how conï¬dent the
model is about the predictions. Models like LR are usually
well calibrated as it directly optimizes the log-loss. But many
other machine learning models like RF are thought to be
poorly calibrated [28]. There are different ways to check for
model calibration, calibration plot usually being the preferred
approach [27], [29]. To evaluate the calibration performance
we also report the Brier score for each classiï¬er [30]. Brier
score measures the mean squared difference between the
predicted probability assigned to the possible outcomes for
an observation and the actual outcome. Lower the Brier score,
the better the predictions from the model are calibrated. The
calibration plots and the Brier scores were generated using a
test set of 463 observations (20% of the whole data) and the
remaining data were used to train the models (using features
from set A).
After investigating the distortion characteristic (or calibra-
tion) of each learning', '-
tween the different feature sets. When comparing the AUCs,
we observe that the ensemble classiï¬er performs best on
average across all the feature sets. For the larger feature sets,
the more advanced machine learning methods perform better
than the logistic regression. For set D which is the smallest
feature set with only 3 features, almost all the algorithms
(with the exception of RF) shows similar performance. For
balanced accuracy, the ensemble classiï¬er outperforms all the
other algorithms on every feature set. In terms of recall, the
more advanced machine learning methods demonstrate a better
performance than logistic regression.
Looking at the standard deviation of all the validation
metrics reported here, we can also observe that the ensem-
ble method usually demonstrates a more stable performance
across the different cross validation folds. This supports the
notion that, because ensemble algorithms aggregate multiple
classiï¬ers it is often more generalizable and robust compared
to individual classiï¬er algorithms [35]. In a sense, the different
base algorithms compliment each other in an ensemble, which
often results in a better classiï¬cation performance.
The ROC curves for the different classiï¬ers can be visual-
ized in ï¬g. 2. The curves were generated using the same test
set as described above using the features from set A.
C. Model Calibration
To investigate the model calibration, we start with the
calibration plots for the classiï¬ers described in the section
III-D. Fig. 3 shows the calibration plots based on the predicted
probabilities that were directly obtained from the models.
The calibration performance is evaluated with Brier score,
reported in the legend of ï¬g. 3 and in table IV. The lower
the Brier score, the better calibrated the model is. Calibration
performance can also be evaluated by investigating the calibra-
tion/reliability plot (the upper half of the ï¬gure). If the model
is well calibrated the points will fall near the diagonal line.
The lower part of the plot shows histograms of the predicted
probabilities. From ï¬g. 3 we can see, as expected the logistic
regression returns a well calibrated model. Notably, contrary
to popular belief, RF produces the best calibrated model here.
The GBM and the ensemble classiï¬er display poor calibration
performance and exhibit an almost sigmoidal shape in the
calibration plots. Investigating the histogram in this ï¬gure it
can be observed that most of the predicted probabilities from
the GBM and the ensemble lies in central region with very
few probabilities reaching 0 or 1.
Fig. 4 shows the calibration plots and histograms of the clas-
siï¬ers after applying the isotonic regression [31]. The adjusted
Brier scores can be found in the legend of 4 and in table IV. It
can be immediately observed that the calibration performance
of GBM and the ensemble model improves signiï¬cantly. The
Brier scores of the calibrated GBM and ensemble models
are now comparable with the native LR and RF outputs
and in some cases even better (for GBMs). Inspecting the
histograms, it can be observed that the probabilities are much
better distributed across the whole spectrum when compared
to ï¬g. 3. Plattâ€™s scaling was also tested on the models and
the corresponding Brier scores can be found in table IV.
No signiï¬cant differences were observed when comparing the
Brier scores of the two different calibration techniques.

In recent years, machine learning has frequently been uti-
lized to predict and aid medical diagnosis. Machine learning
algorithms especially non linear classiï¬ers such as random
forests, gradient boosting trees have often exhibited better
performance in predicting clinical outcomes than traditional
approaches like logistic regression [9], [10]. But even with a
strong algorithm, the model can only be as good as the relevant
information in the training dataset. Selecting the set of relevant
features that fully describes all concepts in a given dataset
can be equally important as selecting the right algorithm. In
this paper we not only compare the different algorithms with
each other but also different feature subsets for predicting the
presence of MetS.
Additionally, we do recognize the need of providing a con-
tinuous risk score along with the diagnosis for MetS. There-
fore, we also investigate the probability estimates obtained
from the different classiï¬ers and test if they are well calibrated
in order to achieve the best individual risk predictions.
II. P REVIOUS WORK
For the purpose of early detection of MetS a lot of work
has been done to discover novel biomarkers of metabolic
risk such as leukocyte and its sub-types, serum bilirubin,
plasminogen activator inhibitor-1, adiponectin, resistin, C-
reactive protein [11]â€“[13]. Some work also exists in identify-
ing anthropological features such as body mass index (BMI),
waist circumference, waist-hip ratio, waist-height ratio etc.
[14], [15]. The discrepancy in the results reported in these
papers points to the need of predictive models that are more
robust and generalize better to unseen data.
Hsiung, Liu, Cheng and Ma proposed a novel method
to predict the presence of MetS using heart rate variability
(HRV) and some other non-invasive measures such as BMI,
body fat, waist circumference, neck circumference [16]. The
work shows that data collected from cardiac bio-signals such
as HRV can be predictive of the presence of MetS when
combined with some anthropological features. Although no
ï¬nal diagnostic accuracy metrics were reported in the paper,
the systolic blood pressure (SBP), BMI and the very low
frequency (VLF) sections of the HRV were found to be good
predictors of the condition. Nevertheless, the lack of HRV data
in current clinical practice makes it challenging to incorporate
it into system whose purpose is to ease the detection of MetS.
Romero-SaldaËœna et al. proposed a new method based on
only anthropometric variables for early detection of MetS for
a Spanish working population (trained on 636 subjects and
validated on 550 subjects) [17]. The features that were used
for the models were waist-height ratio, body mass index, blood
pressure and body fat percentage. Based on the outcome of
the model they proposed a decision tree based on waist-height
ratio (â‰¥ 0.55) and hypertension (blood pressure â‰¥ 128/85
mmHg) which achieved a sensitivity of 91.6% and a speciï¬city
of 95.7% on the validation cohort. In a later work the method
was validated with a larger cohort of Spanish workers (60799
subjects) where a sensitivity of 54.7% and a speciï¬city of
94.9% was observed [18]. A low sensitivity indicates that
proposed model incorrectly classiï¬ed a lot of MetS patients
as healthy. In the paper they also discover that cutoff for the
optimal waist-height ratio varies across gender and different
age groups. This indicates the need of a more sophisticated
model encompassing more features.

estimate of the validation metrics. The hyper-parameters for
the different classiï¬ers were optimized empirically.
2) Model Calibration: Model calibration refers to the
agreement between subgroups of predicted probabilities and
their observed frequencies [27]. For predictive models in
medicine, usually the predicted probabilities of the different
class labels are important as they show how conï¬dent the
model is about the predictions. Models like LR are usually
well calibrated as it directly optimizes the log-loss. But many
other machine learning models like RF are thought to be
poorly calibrated [28]. There are different ways to check for
model calibration, calibration plot usually being the preferred
approach [27], [29]. To evaluate the calibration performance
we also report the Brier score for each classiï¬er [30]. Brier
score measures the mean squared difference between the

an observation and the actual outcome. Lower the Brier score,
the better the predictions from the model are calibrated. The

from set A).
After investigating the distortion characteristic (or calibra-
tion) of each learning', 'olic blood pressure
(SBP), diastolic blood pressure (DBP), waist circumfer-
ence (WC), WtHR, BMI, BFP and all the medication
information from table II
2) Set B: All in set A except the medication information
3) Set C [17]: WtHR, BFP, BMI, DBP
4) Set D: WC, SBP, DBP
The difference between set A and set B is only that set
A contains the medication information which set B does not.
Since the medication information plays a role in the MetS
diagnostic criteria as well we wanted to test the models with
and without it. More importantly, since we want our models
to be operable on a wide variety of cohorts and we do
recognize that reliable medication information can be difï¬cult
to obtain in some scenarios (e.g. electronic health records), it is
necessary to have a model without medications. Set C is the
best performing feature set as reported by Romero-Salda Ëœna
et al. [17]. Set D includes the anthropometric features that
we directly take from the diagnostic criteria of MetS. It is
important to note that unlike some previous work, we avoid
dichotomising any continuous feature variables. The most
noteworthy drawback of dichotomising continuous features is
that individuals close to but on opposite sides of the cutoff
are often characterized as being dissimilar rather than very
similar [21]. Although, since we use the currently established
dichotomous deï¬nition of MetS as the target variable, it
is possible that our models implicitly learn the thresholds,
specially for the features that were directly taken from the
diagnostic criteria.
D. Classiï¬cation Methods
Here we brieï¬‚y describe the classiï¬cation algorithms we
evaluated in this work.
1) Logistic Regression (LR): LR works similar to linear
regression, but with a binomial response variable. To avoid
overï¬tting we use L2 regularization (also known as ridge
regression).
2) Random F orest (RF):RF is an ensemble of randomly
constructed independent decision trees [22]. It usually exhibits
considerable performance improvements over single-tree clas-
siï¬er algorithms such as CART [23].
3) Gradient Boosting Machines (GBMs):In GBMs the al-
gorithm consecutively ï¬ts new models (in this case regression
trees) to provide a more accurate estimate of the target variable
[24]. Gradient boosting trains many models in an additive
and sequential manner. Gradient boosting of regression trees
usually produce highly robust and interpretable procedures for
classiï¬cation, even in situations when the training data are not
so clean [24].
4) Ensemble Classiï¬er: Finally we also built an ensemble
classiï¬er by combining the outputs from the three methods
mentioned above (LR, RF and GBM). Instead of the more
popular hard voting approach which selects the target label
which was predicted by the majority of the classiï¬ers, here we
use a soft voting ensemble technique which takes an average
of output probabilities of the base classiï¬ers and based on
the average value it decides on the target label. The primary
difference between the two approaches is that soft voting also
takes into account how certain each classiï¬er is about the
prediction.
E. Evaluation
The experiment was designed to compare each feature set
and classiï¬cation algorithm combination against each other.

IV . RESULTS AND DISCUSSION
We start this section by comparing the discriminative perfor-
mance of the different classiï¬er and feature set combinations.
Table III shows the mean and the standard deviation (in
brackets) of all the performance metrics that were described
in section III-E1, obtained from 5-fold cross validation for the
combinations. For every feature set, the algorithm with the
best average validation metric is highlighted with bold. When
the mean value is same for multiple algorithms (considering
up to 2 decimal places) preference is given to classiï¬ers with a
low standard deviation. The entire machine learning pipeline
was implemented in python using scikit-learn and the plots
were generated using matplotlib [33], [34].
A. Comparing the Feature sets
It can be observed from Table III that set A clearly outper-
forms the other feature sets both in terms of AUC, balanced
accuracy and recall. This clearly supports our claim of the
need for models encompassing more features. Set B without
incorporating any medicine intake information still manages to
outperform set C and set D. Set C which is reported as the best
performing feature set in [17], performs poorly compared to
the other feature sets, most noticeably sometimes even worse
than set D which only comprises of the 3 features that we
directly incorporate from the diagnostic criteria. Observing
the performance of set D it can be concluded that most of
the information already resides in these 3 variables. As they
directly contribute to the diagnostic deï¬nition this observation
is anticipated and self-explanatory. But comparing set D to
set A and set B it can also be concluded that by adding more
features to the model signiï¬cant performance gains can be
observed. It should be noted, the recall drops sharply as the
number of features are reduced.
The ROC curves for the different feature sets can also be
visualized in ï¬g. 1. The ROC curves in this case was generated
on a test dataset with 463 observations (20% of the whole data)
and the rest of the data were used to train the models with the
ensemble classiï¬er.

approach from Romero-SaldaËœna et al. was also performed [17].

the Brier score, the better calibrated the model is. Calibration
performance can also be evaluated by investigating the calibra-
tion/reliability plot (the upper half of the ï¬gure). If the model
is well calibrated the points will fall near the diagonal line.
The lower part of the plot shows histograms of the predicted
probabilities. From ï¬g. 3 we can see, as expected the logistic
regression returns a well calibrated model. Notably, contrary
to popular belief, RF produces the best calibrated model here.
The GBM and the ensemble classiï¬er display poor calibration
performance and exhibit an almost sigmoidal shape in the
calibration plots. Investigating the histogram in this ï¬gure it
can be observed that most of the predicted probabilities from
the GBM and the ensemble lies in central region with very
few probabilities reaching 0 or 1.
Fig. 4 shows the calibration plots and histograms of the clas-
siï¬ers after applying the isotonic regression [31]. The adjusted
Brier scores can be found in the legend of 4 and in table IV. It
can be immediately observed that the calibration performance
of GBM and the ensemble model improves signiï¬cantly. The
Brier scores of the calibrated GBM and ensemble models
are now comparable with the native LR and RF outputs
and in some cases even better (for GBMs). Inspecting the
histograms, it can be observed that the probabilities are much
better distributed across the whole spectrum when compared
to ï¬g. 3. Plattâ€™s scaling was also tested on the models and
the corresponding Brier scores can be found in table IV.
No signiï¬cant differences were observed when comparing the
Brier scores of the two different calibration techniques.
