correlation-based ï¬lter [10], and sequential forward selection
(wrapper) [11] methods. By comparing the classiï¬cation rate of
identifying ï¬ve daily activities carrying a smartphone on ï¬ve
body positions, Khanet al.[12] proved that Kernel discriminant
analysis is better than linear discriminant analysis and signal
magnitude area. Shoaibet al. [13] demonstrated putting three
types of sensors (i.e., accelerometer, gyroscope, and linear ac-
celerometer) on the wrist and pocket to identify less-repetitive
activities, such as smoking, eating, and drinking coffee. For
solving the problem of online time series segmentation, Ignatov
et al. [14] constructed the phase trajectory matrix and applied
the PCA technique to extract features of the ï¬rst period. Sousa
et al.[15] investigated the classiï¬cation capability with different
feature sets, such as time-domain (mathematical and statis-
tical parameters), frequency-domain (wavelet transform), and
discrete-domain (symbolic representations). Although the above
works achieved signiï¬cant progress for HAR, the limitations
still existed. Most of them ignored the affection of shift changes
in position and orientation of the smartphone due to motion
artifacts.
During the past decades, many researchers have explored
various ML and DL algorithms to identify more complex ac-
tivities with higher recognition rates. Koseet al.[1] proved that
k-nearest neighbor (k-NN) could obtain a higher classiï¬cation
accuracy than NaÂ¨ive Bayes (NB) by recognizing four kinds
of activities, i.e., walking, running, sitting, and standing. Lee
and Cho [16] designed a mixture-of-experts model for dealing
with uncertain and incomplete data. Reyes-Ortiz et al. [17]
proposed a transition-aware HAR system based on the support
vector machine (SVM) algorithm to classify a broad spectrum
(up to 33 types) of activity with smartphone in real-time. Lee
and Cho [18] presented a hierarchical hidden Markov model
(HHMM) method to classify motions (standing, walking, go
stairs, and running) and daily activities (shopping, taking a
bus, and moving arms). A two-stage continuous hidden Markov
model (HMM) algorithm was proposed to reduce the number of
feature subsets because it decomposed the complex activities
into several simpler ones [19]. Reiss et al. [20] found that
the ConfAdaBoost.M1 ensemble algorithm could obtain a high
recognition accuracy, but it was necessary to extract 561 features.
Noor et al.[21] introduced an adaptive sliding window approach
to recognize physical activity by computing the probability of
signals with an adjustable window length. All of the above
contributions were limited by the length of the detected signal
segments. Some of them focused on a short segment, which
cannot express a whole activity. Some of them detected on the
long signal segment, which affected misclassiï¬cation due to a
segment including many activities. Hence, it is essential to ï¬nd a
suitable data length for classiï¬cation. However, the performance
of ML-based solutions', ' (LSTM) HC classiï¬ers. Meanwhile,
all of the HC classiï¬ers are evaluated on uncompressed and no-
compressed datasets. Although the LSTM-based HC classiï¬er
obtains the highest accuracy, it is time-consuming for building
the model. Due to the SVM-based HC algorithm adopting the
linear kernel function, it takes more time to search the optimal
solution. In the same case, the k-NN-based approach is the
fastest method to establish the HC classiï¬er, while the DT-based
classiï¬er is the fastest algorithm to predict the activity. Moreover,
the testing accuracy displays that putting the smartphone in the
pocket acquires more noises than carrying the smartphone on
the waist. The results for the average testing time and training
time computed on the compressed dataset are signiï¬cantly less
than those for the uncompressed dataset. Hence, compressing the
training datasets saves more time for building a new classiï¬er.
Even if the accuracy obtained on the uncompressed dataset is
greater than that on the compressed dataset, it is time-consuming
to build the classiï¬er and predict an activity. Moreover, the trust
degree Î· can be adjusted to increase the accuracy using (7).
B. Online Learning Examination
This experiment aims to prove the updating ability of Ada-
HAR system for recognizing a new activity. Two new activities
(squats and twisting hips) were collected from one subject
carrying the smartphone on the waist or put in the left pocket,
respectively. To conï¬rm that the proposed signal processing al-
gorithms could overcome the effect of changing the direction of
mobile phone, we combined the collected data of two directions
with the same testing protocol (shown in each top graph of
Fig. 6). The DL-based HC algorithm was not adopted because
the training procedure is costly. The experiments adopted an
online batch learning mechanism. The SVM method used the
Gaussian kernel. The built ML-based classiï¬ers for identifying
the 12 original activities were used to predict the new activity
on the four datasets. The following four experiments were per-
formed to evaluate the adaptive performance of both compressed
and uncompressed datasets.

Both k-NN and SVM methods obtain a higher accuracy than the
other methods. The bottom graph is the online predicting time.

accuracy for identifying squats, andk-NN spends less time to
retrain the classiï¬er. Fig. 6(c) and (d) shows the validation

['414 IEEE TRANSACTIONS ON HUMAN-MACHINE SYSTEMS, VOL. 50, NO. 5, OCTOBER 2020
A Smartphone-Based Adaptive Recognition and
Real-Time Monitoring System for Human Activities
Wen Qi , Student Member , IEEE,H a n gS u, Member , IEEE, and Andrea Aliverti
Abstractâ€”Human activity recognition (HAR) using smart-
phones provides signiï¬cant healthcare guidance for telemedicine
and long-term treatment. Machine learning and deep learning
(DL) techniques are widely utilized for the scientiï¬c study of the
statistical models of human behaviors. However, the performance
of existing HAR platforms is limited by complex physical activity.
In this article, we proposed an adaptive recognition and real-time
monitoring system for human activities (Ada-HAR), which is ex-
pected to identify more human motions in dynamic situations. The
Ada-HAR framework introduces an unsupervised online learning
algorithm that is independent of the number of class constraints.
Furthermore, the adopted hierarchical clustering and classiï¬ca-
tion algorithms label and classify 12 activities (ï¬ve dynamics, six
statics, and a series of transitions) autonomously. Finally, practical
experiments have been performed to validate the effectiveness and
robustness of the proposed algorithms. Compared with the methods
mentioned in the literature, the results show that the DL-based
classiï¬er obtains a higher recognition rate (95.15%, waist, and
92.20%, pocket). The decision-tree-based classiï¬er is the fastest
method for modal evolution. Finally, the Ada-HAR system can
monitor human activity in real time, regardless of the direction
of the smartphone.
Index Terms â€”Data compression, deep learning (DL),
hierarchical classiï¬cation (HC), human activity recognition
(HAR).
I. INTRODUCTION
R
ECOGNIZING human activities using inertial sensors in
a smartphone has attracted increasing research interests
during the past decades in various domains, ranging from home
healthcare to sports monitoring, rehabilitation, personalized
medicine, and mental disorders [1]. Recently, with the develop-
ment of the Internet of Things, machine learning (ML), and deep
learning (DL) techniques, human activity recognition (HAR)
can be achieved by transferring data in the body area networks
and wireless Ethernet, allowing the assessment of the human
physical and physiological status [2]. However, many studies
develop appropriate tasks for a given HAR system by resorting
to extensive heuristic knowledge [3]. They are applicable in a
laboratory or well-controlled situation via body-ï¬xed mobile

results prove that the compressed training dataset can save the

C. Demonstration
The video experiment of Ada-HAR demonstrates the recog-
nition process in real time by changing the direction of the
smartphone with two positions. The mean transmission time
of local network is shorter than that of remote connection. For
example, it only cost 0.18 s to receive ten new samples in the
local network, while it needed 0.25 s for the remote transmission.
Each result was obtained as the average of 100 repetitions.
VI. CONCLUSION
In this article, we proposed a smartphone-based adaptive
recognition and real-time monitoring system (Ada-HAR) for
human activities. Experiments were performed with 25 subjects
to validate the performance of the developed system. The most
innovative part was the online learning algorithm. It was capable
of updating the classiï¬er in a dynamic environment, i.e., which
means if any new activity is found, the HC classiï¬er will be
updated automatically to include the new class. It is an unsu-
pervised online learning algorithm that does not need to get the
true labels. In addition to the adaptive algorithm, an automatic
labeling method using Hk-mC algorithm was another original
achievement that improves the efï¬ciency of labeling the raw
signals. The experiments proved its robustness by placing the
smartphone on different positions with various directions. The
introduced signal preprocessing strategy provides stable inputs
for the classiï¬er regardless of the', ' principal component analysis (PCA) [9], fast

V. EXPERIMENTS AND RESULTS
Three experiments were designed to validate the claims about
the Ada-HAR system in Section I. The ï¬rst experiment of the HC
algorithm evaluation aimed to compare the performance among
ML-based and DL-based HC classiï¬ers. The second experiment
was to validate the evolution ability of the Ada-HAR system.
The demonstration revealed the identiï¬cation capability of Ada-
HAR system in real time. The experiments have implemented
these methods in MATLAB 2018b with the hardware platform of
Intel(R) i7 Core, 2.80-GHz CPU, and 16.0-GB RAM. A 64-bit
iPhone 6 s (2-core CPU) was utilized for collecting data with a
50-Hz sampling frequency.
A. HC Algorithm Evaluation
Twenty-ï¬ve subjects (13 females and 12 males, age range
18â€“40 years old) were asked to perform the 12 original activities
described in Section I in a ï¬xed order (shown in Fig. 4). They
carried the smartphone on the waist or put it in their left pant
pocket, respectively. Finally, 50 datasets (25 datasets for each
position) were collected for further analysis.
We adopt the leave-one-out cross-validation strategy to vali-
date the performance of HC classiï¬ers [40]. The length of the
detection window is 150 samples (3 s), and the overlap is 1 s
(50 estimates). Table III reports a comparison of the average and
standard deviation in terms of the accuracy, training time, and
average test time among ML-based (i.e.,k-NN, DT, NB, ANN,
and SVM) and DL-based (LSTM) HC classiï¬ers. Meanwhile,
all of the HC classiï¬ers are evaluated on uncompressed and no-
compressed datasets. Although the LSTM-based HC classiï¬er
obtains the highest accuracy, it is time-consuming for building
the model. Due to the SVM-based HC algorithm adopting the
linear kernel function, it takes more time to search the optimal
solution. In the same case, the k-NN-based approach is the
fastest method to establish the HC classiï¬er, while the DT-based
classiï¬er is the fastest algorithm to predict the activity. Moreover,
the testing accuracy displays that putting the smartphone in the
pocket acquires more noises than carrying the smartphone on
the waist. The results for the', 'Ld +Lo)=1 ,

For accuracy enhancement, the SVM model commonly utilizes
the radial basis function kernel and linear kernel commonly.
As a standard RNN method, the LSTM algorithm learns the
long-term dependencies based on the three gates, namely an
input gate, a forget gate to allow the LSTM unit to unlearn the
previous memory, and an output gate to decide the quantity of
memory transferring to the next hidden layers. However, it will
cost ample time to optimize the parameters of the LSTM network
and predict a result.

IV . METHODOLOGY
Fig. 2 shows the proposed Ada-HAR system with cre-
ation, recognition, and online learning modules. In the creation
module, the Hk-mC [6] is adopted to label the activities au-
tonomously. The HC [7] algorithms are used to establish the
classiï¬er for recognizing the 12 original activities (described in
Section I). In the recognition module, the obtained HC classiï¬er
is implemented for HAR in real time by carrying a smartphone
on the waist or putting it in the left pant pocket. In the online
learning module, a new activity that is not included in the 12
original activities will be identiï¬ed in an unsupervised learning
manner. Meanwhile, the old classiï¬er is updated. The signal
preprocessing and feature extraction models are shared in both
creation and recognition modules.
A. Signal Preprocessing and Feature Extraction
The collected signals typically exhibit various turbulence
(e.g., magnetic ï¬elds and movement artifact), which affects the
recognition ability of the classiï¬er. The derived sensors signals
(e.g., gravity and linear acceleration) that are transferred by the

networkorequipmentduringtelecommunication.

The recording of the speakersâ€™ speech was strictly con-
trolled by a standard operating procedure (SOP). The SOP
was established to capture the natural characteristics of the

sentence was recorded twice, and the value of each feature
was obtained by averaging the values of the 2 recordings for
morestablefeatures.
All features were extracted using 5 vowels (A, E, I,
O, U) and 1 sentence [38]. For speech feature extraction,
we extracted 65 features from the collected data set. The
extracted features consisted of pitch, average ratio of pitch

Also, BMI values differ according to physiological factors
and environmental factors, such as residing in a city or a
rural area. For instance, BMI values of a population in an
Asian region tend to be lower than those of a population
in a Western region, whereas Asians have risk factors for
cardiovascular disease and diabetes related to obesity at
relatively low BMI values [9, 39]. The BMI cutoff values for
overweight and obesity depend on several factors including
ethnicity,rural/urbanresidence,andeconomicstatus[ 7,40].
Therefore, we decided that this studyâ€™s overweight cutoff
point of BMI value wasâ‰¥23kg/m
2, according to suggestions
by the World Health Organization and references [39, 41,
42]. We refer here to only 2 classes: the â€œnormalâ€ and the
â€œoverweight.â€ Subjects in the BMI who range from 18.5 to
22.9 were labeled normal, and subjects with a BMI of 23
or over were labeled as overweight. Underweight patients
were passed over due the lack of a minimum number of
subjects. Finally, we divided the data set into 6 groups for

Obesity is a serious public health problem because of the risk factors for diseases and psychological problems. The focus of this
studyistodiagnosethepatientBMI(bodymassindex)statuswithoutweightandheightmeasurementsfortheuseinfutureclinical
applications.Inthispaper,wefirstproposeamethodforclassifyingthenormalandtheoverweightusingonlyspeechsignals.Also,
weperformastatisticalanalysisofthefeaturesfromspeechsig nals.Basedon1830subjects,theaccuracyandAUC(areaunderthe
ROCcurve)ofage-andgender-specificclassificationsrangedfrom60.4to73.8%andfrom0.628to0.738,respectively.Weidentified
severalfeaturesthatweresignificantlydifferentbetweennormalandoverweight subjects( ğ‘ƒ<0.05). Also,we foundcompact and
discriminatoryfeaturesubsetsforbuildingmodelsfordiagnosing normaloroverweightindividualsthroughwrapper-basedfeature
subset selection. Our results showed that predicting BMI status is possible using a combination of speech features, even though
significantfeaturesarerareandweakinage-andgender-specificgroupsandthattheclassificationaccuracywithfeatureselection
was higher than that without feature selection. Our method has the potential to be used in future clinical applications such as
automaticBMIdiagnosisintelemedicineorremotehealthcare.
1. Introduction
Worldwide, increasing numbers of people are becoming
obese, including adults, adolescents, and children and both
menandwoman[ 1,2].Obesityreferstoexcessadiposetissue
causedbygeneticdeterminants,excessiveeating,insufficient
physical movement, and an inappropriate lifestyle [1, 3, 4].
Obesity and being overweight are serious public health
problems; obesity has a direct relationship with physical
health and psychological health and is a potential risk
factor for many diseases, including cardiovascular diseases,
stroke, ischemic heart disease, diabetes, and cancer [2, 5â€“
8]. Therefore, it is important to recognize when patients are
overweightorobese,andmanystudieshavebeenperformed
about the relationship of obesity, as determined by body
massindex(BMI),anddisease[ 4,6,7,9â€“11].BMI,proposed
by Lambert Adolphe Jacques Quetelet, is a measurement
criterion presenting the relationship between body weight
and height [3]a n dac o m m o n l yu s e dp u b l i ch e a l t hm e t h o d
for classifying underweight, normal, overweight, and obese
patients.
On the other hand, research on the association of body
shape (weight, height),']

featuresinwrapper-basedfeaturesubsetselectionandclassi-
ficationproblems.Fromtheperspectiveofmachinelearning
anddatamining,machinelearningforwrapper-basedfeature
selectionisconsideredaperfectblackbox.Ingeneral,greater
numbers of features exhibiting significant differences lead to
better machine-learning performance. However, we cannot
guarantee that a classification using only significant features
(i.e., those withP values <0.05) always performs better than
one using a combination of significant and less significant
features.Therefore,themostimportantfactoristheselection
and combination of the features of each group. For example,
GuyonandElisseeff[ 43]suggestthattheperformanceofvari-
ables that are ineffective by themselves can be improved sig-
nificantly when combined with others. Furthermore, adding
presumablyredundantvariablescanresultinnoisereduction
and consequently better class separation. The other possible
reasonfortheobservedproblemisthelackofsamples,which
canforceunder-oroverfittinginmachinelearning.Thesmall
sample size is a critical limitation of this study, because our
sample size was not representative of the population. Thus,
thisstudyshouldbedesignatedasapilotobservationalstudy.
In order to reduce or understand this problem, we require
moresamplesandarecurrentlycollectingmoresamples.
In the future, we will investigate the extraction of useful
features that demonstrate statistical significance in all age-
and gender-specific groups, build a more accurate classifi-
cation model, and collect more data for better classification
performance. Furthermore, we will examine the association
of the BMI with features such as respiration rate from
nonstructuredspeechsignalsusinganewprotocol.
4. Conclusions
The classification of normal and overweight according to
body mass index (BMI) is only possible through the mea-
surement and calculation of weight and height. This study
suggested a novel method for BMI classification by speech
signalandshowedthepossibilityofpredictingadiagnosisof
normal status or overweight status on the basis of voice and
machine learning. We found discriminatory feature subsets
f o rd i a g n o s i n gn o r m a lo ro v e r w e i g h ti n d i v i d u a l sb yf e a t u r e
selection. We proved that several features have a statistically
significantdifferencebetweennormalandoverweightclasses
in the female: 20â€“30 group and male: 20â€“30 group through
statisticalanalysisofthefeaturesselectedbyfeatureselection
ineachgroup.Ourfindingsshowedthepossibilitytopredict
BMIdiagnosisusingacombinationofvoicefeatureswithout
additional weight and height measurements, even if signifi-
cant features are rare and weak. The prediction performance
with feature selection was higher than that without feature
selection. However, the accuracy and AUC achieved by our
classification experiment were not yet sufficient for rigorous
diagnosis and medical purposes. Therefore, we need more
research about discriminatory features of broad range, rich
data,andamoreaccurateclassificationmodel.

is a threshold-independent measure, AUC is a widely used
toquantifythequalityofapredictionorclassificationmodel
in medical science, bioinformatics, medicine statistics, and
biology [31, 51â€“53]. An AUC of 1 means a perfect diagnosis
model,anAUCof0.5israndomdiagnosis,andanAUCof0
isaperfectlywrongdiagnosis.

sion [30, 45] with genetic search was used to maximize the
area under ROC curve (AUC). The selected features in each
groupareshownin Table 3.Allexperimentswereperformed
using logistic regression in Weka [46], and a 10-fold cross

positiverate(sensitivity,TPR),falsepositiverate(1specificity,
FPR), precision, and F measure as performance evaluation
criteria [47, 48]. A large proportion of classification algo-
rithms may not solve the class-size imbalance problem [49].
Thus, the accuracy of many classification experiments is
higherforamajorityclassthanforaminorityclass.Therefore,
we also evaluated performance using AUC. An ROC curve
(receiver operating characteristic curve) represents the bal-
ance of sensitivity versus 1 specificity [50]. Because the AUC
is a threshold-independent measure, AUC is a widely used
toquantifythequalityofapredictionorclassificationmodel
in medical science, bioinformatics, medicine statistics, and
biology [31, 51â€“53]. An AUC of 1 means a perfect diagnosis
model,anAUCof0.5israndomdiagnosis,andanAUCof0
isaperfectlywrongdiagnosis.

featuresinwrapper-basedfeaturesubsetselectionandclassi-
ficationproblems.Fromtheperspectiveofmachinelearning
anddatamining,machinelearningforwrapper-basedfeature
selectionisconsideredaperfectblackbox.Ingeneral,greater
numbers of features exhibiting significant differences lead to
better machine-learning performance. However, we cannot
guarantee that a classification using only significant features
(i.e., those withP values <0.05) always performs better than
one using a combination of significant and less significant
features.Therefore,themostimportantfactoristheselection
and combination of the features of each group. For example,
GuyonandElisseeff[ 43]suggestthattheperformanceofvari-
ables that are ineffective by themselves can be improved sig-
nificantly when combined with others. Furthermore, adding
presumablyredundantvariablescanresultinnoisereduction
and consequently better class separation. The other possible
reasonfortheobservedproblemisthelackofsamples,which
canforceunder-oroverfittinginmachinelearning.Thesmall
sample size is a critical limitation of this study, because our
sample size was not representative of the population. Thus,
thisstudyshouldbedesignatedasapilotobservationalstudy.
In order to reduce or understand this problem, we require
moresamplesandarecurrentlycollectingmoresamples.
In the future, we will investigate the extraction of useful
features that demonstrate statistical significance in all age-
and gender-specific groups, build a more accurate classifi-
cation model, and collect more data for better classification
performance. Furthermore, we will examine the association
of the BMI with features such as respiration rate from
nonstructuredspeechsignalsusinganewprotocol.
4. Conclusions
The classification of normal and overweight according to
body mass index (BMI) is only possible through the mea-
surement and calculation of weight and height. This study
suggested a novel method for BMI classification by speech
signalandshowedthepossibilityofpredictingadiagnosisof
normal status or overweight status on the basis of voice and
machine learning. We found discriminatory feature subsets
f o rd i a g n o s i n gn o r m a lo ro v e r w e i g h ti n d i v i d u a l sb yf e a t u r e
selection. We proved that several features have a statistically
significantdifferencebetweennormalandoverweightclasses
in the female: 20â€“30 group and male: 20â€“30 group through
statisticalanalysisofthefeaturesselectedbyfeatureselection
ineachgroup.Ourfindingsshowedthepossibilitytopredict
BMIdiagnosisusingacombinationofvoicefeatureswithout
additional weight and height measurements, even if signifi-
cant features are rare and weak. The prediction performance
with feature selection was higher than that without feature
selection. However, the accuracy and AUC achieved by our
classification experiment were not yet sufficient for rigorous
diagnosis and medical purposes. Therefore, we need more
research about discriminatory features of broad range, rich
data,andamoreaccurateclassificationmodel.

question: Is the aim of this study to predict future events (prognostic) or current disease status (diagnostic)?

T ABLE I
DISTRIBUTION OF DENT AL DISEASE TYPES
Fig. 6. Dental images enhancement comparison chart.
algorithm by this design [18], which is applied to ï¬nd the
image area blocks close to the sample image.
3) Artiï¬cial Screening Determines the Sample Library: For
the image areas after coarse location and classication, the anno-
tation information of each frame of data needs to be manually
conï¬rmed by dental disease experts. Labelme tool is used to gen-
erate mask data set, along with description of the segmentation
region of dental disease as accurate as possible with multiple key
points. We delete the wrong label positions and ï¬x the wrong
tags through articial selection, along with the possible adding of
the undetected target images. The nished data is applied as the
training sample data for the detection and classication of dental
diseases, ending up with the summary of the recorded frame
images to establish the dental training sample set.
C. Model Training
Common target detection algorithms including RCNN,
YOLO, SSD [19] only classify the target in the image. However,
the accurate target segmentation is benecial to the auxiliary med-
ical diagnosis, to achieve the aim of fast and accurate detection
of dental diseases and dental area accurate segmentation. Based
on the established dental sample library, the MASK R-CNN
method is chosen for the accurate detection and segmentation
of the dental target.
The designed MASK R-CNN network is shown in the left
of Fig. 6 , in which, MASK R-CNN adds a branch predicting
the segmentation mask in each interested area based on Faster
R-CNN [20]. In Faster R-CNN, region of interest (RoI) pool
is used to extract the small features from each RoI. Firstly,
RoIPool scales the RoI represented by oating point numbers to
Fig. 7. Left: MASK R-CNN network. Right: example detections using
MASK R-CNN on dental images test.
the granularity matching the feature graph, followed by parti-
tioning of the scaled ROI, ending up with the summary of the
characteristic value of each block coverage area. Such calcula-
tions misplace the ROI and the extracted features, which, though
possibly not affecting the classication, for the classication has
the certain robustness to the small amplitude transformation,
exerts a great negative impact on the prediction of the precise
mask of pixel level. Mask R-CNN proposes the RoI Align layer
to remove the dislocation of RoIPool and aligns the extracted
features with the input accurately. In RoI Align, a bilinear in-
terpolation is used to calculate the exact value of each position,
along with the summary of the results by using the maximum
or average pooling, and the extracted features and input can be
aligned with the pixel to pixel, thereby improving the segmen-
tation accuracy effectively. For the lower convolution network
used for feature extraction on the whole image, the ResNet-50-
C4 backbone [20], [21] is adopted with the depth of 50 layers,
and extract features from the nal convolution layer of the fourth
stage in the MASK R-CNN. For the upper network, we extend
the Faster R-CNN upper network proposed in ResNet, adding a
mask branch respectively. TensorFlow and Mask R-CNN open
source are adopted in the training model, along with modiï¬ca-
tion of ShapesCong class, and GPU COUNT and IMAGES PER
GPU are set to 1 according to the training server conguration.
At the same time, according to the training sample library, cate-
gories NUM CLASSES, image size IMAGE MIN DIM and the
size of the anchor RPN AN', 'iï¬cant impact on the anal-
ysis of artiï¬cial intelligence. Therefore, the future work will
give more priority to the improvement of the hardware design
and the efï¬ciency of image acquisition device, and further work
will focus on improving algorithm efï¬ciency and recognition
rate, reducing false alarm rate, and setting up a larger image
data set for dental diseases.
V. C ONCLUSION
This paper proposes an iHome smart dental Health-IoT sys-
tem based on intelligent hardware, deep learning and mobile
terminal, aiming to regulate as well as optimize the accessibil-
ity of dental treatment and provide home-based dental health
care service more efciently. The trained model was used to
realize the detection and classication of dental diseases, and
application software (Apps) on mobile terminal was designed
for client-side and dentist-side. The software platform with the
functions including pre-examination of dental disease, consulta-
tion, appointment, and evaluation, etc, made the service docking
between the patient and the dentist resources a reality. The AI
algorithm achieved more than 90% recognition rate for seven
dental diseases., which has greatly improved the patient rate and
the resource utilization rate of the dental clinic through a one-
month systematic testing in 10 private dental clinics, showing
high reliability in practical application.

r Second, the cost of dental treatment is relatively high.
r Third, dental disease, due to the characteristics of elective
treatment, is difï¬cult to get timely treatment.
Based on what is discussed above, a promising trend in health-
care is to move routine medical checks and other healthcare ser-
vices from hospital (Hospital-Centric) to the home environment
(Home-centric) [15], through which, the patients can get seam-
less health care at any time in a comfortable home environment.
Even more, it can ensure that the overall iHome dental health-
care system including three partspersonalized services, dental
services and intelligent and interactive service could be opti-
mized to a large extent. Based on this platform, the closed-loop
system of pre-screening, consultation, appointment, treatment
and evaluation of dental disease is established, thereby mak-
Fig. 1. The network architecture of the iHome dental health-IoT
system.
ing the rapid and effective relationship between patients and
doctorsâ€™ resources a reality.
A. The Architecture of iHome DentalHealth-IoT System
The network architecture of the iHome dental health-IoT sys-
tem is shown in Fig. 1 , which consists of three network layers:
1) dental medical service layer; 2) smart dental service layer; 3)
dental image data acquisition layer.
The dental medical service layer is directly connected to pro-
fessional medical facilities such as hospital, dental clinic, regis-
tered dentist and dental healthcare product supplier.
The dental clinics or hospitals equipped with certain quali-
ï¬cations and idle resources can attract customers through their
own medical technology and price advantage, thereby making
it possible for them to make an early judgment with the help
of self-help screening results, and to make a new e-prescription
accordingly or treatment programs based on that. Additionally,
based on the platform, the doctors can not only manage their
patients, interact with patients and track the effectiveness of
treatment effectively, but also identify the patient group whose
health conditions have improved easily, and inform them of their
progress, thereby facilitating the building of positive loops of
rehabilitation and self-care. The dentists can further improve
service quality and efï¬ciency through patient evaluations.
The smart dental service layer is the core layer where data
processing provides the analysis results of dental symptoms or
aesthetic needs, which also serves as an efï¬cient way to meet
usersâ€™ daily needs in dental health monitoring. This layer has
the following three functions:
r Intelligent diagnosis and treatment recommendation: It
can recommend the nearby excellent doctor for those

900 IEEE JOURNAL OF BIOMEDICAL AND HEALTH INFORMATICS, VOL. 24, NO. 3, MARCH 2020
Fig. 2. Application software system diagram.
consumers after the AI diagnose, and prompt them to seek
for low-price as well as time-saving medical treatment.
r Group purchase (E-MALL) service: It can classify the cus-
tomer needs as well as suitable product services and pro-
mote different group purchase & product services based
on AI diagnosis results.
r Large data customization service: It can classify the cus-
tomer needs and provide the customized or personalized
products as well as the services according to AI diagnosis
results.
Mainly consisting of dental image data acquisition devices
and the mobile terminal, local computing, and processing units,
wireless transmitting modules and display terminal, the dental
image data acquisition layer serves as the basis of the entire
platform. The dental image data is uploaded to the smart dental
service layer via the network (Wi-Fi, 3']

Due to the lack of dental diseases standard data sets, we
worked with some dental clinics (such as Beijing Mei-Xiao
dental clinics). With the consent of the subjects, 300 subjects
use dental image acquisition device to sample the dental diseases
video data, and the algorithm analyzes each frame of video, and
3835 images of dental cases are sampled ï¬nally. These clinics
already have 8,765 images of dental cases, with a total of 12,600
clinical images being collected. These images are classiï¬ed into
7 different types as shown in Table I, with the 7 types of dental
diseases as follows: dental caries, dental uorosis, periodontal
disease, cracked tooth, dental calculus, dental plaque, and tooth
loss. 4/5 of these data was used in training, while 1/5 of them was
in model testing, training data set and test data are respectively
from different objects, thus without overlap between the testing
dataset and the training dataset.
B. Build Sample Set
The semi-automatic labeling method is applied to establish
the training sample set to improve the efï¬ciency. The dental im-
ages were initially labeled by the design of detector for 7 types
of dental diseases, as shown in Fig. 5 , the functions of the de-
tector here include image enhancement, color texture matching,
coarse localization and classiï¬cation of disease. Followed by
the conï¬rmation of images with labeling error or classiï¬cation
error through manual screening method, the training samples
set were ï¬nally calibrated by 20 dental disease experts, with the
details as follows:
1) Image Enhancement: In some dental images, the features
of the tooth disease site without very high contrast are not very
obvious, thereby making it necessary to enhance the images
before designing the classiï¬cation algorithms. The Retinex al-
gorithm is used [17], which adaptively prompts various types
of images to achieve balance in dynamic range, edge, and color.
The image enhancement effect in Fig. 6 shows that the color
and texture details of the dental disease are highlighted after the
enhancement.

strong sense of tooth protection, can be problematic. The latest
survey on oral health shows that a shocking 94% of popula-
tion suffers from various forms of dental problems in China [1].
However, dental diseases in many cases can be prevented, and
serious problems can be avoided if teeth are regularly moni-
tored. Moreover, the monitoring of periodontal, gingival and
oral mucosa can play a signiï¬cant role in monitoring the pa-
tientsâ€™ cardiovascular and cerebrovascular diseases, diabetes,
AIDS and other problems [2]â€“[4].
Nowadays, the IoT, a growing ubiquitous concept, has inu-
enced various aspects of human life [5]. To be more speciï¬c,
IoT-based healthcare service has been applied to a wide range of
elds, and various healthcare solutions are thereby provided [6],
[7]. It is possible to achieve signicant enhancement in healthcare
such as early-detection and prediction. However, with the emer-
gence of the IoT-based healthcare services, smart HomeCentric
dental solution can be built to make treatment before getting
illnessa reality. Speciï¬cally, such studies focus commonly on
IoT-based healthcare services platforms, with few researches on
In-home dental healthcare and services.
The rapid development of wireless and mobile networks has
been accompanied by mobile terminals serving as an effective
social platform for everyone, and mobile application software
is increasingly popular, thereby making it necessary to design
the dental healthcare APPs to realize the quick and effective
connection between patients and dental doctors.
Recent years have witnessed deep learning showing potential
in the versatile and highly variable tasks of a variety of ï¬ne-
grained object classiï¬cations. Powered by advances in com-
putation and excessively large datasets, deep learning algo-
rithms have produced promising results in different medical
tasks, which have also been applied in medical image analy-
sis such as MRI, derma to scopic images and standard images.
Deep neural networks were used to form a mammography mass
lesion classiï¬cation [8], Alzheimer disease classiï¬cation [9],
skin lesion and skin cancer classiï¬cation [10], [11] Ayse Betul
Oktay presented a method of detecting teeth in dental panoramic
X-ray images with Convolutional Neural Network (CNN) [12],
which is also used to implement the automated segmentation of
gingival diseases from oral images [13]. In [14], the approaches
of CNN and transfer learning are used in dental diseases, and
the above artiï¬cial intelligence methods for dental are based

logic level. Users capture pictures using intelligent dental im-
age data acquisition device, and then upload the pictures to the
service platform through the mobile terminal, and these den-
tal image data will be analyzed using AI methods. The system
will advise the user to seek for medical care if problems have
been found in teeth after the conï¬rmation of the service by the
user. Nearby dental clinics or doctors based on their geographic
location will be recommended at the service platform, thereby
making it possible for users to consult with doctors to make
appointments and complete ofï¬‚ine medical procedures if the
appointment is successful.

Fig. 4. The intelligent dental image acquisition device hardware
diagram.
C. Intelligent Hardware
Traditional dental image collection methods can bring about
the inconvenience as follows:
r Dentists are required to acquire knowledge on more shoot-
ing skills;
r It is necessary to expand the auxiliary equipment such as
the oral expander, along with high cost of the SLR camera.
r Only partial dental images can be obtained
Due to the peculiarity of oral structure, the general image
acquisition equipment (e.g. smart cell-phone) cant meet the im-
age data collection requirement of 6 surfaces of teeth, thereby
helping explain that an intelligent dental image acquisition de-
vice is designed to photograph dental images. As shown in the
Fig. 4 , the intelligent dental image acquisition device is mainly
composed of an image module and the control board, and the
micro exible packaging technology is applied to manufacture
the image module. On the exible printed circuit board, it is in-
tegrated with a 1-megapixel CMOS Sensor, the supplementary
lighting LEDs, and a macro lens to form a module.
Including processing chip, Wi-Fi module, gyroscope, mem-
ory, keys, LEDs, power management and wireless charger, the
main board has functions such as video encoding, interface con-
trol, light control and task processing. Additionally, the device
can be communicated with the mobile terminal through the Wi-
Fi module. When photographing the teeth, the left-side images
and right-side images are ï¬‚ipped, with the use of a gyroscope
sensor in the hardware design [16]. Moreover, In the process
of shooting, the processor can sense the change signal, and then
correct the image position with the software automatically.

the intelligent dental Health-IoT platform, and the main steps

in model testing, training data set and test data are respectively
from different objects, thus without overlap between the testing
dataset and the training dataset.
B. Build Sample Set
The semi-automatic labeling method is applied to establish
the training sample set to improve the efï¬ciency. The dental im-
ages were initially labeled by the design of detector for 7 types
of dental diseases, as shown in Fig. 5 , the functions of the de-
tector here include image enhancement, color texture matching,
coarse localization and classiï¬cation of disease. Followed by
the conï¬rmation of images with labeling error or classiï¬cation
error through manual screening method, the training samples
set were ï¬nally calibrated by 20 dental disease experts, with the
details as follows:
1) Image Enhancement: In some dental images, the features
of the tooth disease site without very high contrast are not very
obvious, thereby making it necessary to enhance the images
before designing the classiï¬cation algorithms. The Retinex al-
gorithm is used [17], which adaptively prompts various types
of images to achieve balance in dynamic range, edge, and color.
The image enhancement effect in Fig. 6 shows that the color
and texture details of the dental disease are highlighted after the
enhancement.
2) Coarse Localization and Classiï¬cation of Dental Disease
Target Area: It is just a preliminary detecting, and only the areas
close to the color and texture of the image to be matched will
be detected as samples. Firstly, a histogram matching method
with fast calculation speed is used to select the region of color
proximity, followed by the use of the Tamura texture feature

3) Artiï¬cial Screening Determines the Sample Library: For

conï¬rmed by dental disease experts. Labelme tool is used to gen-
erate mask data set, along with description of the segmentation

points. We delete the wrong label positions and ï¬x the wrong
tags through articial selection, along with the possible adding of
the undetected target images. The nished data is applied as the
training sample data for the detection and classication of dental
diseases, ending up with the summary of the recorded frame
images to establish the dental training sample set.
C. Model Training
Common target detection algorithms including RCNN,
YOLO, SSD [19] only classify the target in the image. However,
the accurate target segmentation is benecial to the auxiliary med-
ical diagnosis, to achieve the aim of fast and accurate detection
of dental diseases and dental area accurate segmentation. Based
on the established dental sample library, the MASK R-CNN
method is chosen for the accurate detection and segmentation
of the dental target.
The designed MASK R-CNN network is shown in the left
of Fig. 6 , in which, MASK R-CNN adds a branch predicting
the segmentation mask in each interested area based on Faster
R-CNN [20]. In Faster R-CNN, region of interest (RoI) pool
is used to extract the small features from each RoI. Firstly,
RoIPool scales the RoI represented by oating point numbers to
Fig. 7. Left: MASK R-CNN network. Right: example detections using
MASK R-CNN on dental images test.
the granularity matching the feature graph, followed by parti-
tioning of the scaled ROI, ending up with the summary of the
characteristic value of each block coverage area. Such calcula-
tions misplace the ROI and the extracted features, which, though
possibly not affecting the classication, for the classication has
the certain robustness to the small amplitude transformation,
exerts a great negative impact on the prediction of the precise
mask of pixel level. Mask R-CNN proposes the RoI Align layer
to remove the dislocation of RoIPool and aligns the extracted
features with the input accurately. In RoI Align, a bilinear in-
terpolation is used to calculate the exact value of each position,
along with the summary of the results by using the maximum
or average pooling, and the extracted features and input can be
aligned with the pixel to pixel, thereby improving the segmen-
tation accuracy effectively. For the lower convolution network
used for feature extraction on the whole image, the ResNet-50-
C4 backbone [20], [21] is adopted with the depth of 50 layers,
and extract features from the nal convolution layer of the fourth
stage in the MASK R-CNN. For the upper network, we extend
the Faster R-CNN upper network proposed in ResNet, adding a
mask branch respectively. TensorFlow and Mask R-CNN open
source are adopted in the training model, along with modiï¬ca-
tion of ShapesCong class, and GPU COUNT and IMAGES PER
GPU are set to 1 according to the training server conguration.
At the same time, according to the training sample library, cate-
gories NUM CLASSES, image size IMAGE MIN DIM and the
size of the anchor RPN AN', 'cation of dental diseases

Fig. 8. A board level prototype of the intelligent dental image acquisition

The algorithm above is followed to train the model following the
4-step training of Faster R-CNN [22], with the Table II showing
the recognition accuracy of each dental disease. The table shows
that we can ï¬nd good results achieved by MASK R-CNN even
under challenging conditions, such as the reection of saliva,
tooth gap, etc. The recognition rate of the algorithm is over 90%
for these seven major dental diseases, with the recognition rate
of dental plaque as 100%, and the recognition rate of decayed
tooth as 90.1%. It is analyzed that relatively low recognition rate
of decayed tooth is attributed to the device using a xed focus
lens, which will be affected by the shooting, such as smear
and defocusing blurring. In addition, coding errors and missing
frames can also be responsible for it. Compared with the related
work in [14], the accuracy of the presented transfer learning
method for the classication of dental caries and periodontitis
are all 87.5 %. This work achieves an accuracy of 90.1% and
94.3% respectively, indicating that the classication accuracy of
corresponding dental diseases has been greatly improved in our
work.

algorithm by this design [18], which is applied to ï¬nd the

3) Artiï¬cial Screening Determines the Sample Library: For
the image areas after coarse location and classication, the anno-
tation information of each frame of data needs to be manually
conï¬rmed by dental disease experts. Labelme tool is used to gen-
erate mask data set, along with description of the segmentation
region of dental disease as accurate as possible with multiple key

tags through articial selection, along with the possible adding of
the undetected target images. The nished data is applied as the
training sample data for the detection and classication of dental
diseases, ending up with the summary of the recorded frame
images to establish the dental training sample set.
C. Model Training
Common target detection algorithms including RCNN,
YOLO, SSD [19] only classify the target in the image. However,
the accurate target segmentation is benecial to the auxiliary med-
ical diagnosis, to achieve the aim of fast and accurate detection
of dental diseases and dental area accurate segmentation. Based
on the established dental sample library, the MASK R-CNN
method is chosen for the accurate detection and segmentation
of the dental target.
The designed MASK R-CNN network is shown in the left
of Fig. 6 , in which, MASK R-CNN adds a branch predicting
the segmentation mask in each interested area based on Faster
R-CNN [20]. In Faster R-CNN, region of interest (RoI) pool
is used to extract the small features from each RoI. Firstly,
RoIPool scales the RoI represented by oating point numbers to
Fig. 7. Left: MASK R-CNN network. Right: example detections using
MASK R-CNN on dental images test.
the granularity matching the feature graph, followed by parti-
tioning of the scaled ROI, ending up with the summary of the
characteristic value of each block coverage area. Such calcula-
tions misplace the ROI and the extracted features, which, though
possibly not affecting the classication, for the classication has
the certain robustness to the small amplitude transformation,
exerts a great negative impact on the prediction of the precise
mask of pixel level. Mask R-CNN proposes the RoI Align layer
to remove the dislocation of RoIPool and aligns the extracted
features with the input accurately. In RoI Align, a bilinear in-
terpolation is used to calculate the exact value of each position,
along with the summary of the results by using the maximum
or average pooling, and the extracted features and input can be
aligned with the pixel to pixel, thereby improving the segmen-
tation accuracy effectively. For the lower convolution network
used for feature extraction on the whole image, the ResNet-50-
C4 backbone [20], [21] is adopted with the depth of 50 layers,
and extract features from the nal convolution layer of the fourth
stage in the MASK R-CNN. For the upper network, we extend
the Faster R-CNN upper network proposed in ResNet, adding a
mask branch respectively. TensorFlow and Mask R-CNN open
source are adopted in the training model, along with modiï¬ca-
tion of ShapesCong class, and GPU COUNT and IMAGES PER
GPU are set to 1 according to the training server conguration.
At the same time, according to the training sample library, cate-
gories NUM CLASSES, image size IMAGE MIN DIM and the
size of the anchor RPN AN', ' image, the ResNet-50-
C4 backbone [20], [21] is adopted with the depth of 50 layers,
and extract features from the nal convolution layer of the fourth
stage in the MASK R-CNN. For the upper network, we extend
the Faster R-CNN upper network proposed in ResNet, adding a
mask branch respectively. TensorFlow and Mask R-CNN open
source are adopted in the training model, along with modiï¬ca-
tion of ShapesCong class, and GPU COUNT and IMAGES PER
GPU are set to 1 according to the training server conguration.
At the same time, according to the training sample library, cate-
gories NUM CLASSES, image size IMAGE MIN DIM and the
size of the anchor RPN ANCHOR SCALES are set. The sample
data is transferred from the 16-bit grayscale to 8-bit grayscale,
then copied to the training directory to execute the training code.
The data sets for each dental disease were basically balanced,
and the method of limiting training time is adopted to avoid
overï¬tting, with the detection results using MASK R-CNN on
dental images being shown in the right of Fig. 7 .
D. Inference
Recognition rate in this study refers to the rate at which dental
diseases can be correctly identiï¬ed in these testing image data.

The algorithm above is followed to train the model following the
4-step training of Faster R-CNN [22], with the Table II showing
the recognition accuracy of each dental disease. The table shows
that we can ï¬nd good results achieved by MASK R-CNN even
under challenging conditions, such as the reection of saliva,
tooth gap, etc. The recognition rate of the algorithm is over 90%
for these seven major dental diseases, with the recognition rate
of dental plaque as 100%, and the recognition rate of decayed
tooth as 90.1%. It is analyzed that relatively low recognition rate
of decayed tooth is attributed to the device using a xed focus
lens, which will be affected by the shooting, such as smear
and defocusing blurring. In addition, coding errors and missing
frames can also be responsible for it. Compared with the related
work in [14], the accuracy of the presented transfer learning
method for the classication of dental caries and periodontitis
are all 87.5 %. This work achieves an accuracy of 90.1% and
94.3% respectively, indicating that the classication accuracy of
corresponding dental diseases has been greatly improved in our
work.

the phone communicating via Wi-Fi. As shown in Fig. 8 ,t h e
hardware motherboard is a circular plate with 6cm of diameter,
which is suitable for being held in hands, and can be inserted
into the mouth exibly to collect images of the teeth. A small
percentage of the collected images, due to the lack of']

Due to the lack of dental diseases standard data sets, we
worked with some dental clinics (such as Beijing Mei-Xiao
dental clinics). With the consent of the subjects, 300 subjects
use dental image acquisition device to sample the dental diseases
video data, and the algorithm analyzes each frame of video, and
3835 images of dental cases are sampled ï¬nally. These clinics
already have 8,765 images of dental cases, with a total of 12,600
clinical images being collected. These images are classiï¬ed into
7 different types as shown in Table I, with the 7 types of dental
diseases as follows: dental caries, dental uorosis, periodontal
disease, cracked tooth, dental calculus, dental plaque, and tooth
loss. 4/5 of these data was used in training, while 1/5 of them was
in model testing, training data set and test data are respectively
from different objects, thus without overlap between the testing
dataset and the training dataset.
B. Build Sample Set
The semi-automatic labeling method is applied to establish
the training sample set to improve the efï¬ciency. The dental im-
ages were initially labeled by the design of detector for 7 types
of dental diseases, as shown in Fig. 5 , the functions of the de-
tector here include image enhancement, color texture matching,
coarse localization and classiï¬cation of disease. Followed by
the conï¬rmation of images with labeling error or classiï¬cation
error through manual screening method, the training samples
set were ï¬nally calibrated by 20 dental disease experts, with the
details as follows:
1) Image Enhancement: In some dental images, the features
of the tooth disease site without very high contrast are not very
obvious, thereby making it necessary to enhance the images
before designing the classiï¬cation algorithms. The Retinex al-
gorithm is used [17], which adaptively prompts various types
of images to achieve balance in dynamic range, edge, and color.
The image enhancement effect in Fig. 6 shows that the color
and texture details of the dental disease are highlighted after the
enhancement.
2) Coarse Localization and Classiï¬cation of Dental Disease
Target Area: It is just a preliminary detecting, and only the areas
close to the color and texture of the image to be matched will
be detected as samples. Firstly, a histogram matching method
with fast calculation speed is used to select the region of color
proximity, followed by the use of the Tamura texture feature

on X-ray. However, visual diagnosis serves as one of the most
important parts of dental health care.
The smart dental health IoT system, due to the lack of coor-
dinated IoT-based In-home dental health care services, is devel-
oped in this paper, which plays an important role in elaborating
its applications in home and private dental clinic scenarios. The
proposed system builds a home-centric, self-assisted, fully au-
tomatic intelligent In-home dental healthcare solution by taking
advantage of embedded intelligent hardware technology, articial
intelligence (AI), and the mobile terminal.
The system closely combines the personal self-service dental
health examination and dental resources through studying the
AI method to expand the scope and coverage of traditional
dental health care, which is the major contribution made by the
proposed iHome smart dental Health-IoT system. Patients can
choose medical resources online and receive an appointment for
medical treatment via self-service smart dental screening.
The rest parts of this paper are organized as follows.
Section II discusses smart In-home dentist system, followed
by Section III analyzing the intelligent dental diagnosis, intro-
ducing the algorithm ï¬‚ow and test results. Section IV presents
the integrated system and hardware prototype, and reports the
application results, and a conclusion is given in Section V
ï¬nally.
II. S MART IN-HOME DENTIST SYSTEM
The occurrence of dental disease can be well predictable. For
example, each stage from dental plaque, calculus to dental caries
and periodontal disease shows different characteristics and so-
lutions, thereby making it possible to monitor the whole body
and reduce the risk of sudden diseases effectively. It can reduce
pain, save time and reduce the cost of money for patients. How-
ever, most consumers lack the correct tooth awareness, thereby
making the timely treatment for tooth disease difï¬cult. More-
over, there is a relative shortage of dental resources in hospitals.
These main contradictions are explained in the following aspects
in details:
r First, there are a lot of patients with dental diseases, but
fewer people pay attention to the teeth. Many individ-
uals pay for treatment only when they have teeth with
problems, which may cause irreversible damage to the
long-term development of children.
r Second, the cost of dental treatment is relatively high.
r Third, dental disease, due to the characteristics of elective
treatment, is difï¬cult to get timely treatment.
Based on what is discussed above, a promising trend in health-
care is to move routine medical checks and other healthcare ser-
vices from hospital (Hospital-Centric) to the home environment
(Home-centric) [15], through which, the patients can get seam-
less health care at any time in a comfortable home environment.
Even more, it can ensure that the overall iHome dental health-
care system including three partspersonalized services, dental
services and intelligent and interactive service could be opti-
mized to a large extent. Based on this platform, the closed', ' interconnected devices promise
more efï¬cient and comprehensive health care,â€ IEEE Pulse , vol. 7, no. 5,

strong sense of tooth protection, can be problematic. The latest
survey on oral health shows that a shocking 94% of popula-
tion suffers from various forms of dental problems in China [1].
However, dental diseases in many cases can be prevented, and
serious problems can be avoided if teeth are regularly moni-
tored. Moreover, the monitoring of periodontal, gingival and
oral mucosa can play a signiï¬cant role in monitoring the pa-
tientsâ€™ cardiovascular and cerebrovascular diseases, diabetes,
AIDS and other problems [2]â€“[4].
Nowadays, the IoT, a growing ubiquitous concept, has inu-
enced various aspects of human life [5]. To be more speciï¬c,
IoT-based healthcare service has been applied to a wide range of
elds, and various healthcare solutions are thereby provided [6],
[7]. It is possible to achieve signicant enhancement in healthcare
such as early-detection and prediction. However, with the emer-
gence of the IoT-based healthcare services, smart HomeCentric
dental solution can be built to make treatment before getting
illnessa reality. Speciï¬cally, such studies focus commonly on
IoT-based healthcare services platforms, with few researches on
In-home dental healthcare and services.
The rapid development of wireless and mobile networks has
been accompanied by mobile terminals serving as an effective
social platform for everyone, and mobile application software
is increasingly popular, thereby making it necessary to design
the dental healthcare APPs to realize the quick and effective
connection between patients and dental doctors.
Recent years have witnessed deep learning showing potential
in the versatile and highly variable tasks of a variety of ï¬ne-
grained object classiï¬cations. Powered by advances in com-
putation and excessively large datasets, deep learning algo-
rithms have produced promising results in different medical
tasks, which have also been applied in medical image analy-
sis such as MRI, derma to scopic images and standard images.
Deep neural networks were used to form a mammography mass
lesion classiï¬cation [8], Alzheimer disease classiï¬cation [9],
skin lesion and skin cancer classiï¬cation [10], [11] Ayse Betul
Oktay presented a method of detecting teeth in dental panoramic
X-ray images with Convolutional Neural Network (CNN) [12],

gingival diseases from oral images [13]. In [14], the approaches

The smart dental health IoT system, due to the lack of coor-

its applications in home and private dental clinic scenarios. The
proposed system builds a home-centric, self-assisted, fully au-

advantage of embedded intelligent hardware technology, articial

The system closely combines the personal self-service dental

dental health care, which is the major contribution made by the
proposed iHome smart dental Health-IoT system. Patients can

The rest parts of this paper are organized as follows.
Section II discusses smart In-home dentist system, followed

II. S MART IN-HOME DENTIST SYSTEM
The occurrence of dental disease can be well predictable. For
example, each stage from dental plaque, calculus to dental caries
and periodontal disease shows different characteristics and so-
lutions, thereby making it possible to monitor the whole body
and reduce the risk of sudden diseases effectively. It can reduce
pain, save time and reduce the cost of money for patients. How-
ever, most consumers lack the correct tooth awareness, thereby
making the timely treatment for tooth disease difï¬cult. More-
over, there is a relative shortage of dental resources in hospitals.
These main contradictions are explained in the following aspects
in details:
r First, there are a lot of patients with dental diseases, but
fewer people pay attention to the teeth. Many individ-
uals pay for treatment only when they have teeth with
problems, which may cause irreversible damage to the
long-term development of children.
r Second, the cost of dental treatment is relatively high.
r Third, dental disease, due to the characteristics of elective
treatment, is difï¬cult to get timely treatment.
Based on what is discussed above, a promising trend in health-
care is to move routine medical checks and other healthcare ser-
vices from hospital (Hospital-Centric) to the home environment
(Home-centric) [15], through which, the patients can get seam-
less health care at any time in a comfortable home environment.
Even more, it can ensure that the overall iHome dental health-
care system including three partspersonalized services, dental
services and intelligent and interactive service could be opti-
mized to a large extent. Based on this platform, the closed', ' image, the ResNet-50-

the Faster R-CNN upper network proposed in ResNet, adding a
mask branch respectively. TensorFlow and Mask R-CNN open

The data sets for each dental disease were basically balanced,

dental images being shown in the right of Fig. 7 .

The algorithm above is followed to train the model following the
4-step training of Faster R-CNN [22], with the Table II showing
the recognition accuracy of each dental disease. The table shows
that we can ï¬nd good results achieved by MASK R-CNN even
under challenging conditions, such as the reection of saliva,
tooth gap, etc. The recognition rate of the algorithm is over 90%
for these seven major dental diseases, with the recognition rate
of dental plaque as 100%, and the recognition rate of decayed
tooth as 90.1%. It is analyzed that relatively low recognition rate
of decayed tooth is attributed to the device using a xed focus
lens, which will be affected by the shooting, such as smear
and defocusing blurring. In addition, coding errors and missing
frames can also be responsible for it. Compared with the related
work in [14], the accuracy of the presented transfer learning
method for the classication of dental caries and periodontitis
are all 87.5 %. This work achieves an accuracy of 90.1% and
94.3% respectively, indicating that the classication accuracy of
corresponding dental diseases has been greatly improved in our
work.

A Smart Dental Health-IoT Platform Based on
Intelligent Hardware, Deep Learning, and
Mobile T erminal
Lizheng Liu , Student Member, IEEE,J i a w e iX u , Student Member, IEEE,
Y uxiang Huan , Student Member, IEEE, Zhuo Zou , Senior Member, IEEE,
Shih-Ching Y eh , Member, IEEE, and Li-Rong Zheng , Senior Member, IEEE
Abstractâ€” The dental disease is a common disease for a
human. Screening and visual diagnosis that are currently
performed in clinics possibly cost a lot in various manners.
Along with the progress of the Internet of Things (IoT) and
artiï¬cial intelligence, the internet-based intelligent system
have shown great potential in applying home-based health-
care. Therefore, a smart dental health-IoT system based on
intelligent hardware, deep learning, and mobile terminal is
proposed in this paper, aiming at exploring the feasibility
of its application on in-home dental healthcare. Moreover, a
smart dental device is designed and developed in this study
to perform the image acquisition of teeth. Based on the data
set of 12 600 clinical images collected by the proposed de-
vice from 10 private dental clinics, an automatic diagnosis
model trained by MASK R-CNN is developed for the detec-
tion and classiï¬cation of 7 different dental diseases includ-
ing decayed tooth, dental plaque, uorosis, and periodontal
disease, with the diagnosis accuracy of them reaching up to
90%, along with high sensitivity and high speciï¬city. Follow-
ing the one-month test in ten clinics, compared with that last
month when the platform was not used, the mean diagnosis
time reduces by 37.5% for each patient, helping explain the
increase in the number of treated patients by 18.4%. Fur-
thermore, application software (APPs) on mobile terminal
for client side and for dentist side are implemented to pro-
vide service of pre-examination, consultation, appointment,
and evaluation.
Index Termsâ€” Health-IoT, MASK R-CNN, deep learning,
artiï¬cial intelligence, intelligent hardware, mobile terminal.

ease, dental ï¬‚uorosis, etc.) are becoming increasingly
common. Almost everyones teeth, even though he/she has a

Due to the lack of dental diseases standard data sets, we
worked with some dental clinics (such as Beijing Mei-Xiao
dental clinics). With the consent of the subjects, 300 subjects
use dental image acquisition device to sample the dental diseases
video data, and the algorithm analyzes each frame of video, and
3835 images of dental cases are sampled ï¬nally. These clinics
already have 8,765 images of dental cases, with a total of 12,600
clinical images being collected. These images are classiï¬ed into
7 different types as shown in Table I, with the 7 types of dental
diseases as follows: dental caries, dental uorosis, periodontal
disease, cracked tooth, dental calculus, dental plaque, and tooth
loss. 4/5 of these data was used in training, while 1/5 of them was
in model testing, training data set and test data are respectively
from different objects, thus without overlap between the testing
dataset and the training dataset.
B. Build Sample Set
The semi-automatic labeling method is applied to establish
the training sample set to improve the efï¬ciency. The dental im-
ages were initially labeled by the design of detector for 7 types
of dental diseases, as shown in Fig. 5 , the functions of the de-
tector here include image enhancement, color texture matching,
coarse localization and classiï¬cation of disease. Followed by
the conï¬rmation of images with labeling error or classiï¬cation
error through manual screening method, the training samples
set were ï¬nally calibrated by 20 dental disease experts, with the
details as follows:
1) Image Enhancement: In some dental images, the features
of the tooth disease site without very high contrast are not very
obvious, thereby making it necessary to enhance the images
before designing the classiï¬cation algorithms. The Retinex al-
gorithm is used [17], which adaptively prompts various types
of images to achieve balance in dynamic range, edge, and color.
The image enhancement effect in Fig. 6 shows that the color
and texture details of the dental disease are highlighted after the
enhancement.
2) Coarse Localization and Classiï¬cation of Dental Disease
Target Area: It is just a preliminary detecting, and only the areas
close to the color and texture of the image to be matched will
be detected as samples. Firstly, a histogram matching method
with fast calculation speed is used to select the region of color
proximity, followed by the use of the Tamura texture feature

C. Model Training
Common target detection algorithms including RCNN,
YOLO, SSD [19] only classify the target in the image. However,
the accurate target segmentation is benecial to the auxiliary med-
ical diagnosis, to achieve the aim of fast and accurate detection
of dental diseases and dental area accurate segmentation. Based
on the established dental sample library, the MASK R-CNN
method is chosen for the accurate detection and segmentation
of the dental target.
The designed MASK R-CNN network is shown in the left
of Fig. 6 , in which, MASK R-CNN adds a branch predicting
the segmentation mask in each interested area based on Faster
R-CNN [20]. In Faster R-CNN, region of interest (RoI) pool
is used to extract the small features from each RoI. Firstly,
RoIPool scales the RoI represented by oating point numbers to
Fig. 7. Left: MASK R-CNN network. Right: example detections using
MASK R-CNN on dental images test.
the granularity matching the feature graph, followed by parti-
tioning of the scaled ROI, ending up with the summary of the
characteristic value of each block coverage area. Such calcula-
tions misplace the ROI and the extracted features, which, though
possibly not affecting the classication, for the classication has
the certain robustness to the small amplitude transformation,
exerts a great negative impact on the prediction of the precise
mask of pixel level. Mask R-CNN proposes the RoI Align layer
to remove the dislocation of RoIPool and aligns the extracted
features with the input accurately. In RoI Align, a bilinear in-
terpolation is used to calculate the exact value of each position,
along with the summary of the results by using the maximum
or average pooling, and the extracted features and input can be
aligned with the pixel to pixel, thereby improving the segmen-
tation accuracy effectively. For the lower convolution network
used for feature extraction on the whole image, the ResNet-50-
C4 backbone [20], [21] is adopted with the depth of 50 layers,
and extract features from the nal convolution layer of the fourth
stage in the MASK R-CNN. For the upper network, we extend
the Faster R-CNN upper network proposed in ResNet, adding a
mask branch respectively. TensorFlow and Mask R-CNN open
source are adopted in the training model, along with modiï¬ca-
tion of ShapesCong class, and GPU COUNT and IMAGES PER
GPU are set to 1 according to the training server conguration.

gories NUM CLASSES, image size IMAGE MIN DIM and the
size of the anchor RPN AN']

are all 87.5 %. This work achieves an accuracy of 90.1% and
94.3% respectively, indicating that the classication accuracy of
corresponding dental diseases has been greatly improved in our
work.

C. Model Training
Common target detection algorithms including RCNN,
YOLO, SSD [19] only classify the target in the image. However,
the accurate target segmentation is benecial to the auxiliary med-
ical diagnosis, to achieve the aim of fast and accurate detection
of dental diseases and dental area accurate segmentation. Based
on the established dental sample library, the MASK R-CNN
method is chosen for the accurate detection and segmentation
of the dental target.
The designed MASK R-CNN network is shown in the left
of Fig. 6 , in which, MASK R-CNN adds a branch predicting
the segmentation mask in each interested area based on Faster
R-CNN [20]. In Faster R-CNN, region of interest (RoI) pool
is used to extract the small features from each RoI. Firstly,
RoIPool scales the RoI represented by oating point numbers to
Fig. 7. Left: MASK R-CNN network. Right: example detections using
MASK R-CNN on dental images test.
the granularity matching the feature graph, followed by parti-
tioning of the scaled ROI, ending up with the summary of the
characteristic value of each block coverage area. Such calcula-
tions misplace the ROI and the extracted features, which, though
possibly not affecting the classication, for the classication has
the certain robustness to the small amplitude transformation,
exerts a great negative impact on the prediction of the precise
mask of pixel level. Mask R-CNN proposes the RoI Align layer
to remove the dislocation of RoIPool and aligns the extracted
features with the input accurately. In RoI Align, a bilinear in-
terpolation is used to calculate the exact value of each position,
along with the summary of the results by using the maximum
or average pooling, and the extracted features and input can be
aligned with the pixel to pixel, thereby improving the segmen-
tation accuracy effectively. For the lower convolution network
used for feature extraction on the whole image, the ResNet-50-
C4 backbone [20], [21] is adopted with the depth of 50 layers,
and extract features from the nal convolution layer of the fourth
stage in the MASK R-CNN. For the upper network, we extend
the Faster R-CNN upper network proposed in ResNet, adding a
mask branch respectively. TensorFlow and Mask R-CNN open
source are adopted in the training model, along with modiï¬ca-
tion of ShapesCong class, and GPU COUNT and IMAGES PER
GPU are set to 1 according to the training server conguration.

gories NUM CLASSES, image size IMAGE MIN DIM and the

on X-ray. However, visual diagnosis serves as one of the most
important parts of dental health care.
The smart dental health IoT system, due to the lack of coor-
dinated IoT-based In-home dental health care services, is devel-
oped in this paper, which plays an important role in elaborating
its applications in home and private dental clinic scenarios. The
proposed system builds a home-centric, self-assisted, fully au-
tomatic intelligent In-home dental healthcare solution by taking
advantage of embedded intelligent hardware technology, articial
intelligence (AI), and the mobile terminal.
The system closely combines the personal self-service dental
health examination and dental resources through studying the
AI method to expand the scope and coverage of traditional
dental health care, which is the major contribution made by the
proposed iHome smart dental Health-IoT system. Patients can
choose medical resources online and receive an appointment for
medical treatment via self-service smart dental screening.
The rest parts of this paper are organized as follows.
Section II discusses smart In-home dentist system, followed
by Section III analyzing the intelligent dental diagnosis, intro-
ducing the algorithm ï¬‚ow and test results. Section IV presents
the integrated system and hardware prototype, and reports the
application results, and a conclusion is given in Section V
ï¬nally.
II. S MART IN-HOME DENTIST SYSTEM
The occurrence of dental disease can be well predictable. For
example, each stage from dental plaque, calculus to dental caries
and periodontal disease shows different characteristics and so-
lutions, thereby making it possible to monitor the whole body
and reduce the risk of sudden diseases effectively. It can reduce
pain, save time and reduce the cost of money for patients. How-
ever, most consumers lack the correct tooth awareness, thereby
making the timely treatment for tooth disease difï¬cult. More-
over, there is a relative shortage of dental resources in hospitals.
These main contradictions are explained in the following aspects
in details:
r First, there are a lot of patients with dental diseases, but
fewer people pay attention to the teeth. Many individ-
uals pay for treatment only when they have teeth with
problems, which may cause irreversible damage to the
long-term development of children.
r Second, the cost of dental treatment is relatively high.
r Third, dental disease, due to the characteristics of elective
treatment, is difï¬cult to get timely treatment.
Based on what is discussed above, a promising trend in health-
care is to move routine medical checks and other healthcare ser-
vices from hospital (Hospital-Centric) to the home environment
(Home-centric) [15], through which, the patients can get seam-
less health care at any time in a comfortable home environment.
Even more, it can ensure that the overall iHome dental health-
care system including three partspersonalized services, dental
services and intelligent and interactive service could be opti-
mized to a large extent. Based on this platform, the closed', '3, MARCH 2020

C. Intelligent Hardware
Traditional dental image collection methods can bring about
the inconvenience as follows:
r Dentists are required to acquire knowledge on more shoot-
ing skills;
r It is necessary to expand the auxiliary equipment such as
the oral expander, along with high cost of the SLR camera.
r Only partial dental images can be obtained
Due to the peculiarity of oral structure, the general image
acquisition equipment (e.g. smart cell-phone) cant meet the im-
age data collection requirement of 6 surfaces of teeth, thereby
helping explain that an intelligent dental image acquisition de-
vice is designed to photograph dental images. As shown in the
Fig. 4 , the intelligent dental image acquisition device is mainly
composed of an image module and the control board, and the
micro exible packaging technology is applied to manufacture
the image module. On the exible printed circuit board, it is in-
tegrated with a 1-megapixel CMOS Sensor, the supplementary
lighting LEDs, and a macro lens to form a module.
Including processing chip, Wi-Fi module, gyroscope, mem-
ory, keys, LEDs, power management and wireless charger, the
main board has functions such as video encoding, interface con-
trol, light control and task processing. Additionally, the device
can be communicated with the mobile terminal through the Wi-
Fi module. When photographing the teeth, the left-side images
and right-side images are ï¬‚ipped, with the use of a gyroscope
sensor in the hardware design [16]. Moreover, In the process
of shooting, the processor can sense the change signal, and then
correct the image position with the software automatically.
