B. Build Sample Set
The semi-automatic labeling method is applied to establish
the training sample set to improve the efï¬ciency. The dental im-
ages were initially labeled by the design of detector for 7 types
of dental diseases, as shown in Fig. 5 , the functions of the de-
tector here include image enhancement, color texture matching,
coarse localization and classiï¬cation of disease. Followed by
the conï¬rmation of images with labeling error or classiï¬cation
error through manual screening method, the training samples
set were ï¬nally calibrated by 20 dental disease experts, with the
details as follows:
1) Image Enhancement: In some dental images, the features
of the tooth disease site without very high contrast are not very
obvious, thereby making it necessary to enhance the images
before designing the classiï¬cation algorithms. The Retinex al-
gorithm is used [17], which adaptively prompts various types
of images to achieve balance in dynamic range, edge, and color.
The image enhancement effect in Fig. 6 shows that the color
and texture details of the dental disease are highlighted after the
enhancement.
2) Coarse Localization and Classiï¬cation of Dental Disease
Target Area: It is just a preliminary detecting, and only the areas
close to the color and texture of the image to be matched will
be detected as samples. Firstly, a histogram matching method
with fast calculation speed is used to select the region of color
proximity, followed by the use of the Tamura texture feature

3) Artiï¬cial Screening Determines the Sample Library: For
the image areas after coarse location and classication, the anno-
tation information of each frame of data needs to be manually
conï¬rmed by dental disease experts. Labelme tool is used to gen-
erate mask data set, along with description of the segmentation
region of dental disease as accurate as possible with multiple key
points. We delete the wrong label positions and ï¬x the wrong
tags through articial selection, along with the possible adding of
the undetected target images. The nished data is applied as the
training sample data for the detection and classication of dental
diseases, ending up with the summary of the recorded frame
images to establish the dental training sample set.
C. Model Training
Common target detection algorithms including RCNN,
YOLO, SSD [19] only classify the target in the image. However,
the accurate target segmentation is benecial to the auxiliary med-
ical diagnosis, to achieve the aim of fast and accurate detection
of dental diseases and dental area accurate segmentation. Based
on the established dental sample library, the MASK R-CNN
method is chosen for the accurate detection and segmentation
of the dental target.
The designed MASK R-CNN network is shown in the left
of Fig. 6 , in which, MASK R-CNN adds a branch predicting
the segmentation mask in each interested area based on Faster
R-CNN [20]. In Faster R-CNN, region of interest (RoI) pool
is used to extract the small features from each RoI. Firstly,
RoIPool scales the RoI represented by oating point numbers to
Fig. 7. Left: MASK R-CNN network. Right: example detections using
MASK R-CNN on dental images test.
the granularity matching the feature graph, followed by parti-
tioning of the scaled ROI, ending up with the summary of the
characteristic value of each block coverage area. Such calcula-
tions misplace the ROI and the extracted features, which, though
possibly not affecting the classication, for the classication has
the certain robustness to the small amplitude transformation,
exerts a great negative impact on the prediction of the precise
mask of pixel level. Mask R-CNN proposes the RoI Align layer
to remove the dislocation of RoIPool and aligns the extracted
features with the input accurately. In RoI Align, a bilinear in-
terpolation is used to calculate the exact value of each position,
along with the summary of the results by using the maximum
or average pooling, and the extracted features and input can be
aligned with the pixel to pixel, thereby improving the segmen-
tation accuracy effectively. For the lower convolution network
used for feature extraction on the whole image, the ResNet-50-
C4 backbone [20], [21] is adopted with the depth of 50 layers,
and extract features from the nal convolution layer of the fourth
stage in the MASK R-CNN. For the upper network, we extend
the Faster R-CNN upper network proposed in ResNet, adding a
mask branch respectively. TensorFlow and Mask R-CNN open
source are adopted in the training model, along with modiï¬ca-
tion of ShapesCong class, and GPU COUNT and IMAGES PER
GPU are set to 1 according to the training server conguration.
At the same time, according to the training sample library, cate-
gories NUM CLASSES, image size IMAGE MIN DIM and the
size of the anchor RPN AN', '.
include teeth cases images collection, the sample set building,
and model training to achieve this goal. The system ï¬‚owchart is
shown in Fig. 5 .
Due to the lack of dental diseases standard data sets, we
worked with some dental clinics (such as Beijing Mei-Xiao
dental clinics). With the consent of the subjects, 300 subjects
use dental image acquisition device to sample the dental diseases
video data, and the algorithm analyzes each frame of video, and
3835 images of dental cases are sampled ï¬nally. These clinics
already have 8,765 images of dental cases, with a total of 12,600
clinical images being collected. These images are classiï¬ed into
7 different types as shown in Table I, with the 7 types of dental
diseases as follows: dental caries, dental uorosis, periodontal
disease, cracked tooth, dental calculus, dental plaque, and tooth
loss. 4/5 of these data was used in training, while 1/5 of them was
in model testing, training data set and test data are respectively
from different objects, thus without overlap between the testing
dataset and the training dataset.
B. Build Sample Set
The semi-automatic labeling method is applied to establish
the training sample set to improve the efï¬ciency. The dental im-
ages were initially labeled by the design of detector for 7 types
of dental diseases, as shown in Fig. 5 , the functions of the de-
tector here include image enhancement, color texture matching,
coarse localization and classiï¬cation of disease. Followed by
the conï¬rmation of images with labeling error or classiï¬cation
error through manual screening method, the training samples
set were ï¬nally calibrated by 20 dental disease experts, with the
details as follows:
1) Image Enhancement: In some dental images, the features
of the tooth disease site without very high contrast are not very
obvious, thereby making it necessary to enhance the images
before designing the classiï¬cation algorithms. The Retinex al-
gorithm is used [17], which adaptively prompts various types
of images to achieve balance in dynamic range, edge, and color.
The image enhancement effect in Fig. 6 shows that the color
and texture details of the dental disease are highlighted after the
enhancement.
2) Coarse Localization and Classiï¬cation of Dental Disease
Target Area: It is just a preliminary detecting, and only the areas
close to the color and texture of the image to be matched will
be detected as samples. Firstly, a histogram matching method
with fast calculation speed is used to select the region of color
proximity, followed by the use of the Tamura texture feature

V. C ONCLUSION
This paper proposes an iHome smart dental Health-IoT sys-
tem based on intelligent hardware, deep learning and mobile
terminal, aiming to regulate as well as optimize the accessibil-
ity of dental treatment and provide home-based dental health
care service more efciently. The trained model was used to
realize the detection and classication of dental diseases, and
application software (Apps) on mobile terminal was designed
for client-side and dentist-side. The software platform with the
functions including pre-examination of dental disease, consulta-
tion, appointment, and evaluation, etc, made the service docking
between the patient and the dentist resources a reality. The AI
algorithm achieved more than 90% recognition rate for seven
dental diseases., which has greatly improved the patient rate and
the resource utilization rate of the dental clinic through a one-
month systematic testing in 10 private dental clinics, showing
high reliability in practical application.

E. Discussion
The individual home environment is connected with the hos-
pital, dental clinics, and other medical facilities through the
developed iHome smart dental Health-IoT system, thereby pro-
viding remote diagnosis and medical service, with the key in-
novation and functionality as follows.
1) Oral Disease Prevention: The investigation showed a low
awareness of tooth protection for most patients in China. Usu-
ally, they will choose to diagnose and treat their teeth after
feeling certain discomfort. The iHome smart dental Health-IoT
system provides users with a convenient platform for the self-
examination. To be more speciï¬c, dental diseases of users can
be detected and prevented early with the help of AI analysis, as
well as raising individualsâ€™ awareness of tooth protection.
2) Intelligent Analysis: The proposed iHome smart dental
Health-IoT system performs AI analysis on dental images us-
ing deep learning algorithm, which can quickly and effectively
detect tooth diseases, thereby providing a diagnostic basis for
dentists and saving treatment time.
3) Remote Medical Service: The interactive platform of the
iHome smart dental Health-IoT system makes a direct ap-
pointment to the nearest dentists and prompts them to medi-
cal treatment in a low-price and time-saving manner. This new
internet mode can mobilize the dental diagnostic resources rel-
atively idle. Patients are able to solve their dental problems
at lower price, which is attributed to the fact that on the one
hand, the intelligent dental image acquisition device costs less,
and on the other hand, the platform has been able to mobi-
lize some idle dental clinics where clients can go for treat-
ment. In this way, the cost per customer will be reduced as the
number of users increases. The platform establishes a unique
word-of-mouth system for dentists, with the evaluation from
the patients after treatment promoting further improvement in
the quality of dentist service, making it possible for the user to
choose some cost-effective clinics for treatment.
The implemented intelligent hardware provides a way to ob-
tain dental image data, but the use of prime lens brings image
blurring and ghosting in the process of test. In addition, the lack
of lens angle results in the incomplete coverage of larger teeth.
These problems exert a relatively signiï¬cant impact on the anal-
ysis of artiï¬cial intelligence. Therefore, the future work will
give more priority to the improvement of the hardware design
and the efï¬ciency of image acquisition device, and further work
will focus on improving algorithm efï¬ciency and recognition
rate, reducing false alarm rate, and setting up a larger image
data set for dental diseases.
V. C ONCLUSION
This paper proposes an iHome smart dental Health-IoT sys-
tem based on intelligent hardware, deep learning and mobile
terminal, aiming to regulate as well as optimize the accessibil-
ity of dental treatment and provide home-based dental health
care service more efciently. The trained model was used to

on X-ray. However, visual diagnosis serves as one of the most
important parts of dental health care.
The smart dental health IoT system, due to the lack of coor-
dinated IoT-based In-home dental health care services, is devel-
oped in this paper, which plays an important role in elaborating
its applications in home and private dental clinic scenarios. The
proposed system builds a home-centric, self-assisted, fully au-
tomatic intelligent In-home dental healthcare solution by taking
advantage of embedded intelligent hardware technology, articial
intelligence (AI), and the mobile terminal.
The system closely combines the personal self-service dental
health examination and dental resources through studying the
AI method to expand the scope and coverage of traditional
dental health care, which is the major contribution made by the
proposed iHome smart dental Health-IoT system. Patients can
choose medical resources online and receive an appointment for
medical treatment via self-service smart dental screening.
The rest parts of this paper are organized as follows.
Section II discusses smart In-home dentist system, followed
by Section III analyzing the intelligent dental diagnosis, intro-
ducing the algorithm ï¬‚ow and test results. Section IV presents
the integrated system and hardware prototype, and reports the
application results, and a conclusion is given in Section V
ï¬nally.
II. S MART IN-HOME DENTIST SYSTEM
The occurrence of dental disease can be well predictable. For
example, each stage from dental plaque, calculus to dental caries
and periodontal disease shows different characteristics and so-
lutions, thereby making it possible to monitor the whole body
and reduce the risk of sudden diseases effectively. It can reduce
pain, save time and reduce the cost of money for patients. How-
ever, most consumers lack the correct tooth awareness, thereby
making the timely treatment for tooth disease difï¬cult. More-
over, there is a relative shortage of dental resources in hospitals.
These main contradictions are explained in the following aspects
in details:
r First, there are a lot of patients with dental diseases, but
fewer people pay attention to the teeth. Many individ-
uals pay for treatment only when they have teeth with
problems, which may cause irreversible damage to the
long-term development of children.
r Second, the cost of dental treatment is relatively high.
r Third, dental disease, due to the characteristics of elective
treatment, is difï¬cult to get timely treatment.
Based on what is discussed above, a promising trend in health-
care is to move routine medical checks and other healthcare ser-
vices from hospital (Hospital-Centric) to the home environment
(Home-centric) [15], through which, the patients can get seam-
less health care at any time in a comfortable home environment.
Even more, it can ensure that the overall iHome dental health-
care system including three partspersonalized services, dental
services and intelligent and interactive service could be opti-
mized to a large extent. Based on this platform, the closed', 'cation of dental diseases

TABLE I: Comparison of HRV feature estimation
A. Feature Estimation
The feature values predicted by our model are compared
against HeartPy predictions. To the best of our knowledge,
HeartPy is the most prominent and trusted public library to
provide HRV features from PPG signals. For the prediction
of all the HRV features, we use a 4-layer TCN to get the
input representation from the PPG signal that, in turn is
passed through 2 Fully Connected (FC) layers with hidden
sizes of 64 to get the output prediction. We train the model
using a learning rate of 5e-05 and a dropout value of 0.3.
We evaluate the performance of our model against HeartPy
using mean absolute error (MAE) with the estimates from the
Biopac sensor data considered the ground truth. We report
these results in Table I. Among all the parameters predicted,
we observe that for heart rate alone, HeartPy outperforms our
proposed framework. For the remaining HRV parameters, our
model performs better than HeartPy prediction. On average,
the improvement in HRV parameter estimation compared to
HeartPy is around 26%.
To highlight the significance of fine-tuning, we predicted
HRV features from the earbud PPG without any pre-training
step. The results of this experiment are shown in Table I.
With the exception of HR, we observe that transfer learning
improves performance for all the HRV features.
Throughout all our experiments, we consistently observed
relatively poorer performance in average HR estimation using
our proposed framework. This may be related to the fact that
heart rate estimation is fundamentally different from HRV
parameter estimation. While HRV estimation depends on the
specific sequence of individual peaks, HR is more of an
average of the distances between peaks. The framework was
not optimized for this averaging task and the removal of
outliers that would adversely affect the average. Nevertheless,
heart rate is an important feature and integrating its estimation
in a unified framework can be the focus of future work.
B. Stress detection
In this section, we report the performance of stress clas-
sification using HRV parameters obtained from HeartPy and
our model, respectively. The PPG window from a subject is
labeled as stress if it is sampled from the task that induces
stress, which in our case are Dot-tracking, Speech-Preparation,
Speech, and Exciting Music tasks (see Figure 1 for more
details), PPG windows from the remaining tasks are labeled

B. Downstream HRV parameters estimation
The pre-trained TCN model from the previous step is fine-
tuned to predict different HRV-based features from the earbud
PPG signal. The trained TCN network is transferred here, with
only the final layer changed to predict various HRV parameters
instead of peaks. In our current work, we considered five
different features, including the mean heart rate (HR) and
the following HRV features: root mean square of successive
differences between normal heartbeats (RMSSD), proportion
of the number of pairs of successive NN (R-R) intervals
that differ by more than 50 ms (pNN50), standard deviation
of normal to normal R-R intervals (SDNN), and normalized
high frequency power (HFnorm). We fine-tuned the pre-trained
model separately for each of these HRV parameters. As we
considered features that are continuous values, this required
changing only the loss function from the pre-trained model.
While our framework can be extended to predict any HRV-
based parameter, we chose these five as they were the most
predictive of stress in our prior empirical analysis [16]. An
overview of our framework is shown in Figure 2.
IV. R ESULTS
Using the framework described in the previous section, we
initially trained the upstream model to predict the peaks of the
input Biopac signal. This upstream model was subsequently
fine-tuned on earbud PPG signal to predict different features
separately: HR, RMSSD, pNN50, SDNN, and HFnorm. Ul-
timately, using these features, we predict whether the subject
is feeling stress or not for each PPG signal window. We con-
ducted all our analysis using Leave-One-Subject-Out Cross-
Validation (LOSOXV), where the data from a single subject
was held out for testing while the model was trained on the
remaining subjects. This process was repeated until all subjects
had been tested.

The increase/decrease in the performance of stress detection
by replacing HeartPy predictions with our model predictions
gives us a better understanding of how to evaluate these

II. We also experimented with stress detection by using all
the features as predicted by our framework. However, given
the prominent role of HR in estimating stress, this modelâ€™s
performance was relatively lower compared to ones reported
here. We evaluate the performance of stress detection using
Accuracy, Specificity, and Sensitivity. From this table, we can
see that using the HRV parameter predicted by our framework,
instead of the HeartPy prediction, has resulted in at least a 5%
improvement in all evaluation metrics for all HRV features.
This demonstrates the impact of our proposed framework on
feature extraction in stress classification.
V. C ONCLUSION
Estimating HRV features using wearable sensors is critical
for stress management solutions. In our current work, we take
an initial step toward using earbud PPG signals to estimate
HRV features, employing a framework based on transfer
learning and TCN architecture. We have demonstrated that
our framework estimates these features more accurately than
the existing open-source library, HeartPy. Subsequently, we
observed that using our modelâ€™s predicted HRV features in
place of HeartPy for stress detection results in improved
performance. Encouraged by these initial results, we plan to
conduct our study on a larger and more diverse set of subjects
to corroborate our findings.

[' device placed
on the finger that sampled PPG at 1000Hz. For our current
work, we will only focus on the PPG signal.
The study involved each subject completing a set of validated
tasks that induced stress, interspersed with tasks that help them
relax. The study started with a baseline-recording for 5 min-
utes where the subject sat idle. The subject then performed a
multiple object tracking task for 3 minutes (cognitive stressor),
followed by 3 minutes of progressive muscle relaxation. The
subject then underwent a â€œSpeechâ€ task; a research assistant,
playing the role of an interviewer, asked the subject to speak
on a challenging and personal topic (social stressor). The
subject was then given 3 minute time to prepare for the speech,
after which they entered a room consisting of evaluators. The
research assistant purposefully delayed the start of the speech
to increase the stress. After a 2-minute delay, the subject was
asked to leave without completing the task. Subsequently, the
subject listened to relaxing music for 4 minutes, followed
by exciting music. Finally, the subject was asked to rest and
recover. Between each task, the subject was given at least a
2-minute break to offset the effect of the previous task and
prepare for the next task. In Figure 1, we show the timeline
of the tasks and how the heart rate varies during these tasks
for a sample subject.
B. PPG signal-denoising
The raw PPG signals captured from the Earbud and Biopac
were first filtered by a third-order Butterworth bandpass filter
with cut-off frequencies set to 0.6-4 Hz. The filtered PPG
signal was then sliced into 30-second sliding windows with a
20-second overlap for the prediction of HRV parameters and
stress detection. Even after passing the PPG signal through a
bandpass filter, the signal still contained motion artifacts, shifts
in baseline wandering, and other high-frequency noises. To
address this, we estimated the quality of the PPG signal using
the PQR signal quality index [8]. In this method, we calculated
P/Q/R indexes representing the signal quality for each window
of PPG signal. The â€œPâ€ index indicated the degree of high-
frequency noise in the signal, calculated using the change in
the number of extremum points after bandpass filtering. The
â€œQâ€ index indicated the amount of baseline wandering, cal-
culated using the signalâ€™s maximum and minimum amplitude.
The â€Râ€ index represented the frequency of motion artifacts
by calculating the dispersion of peak and valley points. Using
these three indexes, the method calculated rSQI (relative signal
quality index) to compare the quality of the PPG signal against
a clean reference signal. In our case, we used the signal
collected from the baseline-recording as a reference signal.
The PPG-windowed signals whose rSQI â‰¥ 0, indicating the
signal was comparable or better in quality than the reference
signal, were considered for subsequent analysis. The PPG-
windowed signals with rSQI < 0 are removed. Finally, we
standardized the PPG signals of each subject to remove any
subject-dependent information. Due to poor contact on one
or more of the earbuds or Biopac finger sensor resulting in
signals too noisy to be usable, we excluded PPG data from
four subjects.

EXTRACTING HRV FEATURES

PPG signal, we design a framework based on transfer learning
and using Temporal convolution network (TCN) [9]. The
framework consists of two steps: In the first step we pre-train
a TCN', ' detection in

To extract HRV based features from the denoised earbud

and using Temporal convolution network (TCN) [9]. The
framework consists of two steps: In the first step we pre-train
a TCN', ' for subsequent analysis. The PPG-
windowed signals with rSQI < 0 are removed. Finally, we

III. T RANSFER LEARNING BASED FRAMEWORK FOR
EXTRACTING HRV FEATURES
To extract HRV based features from the denoised earbud
PPG signal, we design a framework based on transfer learning
and using Temporal convolution network (TCN) [9]. The
framework consists of two steps: In the first step we pre-train
a TCN model on Biopac PPG to detect position of peaks.
For the latter step, we use this pre-trained TCN model for the
downstream task of predicting different HRV parameters. We
explain these steps in detail below.
A. Pre-training using Biopac PPG
The growing availability of ubiquitous and unobtrusive
wearable devices has made the collection of continuous sensor
data more convenient and accessible than ever. However,
labeling this data requires significant effort and time. As a
result, the amount of labeled sensor data available is minimal
in comparison to the unlabeled data that can be collected. We
first pre-train a model with the reference PPG signals captured
from the Biopac finger sensor to detect peak positions of this
input signal. We chose this task because all the HRV-related
features extracted from the PPG signal are derived from the
position of peaks. The primary motivation for pre-training a
model on the PPG data is to increase data efficiency given the
relative scarcity of available earbud PPG data, and to acquaint
the model with the PPG signal. We use HeartPy [10], [11], an
open-source python library for extracting ground truth peak
positions. The idea of initiating models on hand-designed tasks
before deploying them for different downstream purposes is
not uncommon. In computer vision, models are often pre-
trained with image segmentation tasks [12], [13] and in natural
language processing to generate language models like BERT
[14] and GPT-3 [15], models are pre-trained with tasks of pre-
dicting of next word in a sentence. We used TCN as our choice
of model, while there are several choices for modeling contin-
uous time-series data TCNs are a type of convolution network
that convolve over a time-domain by combining properties of
Convolutional Neural Networks (CNN) and Recurrent Neural
Networks (RNN). They overcome the problem of exploding
and vanishing gradients by using causal dilated convolution

A. Feature Estimation
The feature values predicted by our model are compared
against HeartPy predictions. To the best of our knowledge,
HeartPy is the most prominent and trusted public library to
provide HRV features from PPG signals. For the prediction
of all the HRV features, we use a 4-layer TCN to get the
input representation from the PPG signal that, in turn is
passed through 2 Fully Connected (FC) layers with hidden
sizes of 64 to get the output prediction. We train the model
using a learning rate of 5e-05 and a dropout value of 0.3.
We evaluate the performance of our model against HeartPy
using mean absolute error (MAE) with the estimates from the
Biopac sensor data considered the ground truth. We report
these results in Table I. Among all the parameters predicted,
we observe that for heart rate alone, HeartPy outperforms our
proposed framework. For the remaining HRV parameters, our
model performs better than HeartPy prediction. On average,
the improvement in HRV parameter estimation compared to
HeartPy is around 26%.
To highlight the significance of fine-tuning, we predicted
HRV features from the earbud PPG without any pre-training
step. The results of this experiment are shown in Table I.
With the exception of HR, we observe that transfer learning
improves performance for all the HRV features.
Throughout all our experiments, we consistently observed
relatively poorer performance in average HR estimation using
our proposed framework. This may be related to the fact that

parameter estimation. While HRV estimation depends on the

recover. Between each task, the subject was given at least a
2-minute break to offset the effect of the previous task and
prepare for the next task. In Figure 1, we show the timeline
of the tasks and how the heart rate varies during these tasks
for a sample subject.
B. PPG signal-denoising
The raw PPG signals captured from the Earbud and Biopac
were first filtered by a third-order Butterworth bandpass filter
with cut-off frequencies set to 0.6-4 Hz. The filtered PPG
signal was then sliced into 30-second sliding windows with a
20-second overlap for the prediction of HRV parameters and
stress detection. Even after passing the PPG signal through a
bandpass filter, the signal still contained motion artifacts, shifts
in baseline wandering, and other high-frequency noises. To
address this, we estimated the quality of the PPG signal using
the PQR signal quality index [8]. In this method, we calculated
P/Q/R indexes representing the signal quality for each window
of PPG signal. The â€œPâ€ index indicated the degree of high-
frequency noise in the signal, calculated using the change in
the number of extremum points after bandpass filtering. The
â€œQâ€ index indicated the amount of baseline wandering, cal-
culated using the signalâ€™s maximum and minimum amplitude.
The â€Râ€ index represented the frequency of motion artifacts
by calculating the dispersion of peak and valley points. Using
these three indexes, the method calculated rSQI (relative signal
quality index) to compare the quality of the PPG signal against
a clean reference signal. In our case, we used the signal
collected from the baseline-recording as a reference signal.
The PPG-windowed signals whose rSQI â‰¥ 0, indicating the
signal was comparable or better in quality than the reference
signal, were considered for subsequent analysis. The PPG-
windowed signals with rSQI < 0 are removed. Finally, we
standardized the PPG signals of each subject to remove any
subject-dependent information. Due to poor contact on one
or more of the earbuds or Biopac finger sensor resulting in
signals too noisy to be usable, we excluded PPG data from
four subjects.

PPG signal, we design a framework based on transfer learning
and using Temporal convolution network (TCN) [9]. The
framework consists of two steps: In the first step we pre-train

TABLE II: Stress detection results when one of the HeartPy
HRV features is replaced with our model predictions
as no-stress. As a first step, we classify stress using all the
HRV features that the HeartPy library outputs from a window
of PPG signal, using a random forest classifier developed
in our previous work. In the next step, we replace one of
the HeartPyâ€™s RMSSD, pNN50, SDNN, HFnorm with our

The increase/decrease in the performance of stress detection
by replacing HeartPy predictions with our model predictions
gives us a better understanding of how to evaluate these

II. We also experimented with stress detection by using all
the features as predicted by our framework. However, given
the prominent role of HR in estimating stress, this modelâ€™s
performance was relatively lower compared to ones reported
here. We evaluate the performance of stress detection using
Accuracy, Specificity, and Sensitivity. From this table, we can
see that using the HRV parameter predicted by our framework,
instead of the HeartPy prediction, has resulted in at least a 5%
improvement in all evaluation metrics for all HRV features.
This demonstrates the impact of our proposed framework on
feature extraction in stress classification.
V. C ONCLUSION
Estimating HRV features using wearable sensors is critical
for stress management solutions. In our current work, we take
an initial step toward using earbud PPG signals to estimate
HRV features, employing a framework based on transfer
learning and TCN architecture. We have demonstrated that
our framework estimates these features more accurately than
the existing open-source library, HeartPy. Subsequently, we
observed that using our modelâ€™s predicted HRV features in
place of HeartPy for stress detection results in improved
performance. Encouraged by these initial results, we plan to
conduct our study on a larger and more diverse set of subjects
to corroborate our findings.

III. T RANSFER LEARNING BASED FRAMEWORK FOR
EXTRACTING HRV FEATURES
To extract HRV based features from the denoised earbud
PPG signal, we design a framework based on transfer learning
and using Temporal convolution network (TCN) [9]. The
framework consists of two steps: In the first step we pre-train
a TCN model on Biopac PPG to detect position of peaks.
For the latter step, we use this pre-trained TCN model for the
downstream task of predicting different HRV parameters. We
explain these steps in detail below.
A. Pre-training using Biopac PPG
The growing availability of ubiquitous and unobtrusive
wearable devices has made the collection of continuous sensor
data more convenient and accessible than ever. However,
labeling this data requires significant effort and time. As a
result, the amount of labeled sensor data available is minimal
in comparison to the unlabeled data that can be collected. We
first pre-train a model with the reference PPG signals captured
from the Biopac finger sensor to detect peak positions of this
input signal. We chose this task because all the HRV-related
features extracted from the PPG signal are derived from the
position of peaks. The primary motivation for pre-training a
model on the PPG data is to increase data efficiency given the
relative scarcity of available earbud PPG data, and to acquaint
the model with the PPG signal. We use HeartPy [10], [11], an
open-source python library for extracting ground truth peak
positions. The idea of initiating models on hand-designed tasks
before deploying them for different downstream purposes is
not uncommon. In computer vision, models are often pre-
trained with image segmentation tasks [12], [13] and in natural
language processing to generate language models like BERT
[14] and GPT-3 [15], models are pre-trained with tasks of pre-
dicting of next word in a sentence. We used TCN as our choice
of model, while there are several choices for modeling contin-
uous time-series data TCNs are a type of convolution network
that convolve over a time-domain by combining properties of
Convolutional Neural Networks (CNN) and Recurrent Neural
Networks (RNN). They overcome the problem of exploding
and vanishing gradients by using causal dilated convolution

B. Downstream HRV parameters estimation
The pre-trained TCN model from the previous step is fine-
tuned', ' device placed
on the finger that sampled PPG at 1000Hz. For our current
work, we will only focus on the PPG signal.
The study involved each subject completing a set of validated
tasks that induced stress, interspersed with tasks that help them
relax. The study started with a baseline-recording for 5 min-
utes where the subject sat idle. The subject then performed a
multiple object tracking task for 3 minutes (cognitive stressor),
followed by 3 minutes of progressive muscle relaxation. The
subject then underwent a â€œSpeechâ€ task; a research assistant,
playing the role of an interviewer, asked the subject to speak
on a challenging and personal topic (social stressor). The
subject was then given 3 minute time to prepare for the speech,
after which they entered a room consisting of evaluators. The
research assistant purposefully delayed the start of the speech
to increase the stress. After a 2-minute delay, the subject was
asked to leave without completing the task. Subsequently, the
subject listened to relaxing music for 4 minutes, followed
by exciting music. Finally, the subject was asked to rest and
recover. Between each task, the subject was given at least a
2-minute break to offset the effect of the previous task and
prepare for the next task. In Figure 1, we show the timeline
of the tasks and how the heart rate varies during these tasks
for a sample subject.
B. PPG signal-denoising
The raw PPG signals captured from the Earbud and Biopac
were first filtered by a third-order Butterworth bandpass filter
with cut-off frequencies set to 0.6-4 Hz. The filtered PPG
signal was then sliced into 30-second sliding windows with a
20-second overlap for the prediction of HRV parameters and
stress detection. Even after passing the PPG signal through a
bandpass filter, the signal still contained motion artifacts, shifts
in baseline wandering, and other high-frequency noises. To
address this, we estimated the quality of the PPG signal using
the PQR signal quality index [8]. In this method, we calculated
P/Q/R indexes representing the signal quality for each window
of PPG signal. The â€œPâ€ index indicated the degree of high-
frequency noise in the signal, calculated using the change in
the number of extremum points after bandpass filtering. The
â€œQâ€ index indicated the amount of baseline wandering, cal-
culated using the signalâ€™s maximum and minimum amplitude.
The â€Râ€ index represented the frequency of motion artifacts
by calculating the dispersion of peak and valley points. Using
these three indexes, the method calculated rSQI (relative signal
quality index) to compare the quality of the PPG signal against
a clean reference signal. In our case, we used the signal
collected from the baseline-recording as a reference signal.
The PPG-windowed signals whose rSQI â‰¥ 0, indicating the
signal was comparable or better in quality than the reference
signal, were considered for subsequent analysis. The PPG-
windowed signals with rSQI < 0 are removed. Finally, we
standardized the PPG signals of each subject to remove any
subject-dependent information. Due to poor contact on one
or more of the earbuds or Biopac finger sensor resulting in
signals too noisy to be usable, we excluded PPG data from
four subjects.
III. T RANSFER LEARNING BASED FRAMEWORK FOR
EXTRACTING HRV FEATURES
To extract HRV based features from the denoised earbud
PPG signal, we design a framework based on transfer learning
and using Temporal convolution network (TCN) [9]. The
framework consists of two steps: In the first step we pre-train
a TCN', 'Speech-PrepSpeech

Fig. 2: Transfer learning framework to predict HRV features
instead of standard convolutions and using a receptive field
that is exponential in network depth.
B. Downstream HRV parameters estimation
The pre-trained TCN model from the previous step is fine-
tuned to predict different HRV-based features from the earbud
PPG signal. The trained TCN network is transferred here, with
only the final layer changed to predict various HRV parameters
instead of peaks. In our current work, we considered five
different features, including the mean heart rate (HR) and
the following HRV features: root mean square of successive
differences between normal heartbeats (RMSSD), proportion
of the number of pairs of successive NN (R-R) intervals
that differ by more than 50 ms (pNN50), standard deviation
of normal to normal R-R intervals (SDNN), and normalized
high frequency power (HFnorm). We fine-tuned the pre-trained
model separately for each of these HRV parameters. As we
considered features that are continuous values, this required
changing only the loss function from the pre-trained model.
While our framework can be extended to predict any HRV-
based parameter, we chose these five as they were the most
predictive of stress in our prior empirical analysis [16]. An
overview of our framework is shown in Figure 2.
IV. R ESULTS
Using the framework described in the previous section, we
initially trained the upstream model to predict the peaks of the
input Biopac signal. This upstream model was subsequently
fine-tuned on earbud PPG signal to predict different features
separately: HR, RMSSD, pNN50, SDNN, and HFnorm. Ul-
timately, using these features, we predict whether the subject
is feeling stress or not for each PPG signal window. We con-
ducted all our analysis using Leave-One-Subject-Out Cross-
Validation (LOSOXV), where the data from a single subject
was held out for testing while the model was trained on the
remaining subjects. This process was repeated until all subjects
had been tested.

Abstractâ€”Unmanaged stress can lead to serious physiological
and mental health issues, making it important to monitor stress
continuously using wearable sensors. In this work, we investigate
the use of photoplethysmography (PPG) sensors in consumer-
grade earbud devices to classify periods of stress. We propose a
framework that initially employs deep learning to predict heart
rate variability (HRV) features from the relatively noisy earbud
PPG signal. Subsequently, we transfer this knowledge and use
these features for the downstream task of stress classification.
The proposed framework outperforms an existing state-of-the-
art library on HRV feature extraction, resulting in at least 5%
improvement in accuracy, sensitivity, and specificity for stress
detection.
Index Termsâ€”Photoplethysmography (PPG), heart rate vari-
ability (HRV), transfer learning, temporal convolutional networks
(TCN)
I. I NTRODUCTION
Stress is the bodyâ€™s physical and emotional reaction in
response to internal or external stressors. It is ubiquitous, with
at least 1 in 2 Americans stressed during the day and around
1 million workers missing work due to stress according to
the American Institute of Stress and American Psychological
Association [1]. These numbers are higher than ever after
the COVID-19 pandemic, inflation, and global uncertainty.
Beyond immediate symptoms such as sleep deprivation or
headaches, unchecked stress can lead to severe cardiovascular
or neurological illness. Many individuals can be unaware of the
timing and extent of their stress episodes, making it challeng-
ing to utilize interventions such as meditation and mindfulness
to alleviate stress. The efficiency of any stress management
solution would be greatly improved by continuous and real-
time detection of stress episodes over the course of each day.
Digital health solutions, particularly wearable devices, offer
a convenient and low-cost avenue for detecting stress episodes.
Several studies have shown that the sensor modalities in
wearable devices are capable of automatically detecting stress.
In earlier works, built-in smartphone accelerometer sensors
were used to characterize the subjectâ€™s behavior which is
subsequently used to classify stress levels [2], [3], though this
can be prone to false positives and may not be discerning
enough to specifically detect stress. In one previous work,
a smartphone and smartwatch were used to capture electro-
dermal activity (EDA) to passively detect stress in field with
75% accuracy [4]. Another study employed a custom-made
wearable chest band for passive ECG sensing and detected
stress with a 0.71 F1-score [5]. There has also been an
approach that combined a commodity chestband to capture
ECG and a commodity wristband called Empatica for EDA
sensor to detect stress with 0.94 F1-score [6]. Stress detection
using head-worn devices is relatively less common. Another
recent work demonstrated a head-neck device capable of
simultaneously capturing ECG and EEG, which can detect
â€™stressedâ€™ states with 75.8% accuracy [7]. While these results
show promise for the use of wearable devices in']

recover. Between each task, the subject was given at least a
2-minute break to offset the effect of the previous task and

of the tasks and how the heart rate varies during these tasks

B. PPG signal-denoising
The raw PPG signals captured from the Earbud and Biopac
were first filtered by a third-order Butterworth bandpass filter
with cut-off frequencies set to 0.6-4 Hz. The filtered PPG
signal was then sliced into 30-second sliding windows with a
20-second overlap for the prediction of HRV parameters and
stress detection. Even after passing the PPG signal through a
bandpass filter, the signal still contained motion artifacts, shifts
in baseline wandering, and other high-frequency noises. To
address this, we estimated the quality of the PPG signal using
the PQR signal quality index [8]. In this method, we calculated
P/Q/R indexes representing the signal quality for each window
of PPG signal. The â€œPâ€ index indicated the degree of high-
frequency noise in the signal, calculated using the change in
the number of extremum points after bandpass filtering. The
â€œQâ€ index indicated the amount of baseline wandering, cal-
culated using the signalâ€™s maximum and minimum amplitude.
The â€Râ€ index represented the frequency of motion artifacts
by calculating the dispersion of peak and valley points. Using
these three indexes, the method calculated rSQI (relative signal
quality index) to compare the quality of the PPG signal against
a clean reference signal. In our case, we used the signal
collected from the baseline-recording as a reference signal.
The PPG-windowed signals whose rSQI â‰¥ 0, indicating the
signal was comparable or better in quality than the reference
signal, were considered for subsequent analysis. The PPG-
windowed signals with rSQI < 0 are removed. Finally, we
standardized the PPG signals of each subject to remove any
subject-dependent information. Due to poor contact on one
or more of the earbuds or Biopac finger sensor resulting in
signals too noisy to be usable, we excluded PPG data from
four subjects.

The increase/decrease in the performance of stress detection
by replacing HeartPy predictions with our model predictions
gives us a better understanding of how to evaluate these
parameters. The results of this experiment are shown in Table
II. We also experimented with stress detection by using all
the features as predicted by our framework. However, given
the prominent role of HR in estimating stress, this modelâ€™s
performance was relatively lower compared to ones reported
here. We evaluate the performance of stress detection using
Accuracy, Specificity, and Sensitivity. From this table, we can
see that using the HRV parameter predicted by our framework,
instead of the HeartPy prediction, has resulted in at least a 5%
improvement in all evaluation metrics for all HRV features.
This demonstrates the impact of our proposed framework on
feature extraction in stress classification.
V. C ONCLUSION
Estimating HRV features using wearable sensors is critical
for stress management solutions. In our current work, we take
an initial step toward using earbud PPG signals to estimate
HRV features, employing a framework based on transfer
learning and TCN architecture. We have demonstrated that
our framework estimates these features more accurately than
the existing open-source library, HeartPy. Subsequently, we
observed that using our modelâ€™s predicted HRV features in
place of HeartPy for stress detection results in improved
performance. Encouraged by these initial results, we plan to
conduct our study on a larger and more diverse set of subjects
to corroborate our findings.

smartphones, is that these devices are expensive, invasive
for everyday use, and typically serve only a single purpose.
Earbuds, as a wearable, have been gaining traction and in-
creasingly adopted. From a signal processing perspective, they
offer certain advantages over smartwatches. These include
lower susceptibility to motion, a relatively fixed orientation,
and their more consistent wear pattern among users. Despite
these advantages, earbuds are more prone to noise interference
than the more stable but less conveniently wearable options
like chest bands or finger sensors. Therefore, earbuds could
greatly benefit from the application of more sophisticated
signal processing and machine learning approaches. The main
contribution of our work was designing a transfer-learning
based framework for heart rate variability (HRV) feature
extraction from noisy earbud PPG signal. We also show the
stress detection performance using our proposed framework on
human subjects with reference sensors undergoing validated
stressor tasks.

A. Study Protocol
This was an experimental study approved by the Institu-

recruited for this study, and they were all healthy individuals
from the 19-22 age group to ensure that the stress responses
induced are minimally affected by other confounders and
comorbidities. Throughout the study, subjects wore earbuds

body temperature (CBT) at 1Hz. The reference ground truth
PPG from subjects was captured using a Biopac device placed
on the finger that sampled PPG at 1000Hz. For our current
work, we will only focus on the PPG signal.

III. T RANSFER LEARNING BASED FRAMEWORK FOR
EXTRACTING HRV FEATURES
To extract HRV based features from the denoised earbud
PPG signal, we design a framework based on transfer learning
and using Temporal convolution network (TCN) [9]. The
framework consists of two steps: In the first step we pre-train
a TCN model on Biopac PPG to detect position of peaks.
For the latter step, we use this pre-trained TCN model for the
downstream task of predicting different HRV parameters. We
explain these steps in detail below.
A. Pre-training using Biopac PPG
The growing availability of ubiquitous and unobtrusive
wearable devices has made the collection of continuous sensor
data more convenient and accessible than ever. However,
labeling this data requires significant effort and time. As a
result, the amount of labeled sensor data available is minimal
in comparison to the unlabeled data that can be collected. We
first pre-train a model with the reference PPG signals captured
from the Biopac finger sensor to detect peak positions of this
input signal. We chose this task because all the HRV-related
features extracted from the PPG signal are derived from the
position of peaks. The primary motivation for pre-training a
model on the PPG data is to increase data efficiency given the
relative scarcity of available earbud PPG data, and to acquaint
the model with the PPG signal. We use HeartPy [10], [11], an
open-source python library for extracting ground truth peak
positions. The idea of initiating models on hand-designed tasks
before deploying them for different downstream purposes is
not uncommon. In computer vision, models are often pre-
trained with image segmentation tasks [12], [13] and in natural
language processing to generate language models like BERT
[14] and GPT-3 [15], models are pre-trained with tasks of pre-
dicting of next word in a sentence. We used TCN as our choice
of model, while there are several choices for modeling contin-
uous time-series data TCNs are a type of convolution network
that convolve over a time-domain by combining properties of
Convolutional Neural Networks (CNN) and Recurrent Neural
Networks (RNN). They overcome the problem of exploding
and vanishing gradients by using causal dilated convolution

B. Downstream HRV parameters estimation
The pre-trained TCN model from the previous step is fine-
tuned to predict different HRV-based features from the earbud
PPG signal. The trained TCN network is transferred here, with
only the final layer changed to predict various HRV parameters
instead of peaks. In our current work, we considered five
different features, including the mean heart rate (HR) and
the following HRV features: root mean square of successive
differences between normal heartbeats (RMSSD), proportion
of the number of pairs of successive NN (R-R) intervals
that differ by more than 50 ms (pNN50), standard deviation
of normal to normal R-R intervals (SDNN), and normalized
high frequency power (HFnorm). We fine-tuned the pre-trained
model separately for each of these HRV parameters. As we
considered features that are continuous values, this required
changing only the loss function from the pre-trained model.
While our framework can be extended to predict any HRV-
based parameter, we chose these five as they were the most
predictive of stress in our prior empirical analysis [16]. An
overview of our framework is shown in Figure 2.
IV. R ESULTS
Using the framework described in the previous section, we
initially trained the upstream model to predict the peaks of the
input Biopac signal. This upstream model was subsequently
fine-tuned on earbud PPG signal to predict different features
separately: HR, RMSSD, pNN50, SDNN, and HFnorm. Ul-
timately, using these features, we predict whether the subject
is feeling stress or not for each PPG signal window. We con-
ducted all our analysis using Leave-One-Subject-Out Cross-
Validation (LOSOXV), where the data from a single subject
was held out for testing while the model was trained on the
remaining subjects. This process was repeated until all subjects
had been tested.

V. C ONCLUSION
Estimating HRV features using wearable sensors is critical
for stress management solutions. In our current work, we take
an initial step toward using earbud PPG signals to estimate
HRV features, employing a framework based on transfer
learning and TCN architecture. We have demonstrated that
our framework estimates these features more accurately than
the existing open-source library, HeartPy. Subsequently, we
observed that using our modelâ€™s predicted HRV features in
place of HeartPy for stress detection results in improved
performance. Encouraged by these initial results, we plan to
conduct our study on a larger and more diverse set of subjects
to corroborate our findings.

Abstractâ€”Unmanaged stress can lead to serious physiological
and mental health issues, making it important to monitor stress
continuously using wearable sensors. In this work, we investigate
the use of photoplethysmography (PPG) sensors in consumer-
grade earbud devices to classify periods of stress. We propose a
framework that initially employs deep learning to predict heart
rate variability (HRV) features from the relatively noisy earbud
PPG signal. Subsequently, we transfer this knowledge and use
these features for the downstream task of stress classification.
The proposed framework outperforms an existing state-of-the-
art library on HRV feature extraction, resulting in at least 5%
improvement in accuracy, sensitivity, and specificity for stress
detection.
Index Termsâ€”Photoplethysmography (PPG), heart rate vari-
ability (HRV), transfer learning, temporal convolutional networks
(TCN)
I. I NTRODUCTION
Stress is the bodyâ€™s physical and emotional reaction in
response to internal or external stressors. It is ubiquitous, with
at least 1 in 2 Americans stressed during the day and around
1 million workers missing work due to stress according to
the American Institute of Stress and American Psychological
Association [1]. These numbers are higher than ever after
the COVID-19 pandemic, inflation, and global uncertainty.
Beyond immediate symptoms such as sleep deprivation or
headaches, unchecked stress can lead to severe cardiovascular
or neurological illness. Many individuals can be unaware of the
timing and extent of their stress episodes, making it challeng-
ing to utilize interventions such as meditation and mindfulness
to alleviate stress. The efficiency of any stress management
solution would be greatly improved by continuous and real-
time detection of stress episodes over the course of each day.
Digital health solutions, particularly wearable devices, offer
a convenient and low-cost avenue for detecting stress episodes.
Several studies have shown that the sensor modalities in
wearable devices are capable of automatically detecting stress.
In earlier works, built-in smartphone accelerometer sensors
were used to characterize the subjectâ€™s behavior which is
subsequently used to classify stress levels [2], [3], though this
can be prone to false positives and may not be discerning
enough to specifically detect stress. In one previous work,
a smartphone and smartwatch were used to capture electro-
dermal activity (EDA) to passively detect stress in field with
75% accuracy [4]. Another study employed a custom-made
wearable chest band for passive ECG sensing and detected
stress with a 0.71 F1-score [5]. There has also been an
approach that combined a commodity chestband to capture
ECG and a commodity wristband called Empatica for EDA
sensor to detect stress with 0.94 F1-score [6]. Stress detection
using head-worn devices is relatively less common. Another
recent work demonstrated a head-neck device capable of
simultaneously capturing ECG and EEG, which can detect
â€™stressedâ€™ states with 75.8% accuracy [7]. While these results
show promise for the use of wearable devices in']

A. Feature Estimation
The feature values predicted by our model are compared
against HeartPy predictions. To the best of our knowledge,
HeartPy is the most prominent and trusted public library to
provide HRV features from PPG signals. For the prediction
of all the HRV features, we use a 4-layer TCN to get the
input representation from the PPG signal that, in turn is
passed through 2 Fully Connected (FC) layers with hidden
sizes of 64 to get the output prediction. We train the model
using a learning rate of 5e-05 and a dropout value of 0.3.
We evaluate the performance of our model against HeartPy
using mean absolute error (MAE) with the estimates from the
Biopac sensor data considered the ground truth. We report
these results in Table I. Among all the parameters predicted,
we observe that for heart rate alone, HeartPy outperforms our
proposed framework. For the remaining HRV parameters, our
model performs better than HeartPy prediction. On average,
the improvement in HRV parameter estimation compared to
HeartPy is around 26%.
To highlight the significance of fine-tuning, we predicted
HRV features from the earbud PPG without any pre-training
step. The results of this experiment are shown in Table I.
With the exception of HR, we observe that transfer learning
improves performance for all the HRV features.
Throughout all our experiments, we consistently observed
relatively poorer performance in average HR estimation using
our proposed framework. This may be related to the fact that
heart rate estimation is fundamentally different from HRV
parameter estimation. While HRV estimation depends on the
specific sequence of individual peaks, HR is more of an
average of the distances between peaks. The framework was
not optimized for this averaging task and the removal of
outliers that would adversely affect the average. Nevertheless,
heart rate is an important feature and integrating its estimation
in a unified framework can be the focus of future work.
B. Stress detection
In this section, we report the performance of stress clas-
sification using HRV parameters obtained from HeartPy and
our model, respectively. The PPG window from a subject is
labeled as stress if it is sampled from the task that induces
stress, which in our case are Dot-tracking, Speech-Preparation,
Speech, and Exciting Music tasks (see Figure 1 for more
details), PPG windows from the remaining tasks are labeled

III. T RANSFER LEARNING BASED FRAMEWORK FOR
EXTRACTING HRV FEATURES
To extract HRV based features from the denoised earbud
PPG signal, we design a framework based on transfer learning
and using Temporal convolution network (TCN) [9]. The
framework consists of two steps: In the first step we pre-train
a TCN model on Biopac PPG to detect position of peaks.
For the latter step, we use this pre-trained TCN model for the
downstream task of predicting different HRV parameters. We
explain these steps in detail below.
A. Pre-training using Biopac PPG
The growing availability of ubiquitous and unobtrusive
wearable devices has made the collection of continuous sensor
data more convenient and accessible than ever. However,
labeling this data requires significant effort and time. As a
result, the amount of labeled sensor data available is minimal
in comparison to the unlabeled data that can be collected. We
first pre-train a model with the reference PPG signals captured
from the Biopac finger sensor to detect peak positions of this
input signal. We chose this task because all the HRV-related
features extracted from the PPG signal are derived from the
position of peaks. The primary motivation for pre-training a
model on the PPG data is to increase data efficiency given the
relative scarcity of available earbud PPG data, and to acquaint
the model with the PPG signal. We use HeartPy [10], [11], an
open-source python library for extracting ground truth peak
positions. The idea of initiating models on hand-designed tasks
before deploying them for different downstream purposes is
not uncommon. In computer vision, models are often pre-
trained with image segmentation tasks [12], [13] and in natural
language processing to generate language models like BERT
[14] and GPT-3 [15], models are pre-trained with tasks of pre-
dicting of next word in a sentence. We used TCN as our choice
of model, while there are several choices for modeling contin-
uous time-series data TCNs are a type of convolution network
that convolve over a time-domain by combining properties of
Convolutional Neural Networks (CNN) and Recurrent Neural
Networks (RNN). They overcome the problem of exploding
and vanishing gradients by using causal dilated convolution

TABLE I: Comparison of HRV feature estimation
A. Feature Estimation
The feature values predicted by our model are compared
against HeartPy predictions. To the best of our', ' device placed
on the finger that sampled PPG at 1000Hz. For our current
work, we will only focus on the PPG signal.
The study involved each subject completing a set of validated
tasks that induced stress, interspersed with tasks that help them
relax. The study started with a baseline-recording for 5 min-
utes where the subject sat idle. The subject then performed a
multiple object tracking task for 3 minutes (cognitive stressor),
followed by 3 minutes of progressive muscle relaxation. The
subject then underwent a â€œSpeechâ€ task; a research assistant,
playing the role of an interviewer, asked the subject to speak
on a challenging and personal topic (social stressor). The
subject was then given 3 minute time to prepare for the speech,
after which they entered a room consisting of evaluators. The
research assistant purposefully delayed the start of the speech
to increase the stress. After a 2-minute delay, the subject was
asked to leave without completing the task. Subsequently, the
subject listened to relaxing music for 4 minutes, followed
by exciting music. Finally, the subject was asked to rest and
recover. Between each task, the subject was given at least a
2-minute break to offset the effect of the previous task and
prepare for the next task. In Figure 1, we show the timeline
of the tasks and how the heart rate varies during these tasks
for a sample subject.
B. PPG signal-denoising
The raw PPG signals captured from the Earbud and Biopac
were first filtered by a third-order Butterworth bandpass filter
with cut-off frequencies set to 0.6-4 Hz. The filtered PPG
signal was then sliced into 30-second sliding windows with a
20-second overlap for the prediction of HRV parameters and
stress detection. Even after passing the PPG signal through a
bandpass filter, the signal still contained motion artifacts, shifts
in baseline wandering, and other high-frequency noises. To
address this, we estimated the quality of the PPG signal using
the PQR signal quality index [8]. In this method, we calculated
P/Q/R indexes representing the signal quality for each window

V. C ONCLUSION
Estimating HRV features using wearable sensors is critical
for stress management solutions. In our current work, we take
an initial step toward using earbud PPG signals to estimate
HRV features, employing a framework based on transfer
learning and TCN architecture. We have demonstrated that
our framework estimates these features more accurately than
the existing open-source library, HeartPy. Subsequently, we
observed that using our modelâ€™s predicted HRV features in
place of HeartPy for stress detection results in improved
performance. Encouraged by these initial results, we plan to
conduct our study on a larger and more diverse set of subjects
to corroborate our findings.

TABLE I: Comparison of HRV feature estimation
A. Feature Estimation
The feature values predicted by our model are compared
against HeartPy predictions. To the best of our knowledge,
HeartPy is the most prominent and trusted public library to
provide HRV features from PPG signals. For the prediction
of all the HRV features, we use a 4-layer TCN to get the
input representation from the PPG signal that, in turn is
passed through 2 Fully Connected (FC) layers with hidden
sizes of 64 to get the output prediction. We train the model
using a learning rate of 5e-05 and a dropout value of 0.3.
We evaluate the performance of our model against HeartPy
using mean absolute error (MAE) with the estimates from the
Biopac sensor data considered the ground truth. We report
these results in Table I. Among all the parameters predicted,
we observe that for heart rate alone, HeartPy outperforms our
proposed framework. For the remaining HRV parameters, our
model performs better than HeartPy prediction. On average,
the improvement in HRV parameter estimation compared to
HeartPy is around 26%.
To highlight the significance of fine-tuning, we predicted
HRV features from the earbud PPG without any pre-training
step. The results of this experiment are shown in Table I.
With the exception of HR, we observe that transfer learning
improves performance for all the HRV features.
Throughout all our experiments, we consistently observed
relatively poorer performance in average HR estimation using
our proposed framework. This may be related to the fact that
heart rate estimation is fundamentally different from HRV
parameter estimation. While HRV estimation depends on the
specific sequence of individual peaks, HR is more of an
average of the distances between peaks. The framework was
not optimized for this averaging task and the removal of
outliers that would adversely affect the average. Nevertheless,
heart rate is an important feature and integrating its estimation
in a unified framework can be the focus of future work.
B. Stress detection
In this section, we report the performance of stress clas-
sification using HRV parameters obtained from HeartPy and
our model, respectively. The PPG window from a subject is
labeled as stress if it is sampled from the task that induces
stress, which in our case are Dot-tracking, Speech-Preparation,
Speech, and Exciting Music tasks (see Figure 1 for more
details), PPG windows from the remaining tasks are labeled

III. T RANSFER LEARNING BASED FRAMEWORK FOR
EXTRACTING HRV FEATURES
To extract HRV based features from the denoised earbud
PPG signal, we design a framework based on transfer learning
and using Temporal convolution network (TCN) [9]. The
framework consists of two steps: In the first step we pre-train
a TCN model on Biopac PPG to detect position of peaks.
For the latter step, we use this pre-trained TCN model for the
downstream task of predicting different HRV parameters. We
explain these steps in detail below.
A. Pre-training using Biopac PPG
The growing availability of ubiquitous and unobtrusive
wearable devices has made the collection of continuous sensor
data more convenient and accessible than ever. However,
labeling this data requires significant effort and time. As a
result, the amount of labeled sensor data available is minimal
in comparison to the unlabeled data that can be collected. We
first pre-train a model with the reference PPG signals captured
from the Biopac finger sensor to detect peak positions of this
input signal. We chose this task because all the HRV-related
features extracted from the PPG signal are derived from the
position of peaks. The primary motivation for pre-training a
model on the PPG data is to increase data efficiency given the
relative scarcity of available earbud PPG data, and to acquaint
the model with the PPG signal. We use HeartPy [10], [11], an
open-source python library for extracting ground truth peak
positions. The idea of initiating models on hand-designed tasks
before deploying them for different downstream purposes is
not uncommon. In computer vision, models are often pre-
trained with image segmentation tasks [12], [13] and in natural
language processing to generate language models like BERT
[14] and GPT-3 [15], models are pre-trained with tasks of pre-
dicting of next word in a sentence. We used TCN as our choice
of model, while there are several choices for modeling contin-
uous time-series data TCNs are a type of convolution network
that convolve over a time-domain by combining properties of
Convolutional Neural Networks (CNN) and Recurrent Neural
Networks (RNN). They overcome the problem of exploding
and vanishing gradients by using causal dilated convolution

The study involved each subject completing a set of validated
tasks that induced stress, interspersed with tasks that help them
relax. The study started with a baseline-recording for 5 min-
utes where the subject sat idle. The subject then performed a
multiple object tracking task for 3 minutes (cognitive stressor),
followed by 3 minutes of progressive muscle relaxation. The
subject then underwent a â€œSpeechâ€ task; a research assistant,
playing the role of an interviewer, asked the subject to speak
on a challenging and personal topic (social stressor). The
subject was then given 3 minute time to prepare for the speech,
after which they entered a room consisting of evaluators. The
research assistant purposefully delayed the start of the speech
to increase the stress. After a 2-minute delay, the subject was
asked to leave without completing the task. Subsequently, the
subject listened to relaxing music for 4 minutes, followed
by exciting music. Finally, the subject was asked to rest and
recover. Between each task, the subject was given at least a
2-minute break to offset the effect of the previous task and
prepare for the next task. In Figure 1, we show the timeline
of the tasks and how the heart rate varies during these tasks
for a sample subject.
B. PPG signal-denoising
The raw PPG signals captured from the Earbud and Biopac
were first filtered by a third-order Butterworth bandpass filter
with cut-off frequencies set to 0.6-4 Hz. The filtered PPG
signal was then sliced into 30-second sliding windows with a
20-second overlap for the prediction of HRV parameters and
stress detection. Even after passing the PPG signal through a
bandpass filter, the signal still contained motion artifacts, shifts
in baseline wandering, and other high-frequency noises. To
address this, we estimated the quality of the PPG signal using
the PQR signal quality index [8]. In this method, we calculated
P/Q/R indexes representing the signal quality for each window
of PPG signal. The â€œPâ€ index indicated the degree of high-
frequency noise in the signal, calculated using the change in
the number of extremum points after bandpass filtering. The
â€œQâ€ index indicated the amount of baseline wandering, cal-
culated using the signalâ€™s maximum and minimum amplitude.
The â€Râ€ index represented the frequency of motion artifacts
by calculating the dispersion of peak and valley points. Using
these three indexes, the method calculated rSQI (relative signal
quality index) to compare the quality of the PPG signal against
a clean reference signal. In our case, we used the signal
collected from the baseline-recording as a reference signal.
The PPG-windowed signals whose rSQI â‰¥ 0, indicating the
signal was comparable or better in quality than the reference
signal, were considered for subsequent analysis. The PPG-
windowed signals with rSQI < 0 are removed. Finally, we
standardized the PPG signals of each subject to remove any
subject-dependent information. Due to poor contact on one
or more of the earbuds or Biopac finger sensor resulting in
signals too noisy to be usable, we excluded PPG data from
four subjects.

[' (EDA) to passively detect stress in field with
75% accuracy [4]. Another study employed a custom-made
wearable chest band for passive ECG sensing and detected
stress with a 0.71 F1-score [5]. There has also been an
approach that combined a commodity chestband to capture
ECG and a commodity wristband called Empatica for EDA
sensor to detect stress with 0.94 F1-score [6]. Stress detection
using head-worn devices is relatively less common. Another
recent work demonstrated a head-neck device capable of
simultaneously capturing ECG and EEG, which can detect
â€™stressedâ€™ states with 75.8% accuracy [7]. While these results
show promise for the use of wearable devices in daily stress
detection, a common limitation, aside from smartwatches and
smartphones, is that these devices are expensive, invasive
for everyday use, and typically serve only a single purpose.
Earbuds, as a wearable, have been gaining traction and in-
creasingly adopted. From a signal processing perspective, they
offer certain advantages over smartwatches. These include
lower susceptibility to motion, a relatively fixed orientation,
and their more consistent wear pattern among users. Despite
these advantages, earbuds are more prone to noise interference
than the more stable but less conveniently wearable options
like chest bands or finger sensors. Therefore, earbuds could
greatly benefit from the application of more sophisticated
signal processing and machine learning approaches. The main
contribution of our work was designing a transfer-learning
based framework for heart rate variability (HRV) feature
extraction from noisy earbud PPG signal. We also show the
stress detection performance using our proposed framework on
human subjects with reference sensors undergoing validated
stressor tasks.

II. D ATA COLLECTION AND CLEANING
A. Study Protocol
This was an experimental study approved by the Institu-
tional Review Board of the University of California, San Fran-
cisco. The aim of this study was to detect stress from the PPG
signals captured by earbud sensors. Eighteen subjects were
recruited for this study, and they were all healthy individuals
from the 19-22 age group to ensure that the stress responses
induced are minimally affected by other confounders and
comorbidities. Throughout the study, subjects wore earbuds
that captured PPG at 25Hz, accelerometer at 50Hz, and Core
body temperature (CBT) at 1Hz. The reference ground truth
PPG from subjects was captured using a Biopac device placed
on the finger that sampled PPG at 1000Hz. For our current
work, we will only focus on the PPG signal.
The study involved each subject completing a set of validated
tasks that induced stress, interspersed with tasks that help them
relax. The study started with a baseline-recording for 5 min-

multiple object tracking task for 3 minutes (cognitive stressor),
followed by 3 minutes of progressive muscle relaxation. The
subject then underwent a â€œSpeechâ€ task; a research assistant,
playing the role of an interviewer, asked the subject to speak
on a challenging and personal topic (social stressor). The
subject was then given 3 minute time', ' for more
details), PPG windows from the remaining tasks are labeled

question: What limitations of the study were discussed?
chunks_str:
[' device placed
on the finger that sampled PPG at 1000Hz. For our current
work, we will only focus on the PPG signal.
The study involved each subject completing a set of validated
tasks that induced stress, interspersed with tasks that help them
relax. The study started with a baseline-recording for 5 min-
utes where the subject sat idle. The subject then performed a
multiple object tracking task for 3 minutes (cognitive stressor),
followed by 3 minutes of progressive muscle relaxation. The
subject then underwent a â€œSpeechâ€ task; a research assistant,
playing the role of an interviewer, asked the subject to speak
on a challenging and personal topic (social stressor). The
subject was then given 3 minute time to prepare for the speech,
after which they entered a room consisting of evaluators. The
research assistant purposefully delayed the start of the speech
to increase the stress. After a 2-minute delay, the subject was
asked to leave without completing the task. Subsequently, the
subject listened to relaxing music for 4 minutes, followed
by exciting music. Finally, the subject was asked to rest and
recover. Between each task, the subject was given at least a
2-minute break to offset the effect of the previous task and
prepare for the next task. In Figure 1, we show the timeline
of the tasks and how the heart rate varies during these tasks
for a sample subject.
B. PPG signal-denoising
The raw PPG signals captured from the Earbud and Biopac
were first filtered by a third-order Butterworth bandpass filter
with cut-off frequencies set to 0.6-4 Hz. The filtered PPG
signal was then sliced into 30-second sliding windows with a
20-second overlap for the prediction of HRV parameters and
stress detection. Even after passing the PPG signal through a
bandpass filter, the signal still contained motion artifacts, shifts
in baseline wandering, and other high-frequency noises. To
address this, we estimated the quality of the PPG signal using
the PQR signal quality index [8]. In this method, we calculated
P/Q/R indexes representing the signal quality for each window
of PPG signal. The â€œPâ€ index indicated the degree of high-
frequency noise in the signal, calculated using the change in
the number of extremum points after bandpass filtering. The
â€œQâ€ index indicated the amount of baseline wandering, cal-
culated using the signalâ€™s maximum and minimum amplitude.
The â€Râ€ index represented the frequency of motion artifacts
by calculating the dispersion of peak and valley points. Using
these three indexes, the method calculated rSQI (relative signal
quality index) to compare the quality of the PPG signal against
a clean reference signal. In our case, we used the signal
collected from the baseline-recording as a reference signal.
The PPG-windowed signals whose rSQI â‰¥ 0, indicating the
signal was comparable or better in quality than the reference
signal, were considered for subsequent analysis. The PPG-
windowed signals with rSQI < 0 are removed. Finally, we
standardized the PPG signals of each subject to remove any
subject-dependent information. Due to poor contact on one
or more of the earbuds or Biopac finger sensor resulting in
signals too noisy to be usable, we excluded PPG data from
four subjects.
III. T RANSFER LEARNING BASED FRAMEWORK FOR
EXTRACTING HRV FEATURES
To extract HRV based features from the denoised earbud
PPG signal, we design a framework based on transfer learning
and using Temporal convolution network (TCN) [9]. The
framework consists of two steps: In the first step we pre-train
a TCN', 'Speech-PrepSpeech
