The models are evaluated based on two main criteria, namely
the discriminative performance and the model calibration.
1) Discriminative Performance: The primary metric that
we use to judge the discriminative power of a model is
the Area Under the Curve (AUC) of the receiver operating
characteristic (ROC) curve. Models with ideal discrimination
power have an AUC of 1.0 and the ones with no discrimi-
natory ability have AUC equal 0.5. Along with AUC we also
report balanced accuracy (or average class accuracy), precision
(or positive predictive value) and recall (or true positive
rate). Balanced accuracy is calculated as the average of the
proportion of correct predictions for each class individually.
Balanced accuracy is chosen ahead of regular accuracy as it
provides a better overview of the model performance than the
classiï¬cation accuracy when the classes are not balanced [25].
Precision is the proportion of positive identiï¬cations by the
model that were actually correct. Recall is the proportion of
actual positives that were identiï¬ed correctly.
It should be noted, that AUC is the strongest indicator of the
model performance among all the discriminative performance
metrics that we report here. AUC is statistically consistent and
more discriminating than accuracy [26]. Balanced accuracy,
precision and recall are all dependent on the threshold we
choose to apply on the probability estimations of the class
prediction to get the class labels. Choosing an appropriate
decision threshold is highly dependent on the desired outcome
of the predictive model (high speciï¬city or high sensitivity).
Since our goal is to give a probability score for MetS, AUC
is more relevant for us. For computing balanced accuracy,
precision and recall, a decision threshold of 0.5 is assumed.
A 5-fold cross-validation was performed to get a more robust
estimate of the validation metrics. The hyper-parameters for
the different classiï¬ers were optimized empirically.
2) Model Calibration: Model calibration refers to the
agreement between subgroups of predicted probabilities and
their observed frequencies [27]. For predictive models in
medicine, usually the predicted probabilities of the different
class labels are important as they show how conï¬dent the
model is about the predictions. Models like LR are usually
well calibrated as it directly optimizes the log-loss. But many
other machine learning models like RF are thought to be
poorly calibrated [28]. There are different ways to check for
model calibration, calibration plot usually being the preferred
approach [27], [29]. To evaluate the calibration performance
we also report the Brier score for each classiï¬er [30]. Brier
score measures the mean squared difference between the
predicted probability assigned to the possible outcomes for
an observation and the actual outcome. Lower the Brier score,
the better the predictions from the model are calibrated. The
calibration plots and the Brier scores were generated using a
test set of 463 observations (20% of the whole data) and the
remaining data were used to train the models (using features
from set A).
After investigating the distortion characteristic (or calibra-
tion) of each learning', ')

After computing the new features, we construct a few
subsets of the whole feature space. Although it may seem
counter intuitive to use a subset of the features instead of all, it
is often observed that only a few of those features are actually
related to the target concept. Irrelevant and redundant features
may confuse the machine learning algorithm by shrouding the
distributions of the small set of truly relevant features for
the task at hand [20]. In this situation, feature selection is
important to speed up learning and to improve concept quality.
It should be noted that the feature subsets here are created
manually mostly based on prior work and domain knowledge.
These smaller subsets are necessary to compare our work
with the results of Romero-SaldaËœna et al. and establish some
baselines [17]. We deï¬ne the following feature sets:
1) Set A: age, sex, height, weight, systolic blood pressure
(SBP), diastolic blood pressure (DBP), waist circumfer-
ence (WC), WtHR, BMI, BFP and all the medication
information from table II
2) Set B: All in set A except the medication information
3) Set C [17]: WtHR, BFP, BMI, DBP
4) Set D: WC, SBP, DBP
The difference between set A and set B is only that set
A contains the medication information which set B does not.
Since the medication information plays a role in the MetS
diagnostic criteria as well we wanted to test the models with
and without it. More importantly, since we want our models

model calibration, calibration plot usually being the preferred
approach [27], [29]. To evaluate the calibration performance
we also report the Brier score for each classiï¬er [30]. Brier
score measures the mean squared difference between the
predicted probability assigned to the possible outcomes for
an observation and the actual outcome. Lower the Brier score,
the better the predictions from the model are calibrated. The
calibration plots and the Brier scores were generated using a
test set of 463 observations (20% of the whole data) and the
remaining data were used to train the models (using features
from set A).
After investigating the distortion characteristic (or calibra-
tion) of each learning algorithm, calibration methods (e.g.
isotonic regression, Plattâ€™s scaling) are used to correct this
distortions [31], [32]. Isotonic regression in general is more
powerful calibrator than Plattâ€™s scaling as it can correct any
monotonic distortion and also unlike Plattâ€™s, isotonic regres-
sion is a non-parametric method. On the downside isotonic
regression is more prone to overï¬tting when the dataset is
small [28]. We report Brier scores of all the classiï¬ers, both
before and after the calibrations are performed.
The results from the experiments are discussed it details in
the next section.
IV . RESULTS AND DISCUSSION
We start this section by comparing the discriminative perfor-
mance of the different classiï¬er and feature set combinations.
Table III shows the mean and the standard deviation (in
brackets) of all the performance metrics that were described
in section III-E1, obtained from 5-fold cross validation for the
combinations. For every feature set, the algorithm with the
best average validation metric is highlighted with bold. When
the mean value is same for multiple algorithms (considering
up to 2 decimal places) preference is given to classiï¬ers with a
low standard deviation. The entire machine learning pipeline
was implemented in python using scikit-learn and the plots
were generated using matplotlib [33], [34].
A. Comparing the Feature sets
It can be observed from Table III that set A clearly outper-
forms the other feature sets both in terms of AUC, balanced
accuracy and recall. This clearly supports our claim of the
need for models encompassing more features. Set B without
incorporating any medicine intake information still manages to
outperform set C and set D. Set C which is reported as the best
performing feature set in [17], performs poorly compared to
the other feature sets, most noticeably sometimes even worse
than set D which only comprises of the 3 features that we
directly incorporate from the diagnostic criteria. Observing
the performance of set D it can be concluded that most of
the information already resides in these 3 variables. As they
directly contribute to the diagnostic deï¬nition this observation
is anticipated and self-explanatory. But comparing set D to
set A and set B it can also be concluded that by adding more
features to the model signiï¬cant performance gains can be
observed. It should be noted, the recall drops sharply as the
number of features are reduced.
The ROC curves for the different feature sets can also be
visualized in ï¬g. 1. The ROC curves in this case was generated
on a test dataset with 463 observations (20% of the whole data)
and the rest of the data were used to train the models with the
ensemble classiï¬er.
A comparison between our models and the rule-based
approach from Romero-SaldaËœna et al. was also performed [17].

In recent years, machine learning has frequently been uti-
lized to predict and aid medical diagnosis. Machine learning
algorithms especially non linear classiï¬ers such as random
forests, gradient boosting trees have often exhibited better
performance in predicting clinical outcomes than traditional
approaches like logistic regression [9], [10]. But even with a
strong algorithm, the model can only be as good as the relevant
information in the training dataset. Selecting the set of relevant
features that fully describes all concepts in a given dataset
can be equally important as selecting the right algorithm. In
this paper we not only compare the different algorithms with
each other but also different feature subsets for predicting the
presence of MetS.
Additionally, we do recognize the need of providing a con-
tinuous risk score along with the diagnosis for MetS. There-
fore, we also investigate the probability estimates obtained
from the different classiï¬ers and test if they are well calibrated
in order to achieve the best individual risk predictions.
II. P REVIOUS WORK
For the purpose of early detection of MetS a lot of work
has been done to discover novel biomarkers of metabolic
risk such as leukocyte and its sub-types, serum bilirubin,
plasminogen activator inhibitor-1, adiponectin, resistin, C-
reactive protein [11]â€“[13]. Some work also exists in identify-
ing anthropological features such as body mass index (BMI),
waist circumference, waist-hip ratio, waist-height ratio etc.
[14], [15]. The discrepancy in the results reported in these
papers points to the need of predictive models that are more
robust and generalize better to unseen data.
Hsiung, Liu, Cheng and Ma proposed a novel method
to predict the presence of MetS using heart rate variability
(HRV) and some other non-invasive measures such as BMI,
body fat, waist circumference, neck circumference [16]. The
work shows that data collected from cardiac bio-signals such
as HRV can be predictive of the presence of MetS when
combined with some anthropological features. Although no
ï¬nal diagnostic accuracy metrics were reported in the paper,
the systolic blood pressure (SBP), BMI and the very low
frequency (VLF) sections of the HRV were found to be good
predictors of the condition. Nevertheless, the lack of HRV data
in current clinical practice makes it challenging to incorporate
it into system whose purpose is to ease the detection of MetS.
Romero-SaldaËœna et al. proposed a new method based on
only anthropometric variables for early detection of MetS for
a Spanish working population (trained on 636 subjects and
validated on 550 subjects) [17]. The features that were used
for the models were waist-height ratio, body mass index, blood
pressure and body fat percentage. Based on the outcome of
the model they proposed a decision tree based on waist-height
ratio (â‰¥ 0.55) and hypertension (blood pressure â‰¥ 128/85
mmHg) which achieved a sensitivity of 91.6% and a speciï¬city
of 95.7% on the validation cohort. In a later work the method
was validated with a larger cohort of Spanish workers (60799
subjects) where a sensitivity of 54.7% and a speciï¬city of
94.9% was observed [18]. A low sensitivity indicates that
proposed model incorrectly classiï¬ed a lot of MetS patients
as healthy. In the paper they also discover that cutoff for the
optimal waist-height ratio varies across gender and different
age groups. This indicates the need of a more sophisticated
model encompassing more features.
III. M ETHODS
A. Data Collection
Data collection was', ' self-explanatory. But comparing set D to
set A and set B it can also be concluded that by adding more
features to the model signiï¬cant performance gains can be
observed. It should be noted, the recall drops sharply as the
number of features are reduced.
The ROC curves for the different feature sets can also be
visualized in ï¬g. 1. The ROC curves in this case was generated
on a test dataset with 463 observations (20% of the whole data)
and the rest of the data were used to train the models with the
ensemble classiï¬er.
A comparison between our models and the rule-based
approach from Romero-SaldaËœna et al. was also performed [17].
The ï¬xed rule approach demonstrates a balanced accuracy
of 0.73 (recall: 0.55, precision: 0.80) on the whole dataset.
The results are in accordance with the later work that was
published to validate this method on a bigger dataset [18]. The
low recall again underlines the fact that the ï¬xed rule based
approach suffers from a high number of false negatives, i.e it

III. M ETHODS
A. Data Collection
Data collection was', '-
tween the different feature sets. When comparing the AUCs,
we observe that the ensemble classiï¬er performs best on
average across all the feature sets. For the larger feature sets,
the more advanced machine learning methods perform better
than the logistic regression. For set D which is the smallest
feature set with only 3 features, almost all the algorithms
(with the exception of RF) shows similar performance. For
balanced accuracy, the ensemble classiï¬er outperforms all the
other algorithms on every feature set. In terms of recall, the
more advanced machine learning methods demonstrate a better
performance than logistic regression.
Looking at the standard deviation of all the validation
metrics reported here, we can also observe that the ensem-
ble method usually demonstrates a more stable performance
across the different cross validation folds. This supports the
notion that, because ensemble algorithms aggregate multiple
classiï¬ers it is often more generalizable and robust compared
to individual classiï¬er algorithms [35]. In a sense, the different
base algorithms compliment each other in an ensemble, which
often results in a better classiï¬cation performance.
The ROC curves for the different classiï¬ers can be visual-
ized in ï¬g. 2. The curves were generated using the same test
set as described above using the features from set A.
C. Model Calibration
To investigate the model calibration, we start with the
calibration plots for the classiï¬ers described in the section
III-D. Fig. 3 shows the calibration plots based on the predicted
probabilities that were directly obtained from the models.
The calibration performance is evaluated with Brier score,
reported in the legend of ï¬g. 3 and in table IV. The lower
the Brier score, the better calibrated the model is. Calibration
performance can also be evaluated by investigating the calibra-
tion/reliability plot (the upper half of the ï¬gure). If the model
is well calibrated the points will fall near the diagonal line.
The lower part of the plot shows histograms of the predicted
probabilities. From ï¬g. 3 we can see, as expected the logistic
regression returns a well calibrated model. Notably, contrary
to popular belief, RF produces the best calibrated model here.
The GBM and the ensemble classiï¬er display poor calibration
performance and exhibit an almost sigmoidal shape in the
calibration plots. Investigating the histogram in this ï¬gure it
can be observed that most of the predicted probabilities from
the GBM and the ensemble lies in central region with very
few probabilities reaching 0 or 1.
Fig. 4 shows the calibration plots and histograms of the clas-
siï¬ers after applying the isotonic regression [31]. The adjusted
Brier scores can be found in the legend of 4 and in table IV. It
can be immediately observed that the calibration performance
of GBM and the ensemble model improves signiï¬cantly. The
Brier scores of the calibrated GBM and ensemble models
are now comparable with the native LR and RF outputs
and in some cases even better (for GBMs). Inspecting the
histograms, it can be observed that the probabilities are much
better distributed across the whole spectrum when compared
to ï¬g. 3. Plattâ€™s scaling was also tested on the models and
the corresponding Brier scores can be found in table IV.
No signiï¬cant differences were observed when comparing the
Brier scores of the two different calibration techniques.

question: How is missing data handled in this study?
chunks_str:
['olic blood pressure
(SBP), diastolic blood pressure (DBP), waist circumfer-
ence (WC), WtHR, BMI, BFP and all the medication
information from table II
2) Set B: All in set A except the medication information
3) Set C [17]: WtHR, BFP, BMI, DBP
4) Set D: WC, SBP, DBP
The difference between set A and set B is only that set
A contains the medication information which set B does not.
Since the medication information plays a role in the MetS
diagnostic criteria as well we wanted to test the models with
and without it. More importantly, since we want our models
to be operable on a wide variety of cohorts and we do
recognize that reliable medication information can be difï¬cult
to obtain in some scenarios (e.g. electronic health records), it is
necessary to have a model without medications. Set C is the
best performing feature set as reported by Romero-Salda Ëœna
et al. [17]. Set D includes the anthropometric features that
we directly take from the diagnostic criteria of MetS. It is
important to note that unlike some previous work, we avoid
dichotomising any continuous feature variables. The most
noteworthy drawback of dichotomising continuous features is
that individuals close to but on opposite sides of the cutoff
are often characterized as being dissimilar rather than very
similar [21]. Although, since we use the currently established
dichotomous deï¬nition of MetS as the target variable, it
is possible that our models implicitly learn the thresholds,
specially for the features that were directly taken from the
diagnostic criteria.
D. Classiï¬cation Methods
Here we brieï¬‚y describe the classiï¬cation algorithms we
evaluated in this work.
1) Logistic Regression (LR): LR works similar to linear
regression, but with a binomial response variable. To avoid
overï¬tting we use L2 regularization (also known as ridge
regression).
2) Random F orest (RF):RF is an ensemble of randomly
constructed independent decision trees [22]. It usually exhibits
considerable performance improvements over single-tree clas-
siï¬er algorithms such as CART [23].
3) Gradient Boosting Machines (GBMs):In GBMs the al-
gorithm consecutively ï¬ts new models (in this case regression
trees) to provide a more accurate estimate of the target variable
[24]. Gradient boosting trains many models in an additive
and sequential manner. Gradient boosting of regression trees
usually produce highly robust and interpretable procedures for
classiï¬cation, even in situations when the training data are not
so clean [24].
4) Ensemble Classiï¬er: Finally we also built an ensemble
classiï¬er by combining the outputs from the three methods
mentioned above (LR, RF and GBM). Instead of the more
popular hard voting approach which selects the target label
which was predicted by the majority of the classiï¬ers, here we
use a soft voting ensemble technique which takes an average
of output probabilities of the base classiï¬ers and based on
the average value it decides on the target label. The primary
difference between the two approaches is that soft voting also
takes into account how certain each classiï¬er is about the
prediction.
E. Evaluation
The experiment was designed to compare each feature set
and classiï¬cation algorithm combination against each other.

After computing the new features, we construct a few
subsets of the whole feature space. Although it may seem
counter intuitive to use a subset of the features instead of all, it
is often observed that only a few of those features are actually
related to the target concept. Irrelevant and redundant features
may confuse the machine learning algorithm by shrouding the
distributions of the small set of truly relevant features for
the task at hand [20]. In this situation, feature selection is
important to speed up learning and to improve concept quality.
It should be noted that the feature subsets here are created
manually mostly based on prior work and domain knowledge.
These smaller subsets are necessary to compare our work
with the results of Romero-SaldaËœna et al. and establish some
baselines [17]. We deï¬ne the following feature sets:
1) Set A: age, sex, height, weight, systolic blood pressure
(SBP), diastolic blood pressure (DBP), waist circumfer-
ence (WC), WtHR, BMI, BFP and all the medication
information from table II
2) Set B: All in set A except the medication information
3) Set C [17]: WtHR, BFP, BMI, DBP
4) Set D: WC, SBP, DBP
The difference between set A and set B is only that set
A contains the medication information which set B does not.
Since the medication information plays a role in the MetS
diagnostic criteria as well we wanted to test the models with
and without it. More importantly, since we want our models
to be operable on a wide variety of cohorts', '[22] 0.139 0.138 0.138

Though showing promising results for a relatively unex-
plored problem, our study has certain limitations. We do
acknowledge, our training cohort contains subjects with pre-
dominately European origin, with an age range of 40 to
70. This limits the generalizability of our models to other
populations. Secondly it is a retrospective study with all the
usual limitations. Finally, we also acknowledge the limitations
rising from using MetS as the target variable, instead of
using the secondary complications such as CVDs and type
2 diabetes directly. Training on the secondary complications
directly would have allowed us to circumvent the problems
rising from the dichotomous deï¬nition currently used for MetS
[36].
This study can be used as a prototype for developing a
non-invasive risk score for the diagnosis of MetS. In future,
we plan to validate our methods on different cohorts and also
on electronic health record (EHR) databases. EHR databases
with longitudinal patient data will also allow us to train our
models with the secondary complications as target variable.
Finally we would also like to add more features to our cohort,
specially those collected from wearable sensors such as heart
rate, HRV and daily activity information to see if that improves
the diagnostic accuracy.

[' calibrated [28]. There are different ways to check for
model calibration, calibration plot usually being the preferred
approach [27], [29]. To evaluate the calibration performance
we also report the Brier score for each classiï¬er [30]. Brier
score measures the mean squared difference between the
predicted probability assigned to the possible outcomes for
an observation and the actual outcome. Lower the Brier score,
the better the predictions from the model are calibrated. The
calibration plots and the Brier scores were generated using a
test set of 463 observations (20% of the whole data) and the
remaining data were used to train the models (using features
from set A).
After investigating the distortion characteristic (or calibra-
tion) of each learning algorithm, calibration methods (e.g.
isotonic regression, Plattâ€™s scaling) are used to correct this
distortions [31], [32]. Isotonic regression in general is more
powerful calibrator than Plattâ€™s scaling as it can correct any
monotonic distortion and also unlike Plattâ€™s, isotonic regres-
sion is a non-parametric method. On the downside isotonic
regression is more prone to overï¬tting when the dataset is
small [28]. We report Brier scores of all the classiï¬ers, both
before and after the calibrations are performed.
The results from the experiments are discussed it details in
the next section.
IV . RESULTS AND DISCUSSION
We start this section by comparing the discriminative perfor-
mance of the different classiï¬er and feature set combinations.
Table III shows the mean and the standard deviation (in
brackets) of all the performance metrics that were described
in section III-E1, obtained from 5-fold cross validation for the
combinations. For every feature set, the algorithm with the
best average validation metric is highlighted with bold. When
the mean value is same for multiple algorithms (considering
up to 2 decimal places) preference is given to classiï¬ers with a
low standard deviation. The entire machine learning pipeline
was implemented in python using scikit-learn and the plots
were generated using matplotlib [33], [34].
A. Comparing the Feature sets
It can be observed from Table III that set A clearly outper-
forms the other feature sets both in terms of AUC, balanced
accuracy and recall. This clearly supports our claim of the
need for models encompassing more features. Set B without
incorporating any medicine intake information still manages to
outperform set C and set D. Set C which is reported as the best
performing feature set in [17], performs poorly compared to
the other feature sets, most noticeably sometimes even worse
than set D which only comprises of the 3 features that we
directly incorporate from the diagnostic criteria. Observing
the performance of set D it can be concluded that most of
the information already resides in these 3 variables. As they
directly contribute to the diagnostic deï¬nition this observation

It can be observed from Table III that set A clearly outper-

MetS risk and undergo further diagnostic steps if necessary.
In recent years, machine learning has frequently been uti-
lized to predict and aid medical diagnosis. Machine learning
algorithms especially non linear classiï¬ers such as random
forests, gradient boosting trees have often exhibited better
performance in predicting clinical outcomes than traditional
approaches like logistic regression [9], [10]. But even with a
strong algorithm, the model can only be as good as the relevant
information in the training dataset. Selecting the set of relevant
features that fully describes all concepts in a given dataset
can be equally important as selecting the right algorithm. In
this paper we not only compare the different algorithms with
each other but also different feature subsets for predicting the
presence of MetS.
Additionally, we do recognize the need of providing a con-
tinuous risk score along with the diagnosis for MetS. There-
fore, we also investigate the probability estimates obtained
from the different classiï¬ers and test if they are well calibrated
in order to achieve the best individual risk predictions.
II. P REVIOUS WORK
For the purpose of early detection of MetS a lot of work
has been done to discover novel biomarkers of metabolic
risk such as leukocyte and its sub-types, serum bilirubin,
plasminogen activator inhibitor-1, adiponectin, resistin, C-
reactive protein [11]â€“[13]. Some work also exists in identify-
ing anthropological features such as body mass index (BMI),
waist circumference, waist-hip ratio, waist-height ratio etc.
[14], [15]. The discrepancy in the results reported in these
papers points to the need of predictive models that are more
robust and generalize better to unseen data.
Hsiung, Liu, Cheng and Ma proposed a novel method
to predict the presence of MetS using heart rate variability
(HRV) and some other non-invasive measures such as BMI,
body fat, waist circumference, neck circumference [16]. The
work shows that data collected from cardiac bio-signals such
as HRV can be predictive of the presence of MetS when
combined with some anthropological features. Although no
ï¬nal diagnostic accuracy metrics were reported in the paper,
the systolic blood pressure (SBP), BMI and the very low
frequency (VLF) sections of the HRV were found to be good
predictors of the condition. Nevertheless, the lack of HRV data
in current clinical practice makes it challenging to incorporate
it into system whose purpose is to ease the detection of MetS.
Romero-SaldaËœna et al. proposed a new method based on
only anthropometric variables for early detection of MetS for
a Spanish working population (trained on 636 subjects and
validated on 550 subjects) [17]. The features that were used
for the models were waist-height ratio, body mass index, blood
pressure and body fat percentage. Based on the outcome of
the model they proposed a decision tree based on waist-height
ratio (â‰¥ 0.55) and hypertension (blood pressure â‰¥ 128/85
mmHg) which achieved a sensitivity of 91.6% and a speciï¬city
of 95.7% on the validation cohort. In a later work the method
was validated with a larger cohort of Spanish workers (60799
subjects) where a sensitivity of 54.7% and a speciï¬city of
94.9% was observed [18]. A low sensitivity indicates that
proposed model incorrectly classiï¬ed a lot of MetS patients
as healthy. In the paper they also discover that cutoff for the
optimal waist-height ratio varies across gender and different
age groups. This indicates the need of a more sophisticated
model encompassing more features.
III. M ETHODS
A. Data Collection
Data collection was', 'olic blood pressure
(SBP), diastolic blood pressure (DBP), waist circumfer-
ence (WC), WtHR, BMI, BFP and all the medication
information from table II
2) Set B: All in set A except the medication information
3) Set C [17]: WtHR, BFP, BMI, DBP
4) Set D: WC, SBP, DBP
The difference between set A and set B is only that set
A contains the medication information which set B does not.
Since the medication information plays a role in the MetS
diagnostic criteria as well we wanted to test the models with
and without it. More importantly, since we want our models
to be operable on a wide variety of cohorts and we do
recognize that reliable medication information can be difï¬cult
to obtain in some scenarios (e.g. electronic health records), it is
necessary to have a model without medications. Set C is the
best performing feature set as reported by Romero-Salda Ëœna
et al. [17]. Set D includes the anthropometric features that
we directly take from the diagnostic criteria of MetS. It is
important to note that unlike some previous work, we avoid
dichotomising any continuous feature variables. The most
noteworthy drawback of dichotomising continuous features is
that individuals close to but on opposite sides of the cutoff
are often characterized as being dissimilar rather than very
similar [21]. Although, since we use the currently established
dichotomous deï¬nition of MetS as the target variable, it
is possible that our models implicitly learn the thresholds,
specially for the features that were directly taken from the
diagnostic criteria.
D. Classiï¬cation Methods
Here we brieï¬‚y describe the classiï¬cation algorithms we
evaluated in this work.
1) Logistic Regression (LR): LR works similar to linear
regression, but with a binomial response variable. To avoid
overï¬tting we use L2 regularization (also known as ridge
regression).
2) Random F orest (RF):RF is an ensemble of randomly
constructed independent decision trees [22]. It usually exhibits
considerable performance improvements over single-tree clas-
siï¬er algorithms such as CART [23].
3) Gradient Boosting Machines (GBMs):In GBMs the al-
gorithm consecutively ï¬ts new models (in this case regression
trees) to provide a more accurate estimate of the target variable
[24]. Gradient boosting trains many models in an additive
and sequential manner. Gradient boosting of regression trees
usually produce highly robust and interpretable procedures for
classiï¬cation, even in situations when the training data are not
so clean [24].
4) Ensemble Classiï¬er: Finally we also built an ensemble
classiï¬er by combining the outputs from the three methods
mentioned above (LR, RF and GBM). Instead of the more
popular hard voting approach which selects the target label
which was predicted by the majority of the classiï¬ers, here we
use a soft voting ensemble technique which takes an average
of output probabilities of the base classiï¬ers and based on
the average value it decides on the target label. The primary
difference between the two approaches is that soft voting also
takes into account how certain each classiï¬er is about the
prediction.
E. Evaluation
The experiment was designed to compare each feature set
and classiï¬cation algorithm combination against each other.

In recent years, machine learning has frequently been uti-
lized to predict and aid medical diagnosis. Machine learning
algorithms especially non linear classiï¬ers such as random
forests, gradient boosting trees have often exhibited better
performance in predicting clinical outcomes than traditional
approaches like logistic regression [9], [10]. But even with a
strong algorithm, the model can only be as good as the relevant
information in the training dataset. Selecting the set of relevant
features that fully describes all concepts in a given dataset
can be equally important as selecting the right algorithm. In
this paper we not only compare the different algorithms with
each other but also different feature subsets for predicting the
presence of MetS.
Additionally, we do recognize the need of providing a con-
tinuous risk score along with the diagnosis for MetS. There-
fore, we also investigate the probability estimates obtained
from the different classiï¬ers and test if they are well calibrated
in order to achieve the best individual risk predictions.
II. P REVIOUS WORK
For the purpose of early detection of MetS a lot of work
has been done to discover novel biomarkers of metabolic
risk such as leukocyte and its sub-types, serum bilirubin,
plasminogen activator inhibitor-1, adiponectin, resistin, C-
reactive protein [11]â€“[13]. Some work also exists in identify-
ing anthropological features such as body mass index (BMI),
waist circumference, waist-hip ratio, waist-height ratio etc.
[14], [15]. The discrepancy in the results reported in these
papers points to the need of predictive models that are more
robust and generalize better to unseen data.
Hsiung, Liu, Cheng and Ma proposed a novel method
to predict the presence of MetS using heart rate variability
(HRV) and some other non-invasive measures such as BMI,
body fat, waist circumference, neck circumference [16]. The
work shows that data collected from cardiac bio-signals such
as HRV can be predictive of the presence of MetS when
combined with some anthropological features. Although no
ï¬nal diagnostic accuracy metrics were reported in the paper,
the systolic blood pressure (SBP), BMI and the very low
frequency (VLF) sections of the HRV were found to be good
predictors of the condition. Nevertheless, the lack of HRV data
in current clinical practice makes it challenging to incorporate
it into system whose purpose is to ease the detection of MetS.
Romero-SaldaËœna et al. proposed a new method based on
only anthropometric variables for early detection of MetS for
a Spanish working population (trained on 636 subjects and
validated on 550 subjects) [17]. The features that were used
for the models were waist-height ratio, body mass index, blood
pressure and body fat percentage. Based on the outcome of
the model they proposed a decision tree based on waist-height
ratio (â‰¥ 0.55) and hypertension (blood pressure â‰¥ 128/85
mmHg) which achieved a sensitivity of 91.6% and a speciï¬city
of 95.7% on the validation cohort. In a later work the method
was validated with a larger cohort of Spanish workers (60799
subjects) where a sensitivity of 54.7% and a speciï¬city of
94.9% was observed [18]. A low sensitivity indicates that
proposed model incorrectly classiï¬ed a lot of MetS patients
as healthy. In the paper they also discover that cutoff for the
optimal waist-height ratio varies across gender and different
age groups. This indicates the need of a more sophisticated
model encompassing more features.

The models are evaluated based on two main criteria, namely
the discriminative performance and the model calibration.
1) Dis', ' calibrated [28]. There are different ways to check for
model calibration, calibration plot usually being the preferred
approach [27], [29]. To evaluate the calibration performance
we also report the Brier score for each classiï¬er [30]. Brier
score measures the mean squared difference between the
predicted probability assigned to the possible outcomes for
an observation and the actual outcome. Lower the Brier score,
the better the predictions from the model are calibrated. The
calibration plots and the Brier scores were generated using a
test set of 463 observations (20% of the whole data) and the
remaining data were used to train the models (using features
from set A).
After investigating the distortion characteristic (or calibra-
tion) of each learning algorithm, calibration methods (e.g.
isotonic regression, Plattâ€™s scaling) are used to correct this
distortions [31], [32]. Isotonic regression in general is more
powerful calibrator than Plattâ€™s scaling as it can correct any
monotonic distortion and also unlike Plattâ€™s, isotonic regres-
sion is a non-parametric method. On the downside isotonic
regression is more prone to overï¬tting when the dataset is
small [28]. We report Brier scores of all the classiï¬ers, both
before and after the calibrations are performed.
The results from the experiments are discussed it details in
the next section.
IV . RESULTS AND DISCUSSION
We start this section by comparing the discriminative perfor-
mance of the different classiï¬er and feature set combinations.
Table III shows the mean and the standard deviation (in
brackets) of all the performance metrics that were described
in section III-E1, obtained from 5-fold cross validation for the
combinations. For every feature set, the algorithm with the
best average validation metric is highlighted with bold. When
the mean value is same for multiple algorithms (considering
up to 2 decimal places) preference is given to classiï¬ers with a
low standard deviation. The entire machine learning pipeline
was implemented in python using scikit-learn and the plots
were generated using matplotlib [33], [34].
A. Comparing the Feature sets
It can be observed from Table III that set A clearly outper-
forms the other feature sets both in terms of AUC, balanced
accuracy and recall. This clearly supports our claim of the
need for models encompassing more features. Set B without
incorporating any medicine intake information still manages to
outperform set C and set D. Set C which is reported as the best
performing feature set in [17], performs poorly compared to
the other feature sets, most noticeably sometimes even worse
than set D which only comprises of the 3 features that we
directly incorporate from the diagnostic criteria. Observing
the performance of set D it can be concluded that most of
the information already resides in these 3 variables. As they
directly contribute to the diagnostic deï¬nition this observation
is anticipated and self-explanatory. But comparing set D to
set A and set B it can also be concluded that by adding more
features to the model signiï¬cant performance gains can be
observed. It should be noted, the recall drops sharply as the
number of features are reduced.
The ROC curves for the different feature sets can also be
visualized in ï¬g. 1. The ROC curves in this case was generated
on a test dataset with 463 observations (20% of the whole data)
and the rest of the data were used to train the models with the
ensemble classiï¬er.
A comparison between our models and the rule-based
approach from Romero-SaldaËœna et al. was also performed [17].

Ensemble 0.153 0.141 0.140
Though showing promising results for a relatively unex-
plored problem, our study has certain limitations. We do
acknowledge, our training cohort contains subjects with pre-
dominately European origin, with an age range of 40 to
70. This limits the generalizability of our models to other
populations. Secondly it is a retrospective study with all the
usual limitations. Finally, we also acknowledge the limitations
rising from using MetS as the target variable, instead of
using the secondary complications such as CVDs and type
2 diabetes directly. Training on the secondary complications
directly would have allowed us to circumvent the problems
rising from the dichotomous deï¬nition currently used for MetS
[36].
This study can be used as a prototype for developing a
non-invasive risk score for the diagnosis of MetS. In future,
we plan to validate our methods on different cohorts and also
on electronic health record (EHR) databases. EHR databases
with longitudinal patient data will also allow us to train our
models with the secondary complications as target variable.
Finally we would also like to add more features to our cohort,
specially those collected from wearable sensors such as heart
rate, HRV and daily activity information to see if that improves
the diagnostic accuracy.
ACKNOWLEDGMENT
We would like to thank Prof. M. Rapp, Prof. P. M. Wippert,
Prof. H. V Â¨oller and Dr. K. Bonaventura from University
of Potsdam for helping us with the study design and data
collection.

E. Evaluation
The experiment was designed to compare each feature set
and classiï¬cation algorithm combination against each other.

Authorized licensed use limited to: Universiteit Leiden. Downloaded on May 25,2025 at 12:50:05 UTC from IEEE Xplore.  Restrictions apply. 

The models are evaluated based on two main criteria, namely
the discriminative performance and the model calibration.
1) Discriminative Performance: The primary metric that
we use to judge the discriminative power of a model is
the Area Under the Curve (AUC) of the receiver operating
characteristic (ROC) curve. Models with ideal discrimination
power have an AUC of 1.0 and the ones with no discrimi-
natory ability have AUC equal 0.5. Along with AUC we also
report balanced accuracy (or average class accuracy), precision
(or positive predictive value) and recall (or true positive
rate). Balanced accuracy is calculated as the average of the
proportion of correct predictions for each class individually.
Balanced accuracy is chosen ahead of regular accuracy as it
provides a better overview of the model performance than the
classiï¬cation accuracy when the classes are not balanced [25].
Precision is the proportion of positive identiï¬cations by the
model that were actually correct. Recall is the proportion of
actual positives that were identiï¬ed correctly.
It should be noted, that AUC is the strongest indicator of the
model performance among all the discriminative performance
metrics that we report here. AUC is statistically consistent and
more discriminating than accuracy [26]. Balanced accuracy,
precision and recall are all dependent on the threshold we
choose to apply on the probability estimations of the class
prediction to get the class labels. Choosing an appropriate
decision threshold is highly dependent on the desired outcome
of the predictive model (high speciï¬city or high sensitivity).
Since our goal is to give a probability score for MetS, AUC
is more relevant for us. For computing balanced accuracy,
precision and recall, a decision threshold of 0.5 is assumed.
A 5-fold cross-validation was performed to get a more robust
estimate of the validation metrics. The hyper-parameters for
the different classiï¬ers were optimized empirically.
2) Model Calibration: Model calibration refers to the
agreement between subgroups of predicted probabilities and
their observed frequencies [27]. For predictive models in
medicine, usually the predicted probabilities of the different
class labels are important as they show how conï¬dent the
model is about the predictions. Models like LR are usually
well calibrated as it directly optimizes the log-loss. But many
other machine learning models like RF are thought to be
poorly calibrated [28]. There are different ways to check for
model calibration, calibration plot usually being the preferred
approach [27], [29]. To evaluate the calibration performance
we also report the Brier score for each classiï¬er [30]. Brier
score measures the mean squared difference between the
predicted probability assigned to the possible outcomes for
an observation and the actual outcome. Lower the Brier score,
the better the predictions from the model are calibrated. The
calibration plots and the Brier scores were generated using a
test set of 463 observations (20% of the whole data) and the
remaining data were used to train the models (using features
from set A).
After investigating the distortion characteristic (or calibra-
tion) of each learning', '-
tween the different feature sets. When comparing the AUCs,
we observe that the ensemble classiï¬er performs best on
average across all the feature sets. For the larger feature sets,
the more advanced machine learning methods perform better
than the logistic regression. For set D which is the smallest
feature set with only 3 features, almost all the algorithms
(with the exception of RF) shows similar performance. For
balanced accuracy, the ensemble classiï¬er outperforms all the
other algorithms on every feature set. In terms of recall, the
more advanced machine learning methods demonstrate a better
performance than logistic regression.
Looking at the standard deviation of all the validation
metrics reported here, we can also observe that the ensem-
ble method usually demonstrates a more stable performance
across the different cross validation folds. This supports the
notion that, because ensemble algorithms aggregate multiple
classiï¬ers it is often more generalizable and robust compared
to individual classiï¬er algorithms [35]. In a sense, the different
base algorithms compliment each other in an ensemble, which
often results in a better classiï¬cation performance.
The ROC curves for the different classiï¬ers can be visual-
ized in ï¬g. 2. The curves were generated using the same test
set as described above using the features from set A.
C. Model Calibration
To investigate the model calibration, we start with the
calibration plots for the classiï¬ers described in the section
III-D. Fig. 3 shows the calibration plots based on the predicted
probabilities that were directly obtained from the models.
The calibration performance is evaluated with Brier score,
reported in the legend of ï¬g. 3 and in table IV. The lower
the Brier score, the better calibrated the model is. Calibration
performance can also be evaluated by investigating the calibra-
tion/reliability plot (the upper half of the ï¬gure). If the model
is well calibrated the points will fall near the diagonal line.
The lower part of the plot shows histograms of the predicted
probabilities. From ï¬g. 3 we can see, as expected the logistic
regression returns a well calibrated model. Notably, contrary
to popular belief, RF produces the best calibrated model here.
The GBM and the ensemble classiï¬er display poor calibration
performance and exhibit an almost sigmoidal shape in the
calibration plots. Investigating the histogram in this ï¬gure it
can be observed that most of the predicted probabilities from
the GBM and the ensemble lies in central region with very
few probabilities reaching 0 or 1.
Fig. 4 shows the calibration plots and histograms of the clas-
siï¬ers after applying the isotonic regression [31]. The adjusted
Brier scores can be found in the legend of 4 and in table IV. It
can be immediately observed that the calibration performance
of GBM and the ensemble model improves signiï¬cantly. The
Brier scores of the calibrated GBM and ensemble models
are now comparable with the native LR and RF outputs
and in some cases even better (for GBMs). Inspecting the
histograms, it can be observed that the probabilities are much
better distributed across the whole spectrum when compared
to ï¬g. 3. Plattâ€™s scaling was also tested on the models and
the corresponding Brier scores can be found in table IV.
No signiï¬cant differences were observed when comparing the
Brier scores of the two different calibration techniques.

(SBP), diastolic blood pressure (DBP), waist circumfer-

2) Set B: All in set A except the medication information
3) Set C [17]: WtHR, BFP, BMI, DBP
4) Set D: WC, SBP, DBP
The difference between set A and set B is only that set
A contains the medication information which set B does not.
Since the medication information plays a role in the MetS
diagnostic criteria as well we wanted to test the models with
and without it. More importantly, since we want our models
to be operable on a wide variety of cohorts and we do
recognize that reliable medication information can be difï¬cult
to obtain in some scenarios (e.g. electronic health records), it is
necessary to have a model without medications. Set C is the
best performing feature set as reported by Romero-Salda Ëœna
et al. [17]. Set D includes the anthropometric features that
we directly take from the diagnostic criteria of MetS. It is
important to note that unlike some previous work, we avoid
dichotomising any continuous feature variables. The most
noteworthy drawback of dichotomising continuous features is
that individuals close to but on opposite sides of the cutoff
are often characterized as being dissimilar rather than very
similar [21]. Although, since we use the currently established
dichotomous deï¬nition of MetS as the target variable, it
is possible that our models implicitly learn the thresholds,
specially for the features that were directly taken from the
diagnostic criteria.
D. Classiï¬cation Methods
Here we brieï¬‚y describe the classiï¬cation algorithms we
evaluated in this work.
1) Logistic Regression (LR): LR works similar to linear
regression, but with a binomial response variable. To avoid
overï¬tting we use L2 regularization (also known as ridge
regression).
2) Random F orest (RF):RF is an ensemble of randomly
constructed independent decision trees [22]. It usually exhibits
considerable performance improvements over single-tree clas-
siï¬er algorithms such as CART [23].
3) Gradient Boosting Machines (GBMs):In GBMs the al-
gorithm consecutively ï¬ts new models (in this case regression
trees) to provide a more accurate estimate of the target variable
[24]. Gradient boosting trains many models in an additive
and sequential manner. Gradient boosting of regression trees
usually produce highly robust and interpretable procedures for
classiï¬cation, even in situations when the training data are not
so clean [24].
4) Ensemble Classiï¬er: Finally we also built an ensemble
classiï¬er by combining the outputs from the three methods
mentioned above (LR, RF and GBM). Instead of the more
popular hard voting approach which selects the target label
which was predicted by the majority of the classiï¬ers, here we
use a soft voting ensemble technique which takes an average
of output probabilities of the base classiï¬ers and based on
the average value it decides on the target label. The primary
difference between the two approaches is that soft voting also
takes into account how certain each classiï¬er is about the
prediction.
E. Evaluation
The experiment was designed to compare each feature set
and classiï¬cation algorithm combination against each other.

We start this section by comparing the discriminative perfor-

Table III shows the mean and the standard deviation (in

were generated using matplotlib [33], [34].
A. Comparing the Feature sets
It can be observed from Table III that set A clearly outper-
forms the other feature sets both in terms of AUC, balanced
accuracy and recall. This clearly supports our claim of the
need for models encompassing more features. Set B without
incorporating any medicine intake information still manages to

In recent years, machine learning has frequently been uti-
lized to predict and aid medical diagnosis. Machine learning
algorithms especially non linear classiï¬ers such as random
forests, gradient boosting trees have often exhibited better
performance in predicting clinical outcomes than traditional
approaches like logistic regression [9], [10]. But even with a
strong algorithm, the model can only be as good as the relevant
information in the training dataset. Selecting the set of relevant
features that fully describes all concepts in a given dataset
can be equally important as selecting the right algorithm. In
this paper we not only compare the different algorithms with
each other but also different feature subsets for predicting the
presence of MetS.
Additionally, we do recognize the need of providing a con-
tinuous risk score along with the diagnosis for MetS. There-
fore, we also investigate the probability estimates obtained
from the different classiï¬ers and test if they are well calibrated
in order to achieve the best individual risk predictions.
II. P REVIOUS WORK
For the purpose of early detection of MetS a lot of work
has been done to discover novel biomarkers of metabolic
risk such as leukocyte and its sub-types, serum bilirubin,
plasminogen activator inhibitor-1, adiponectin, resistin, C-
reactive protein [11]â€“[13]. Some work also exists in identify-
ing anthropological features such as body mass index (BMI),
waist circumference, waist-hip ratio, waist-height ratio etc.
[14], [15]. The discrepancy in the results reported in these
papers points to the need of predictive models that are more
robust and generalize better to unseen data.
Hsiung, Liu, Cheng and Ma proposed a novel method
to predict the presence of MetS using heart rate variability
(HRV) and some other non-invasive measures such as BMI,
body fat, waist circumference, neck circumference [16]. The
work shows that data collected from cardiac bio-signals such
as HRV can be predictive of the presence of MetS when
combined with some anthropological features. Although no
ï¬nal diagnostic accuracy metrics were reported in the paper,
the systolic blood pressure (SBP), BMI and the very low
frequency (VLF) sections of the HRV were found to be good
predictors of the condition. Nevertheless, the lack of HRV data
in current clinical practice makes it challenging to incorporate
it into system whose purpose is to ease the detection of MetS.
Romero-SaldaËœna et al. proposed a new method based on
only anthropometric variables for early detection of MetS for
a Spanish working population (trained on 636 subjects and
validated on 550 subjects) [17]. The features that were used
for the models were waist-height ratio, body mass index, blood
pressure and body fat percentage. Based on the outcome of
the model they proposed a decision tree based on waist-height
ratio (â‰¥ 0.55) and hypertension (blood pressure â‰¥ 128/85
mmHg) which achieved a sensitivity of 91.6% and a speciï¬city
of 95.7% on the validation cohort. In a later work the method
was validated with a larger cohort of Spanish workers (60799
subjects) where a sensitivity of 54.7% and a speciï¬city of
94.9% was observed [18]. A low sensitivity indicates that
proposed model incorrectly classiï¬ed a lot of MetS patients
as healthy. In the paper they also discover that cutoff for the
optimal waist-height ratio varies across gender and different
age groups. This indicates the need of a more sophisticated
model encompassing more features.

Looking at the standard deviation of all the validation

A. Data Collection

Though showing promising results for a relatively unex-
plored problem, our study has certain limitations. We do
acknowledge, our training cohort contains subjects with pre-
dominately European origin, with an age range of 40 to
70. This limits the generalizability of our models to other
populations. Secondly it is a retrospective study with all the
usual limitations. Finally, we also acknowledge the limitations
rising from using MetS as the target variable, instead of
using the secondary complications such as CVDs and type
2 diabetes directly. Training on the secondary complications
directly would have allowed us to circumvent the problems
rising from the dichotomous deï¬nition currently used for MetS
[36].
This study can be used as a prototype for developing a
non-invasive risk score for the diagnosis of MetS. In future,
we plan to validate our methods on different cohorts and also
on electronic health record (EHR) databases. EHR databases
with longitudinal patient data will also allow us to train our
models with the secondary complications as target variable.
Finally we would also like to add more features to our cohort,
specially those collected from wearable sensors such as heart
rate, HRV and daily activity information to see if that improves
the diagnostic accuracy.

III. M ETHODS
A. Data Collection
Data collection was carried out in a mobile study center,
which was placed in cities and rural areas across the state
of Brandenburg, Germany (between 2016 and 2019). Partic-
ipants (aged 40 to 70 years old) were examined in mobile
examination units to diagnose MetS. Waist circumference was
measured using a tape measure (Seca, Germany). The arterial
blood pressure was measured manually by the auscultatory
method using a sphygmomanometer with a stethoscope. Cap-
illary blood was taken from the ï¬nger bulb for the analyses
of blood glucose (in mg/dl), triglycerides and HDL choles-
terol (in mg/dl) using the Alere Cholestech LDX analyzer
(Alere, Germany). Additionally, body mass was measured
using an electronic digital scale (Seca 899, Seca, Germany).
Participants were asked for any drug treatment because of
diagnosed diabetes, arterial hypertension, hypertriglyceridemia
or hypercholesterolemia. The study was approved by the
ethics committee of the University of Potsdam (ethics approval
number: 40/2016).
B. Cohort Description
Using the setting described above data from 2477 individ-
uals were collected. After removing rows with missing values
for variables that would have been required to deï¬ne the target
variable (in this case, presence of MetS) we end up with 2314
subjects. Following the diagnostic criteria described in section
I, 941 subjects (40.66%) were identiï¬ed as having MetS. A
more detailed description of the cohort can be found in Table
II.

2) Set B: All in set A except the medication information
3) Set C [17]: WtHR, BFP, BMI, DBP
4) Set D: WC, SBP, DBP
The difference between set A and set B is only that set
A contains the medication information which set B does not.
Since the medication information plays a role in the MetS
diagnostic criteria as well we wanted to test the models with
and without it. More importantly, since we want our models
to be operable on a wide variety of cohorts and we do
recognize that reliable medication information can be difï¬cult
to obtain in some scenarios (e.g. electronic health records), it is
necessary to have a model without medications. Set C is the
best performing feature set as reported by Romero-Salda Ëœna
et al. [17]. Set D includes the anthropometric features that
we directly take from the diagnostic criteria of MetS. It is
important to note that unlike some previous work, we avoid
dichotomising any continuous feature variables. The most
noteworthy drawback of dichotomising continuous features is
that individuals close to but on opposite sides of the cutoff
are often characterized as being dissimilar rather than very
similar [21]. Although, since we use the currently established
dichotomous deï¬nition of MetS as the target variable, it
is possible that our models implicitly learn the thresholds,
specially for the features that were directly taken from the
diagnostic criteria.
D. Classiï¬cation Methods
Here we brieï¬‚y describe the classiï¬cation algorithms we
evaluated in this work.
1) Logistic Regression (LR): LR works similar to linear
regression, but with a binomial response variable. To avoid
overï¬tting we use L2 regularization (also known as ridge
regression).
2) Random F orest (RF):RF is an ensemble of randomly
constructed independent decision trees [22]. It usually exhibits
considerable performance improvements over single-tree clas-
siï¬er algorithms such as CART [23].
3) Gradient Boosting Machines (GBMs):In GBMs the al-
gorithm consecutively ï¬ts new models (in this case regression
trees) to provide a more accurate estimate of the target variable
[24]. Gradient boosting trains many models in an additive
and sequential manner. Gradient boosting of regression trees
usually produce highly robust and interpretable procedures for
classiï¬cation, even in situations when the training data are not
so clean [24].
4) Ensemble Classiï¬er: Finally we also built an ensemble
classiï¬er by combining the outputs from the three methods
mentioned above (LR, RF and GBM). Instead of the more
popular hard voting approach which selects the target label
which was predicted by the majority of the classiï¬ers, here we
use a soft voting ensemble technique which takes an average
of output probabilities of the base classiï¬ers and based on
the average value it decides on the target label. The primary
difference between the two approaches is that soft voting also
takes into account how certain each classiï¬er is about the
prediction.
E. Evaluation
The experiment was designed to compare each feature set
and classiï¬cation algorithm combination against each other.

Diagnosis of Metabolic Syndrome
Suparno Dattaâˆ—â€ , Anne Schraplauâ€¡, Harry Freitas da Cruzâˆ—â€ , Jan Philipp Sachsâˆ—â€ ,

Email: suparno.datta@hpi.de
Abstractâ€”The metabolic syndrome is one of the major public
health challenges worldwide. Prevalence of metabolic syndrome
vastly increases the risk of type 2 diabetes and cardiovascular
diseases (CVDs). Metabolic Syndrome in general is under-
diagnosed and often goes undetected for years. In this paper
we present a machine learning based method for early detection
of metabolic syndrome which uses only non-invasive features. We
train and test our model based on data collected from a German
population consisting of 2314 subjects (male = 918, female =
1396). Out of 2314 subjects 941 were diagnosed with metabolic
syndrome (male = 441, female = 500). Features we consider
include different anthropometric features (such as height, weight,
waist circumference), medications, age, gender etc.; machine
learning techniques we employed included gradient boosting
machines, random forest, logistic regression and an ensemble
model. We compare our models against the ones that were
proposed in previous literature and outperform them in our
cohort. We achieve area under the curve values (AUCs) of up
to 0.90 with the ensemble classiï¬er . The results achieved suggest
that machine learning can be a valuable tool to predict metabolic
syndrome with high discriminative power without relying on
any invasive bio-markers, which signiï¬cantly facilitates early
detection.
Index T ermsâ€”Metabolic Syndrome, Machine learning, Predic-
tive models, Biomedical informatics
I. I NTRODUCTION
Over the past three decades, there has been a stagger-
ing increase in the number of people with metabolic syn-
drome (MetS) worldwide [1]. MetS is characterized by hy-
perglycemia, high blood pressure, central obesity and dyslipi-
demia. The increasing prevalence of MetS is associated with
the global epidemic of obesity and diabetes [2]. As a several-
fold increase in the risk of diabetes and cardiovascular diseases
(CVDs) is commonly associated with MetS, there is urgent
need for strategies to prevent this emerging global epidemic
that results in a considerable long-term burden for the public
health system [1]â€“[3].
A number of expert groups over the time have devel-
oped clinical criteria for MetS. The most widely accepted
of these were produced by the World Health Organization
(WHO), the National Cholesterol Education Program Third
Adult Treatment Panel (NCEP ATP III), the International
Diabetes Federation (IDF) and the American Heart Associa-
tion/National Heart, Lung, and Blood Institute (AHA/NHLBI)
[4]â€“[7]. To circumvent the inconsistencies arising from the
multiple criteria and to establish a uniï¬ed working diagnostic
tool for MetS, IDF and AHA/NHLBI together proposed a
new harmonized deï¬nition for this syndrome in 2009 [8].
According to the new deï¬nition, the presence of any 3 of
5 risk factors mentioned in Table I constitutes a diagnosis of
MetS.']

V. EXPERIMENTS AND RESULTS
Three experiments were designed to validate the claims about
the Ada-HAR system in Section I. The ï¬rst experiment of the HC
algorithm evaluation aimed to compare the performance among
ML-based and DL-based HC classiï¬ers. The second experiment
was to validate the evolution ability of the Ada-HAR system.
The demonstration revealed the identiï¬cation capability of Ada-
HAR system in real time. The experiments have implemented
these methods in MATLAB 2018b with the hardware platform of
Intel(R) i7 Core, 2.80-GHz CPU, and 16.0-GB RAM. A 64-bit
iPhone 6 s (2-core CPU) was utilized for collecting data with a
50-Hz sampling frequency.
A. HC Algorithm Evaluation
Twenty-ï¬ve subjects (13 females and 12 males, age range
18â€“40 years old) were asked to perform the 12 original activities
described in Section I in a ï¬xed order (shown in Fig. 4). They
carried the smartphone on the waist or put it in their left pant
pocket, respectively. Finally, 50 datasets (25 datasets for each
position) were collected for further analysis.
We adopt the leave-one-out cross-validation strategy to vali-
date the performance of HC classiï¬ers [40]. The length of the
detection window is 150 samples (3 s), and the overlap is 1 s
(50 estimates). Table III reports a comparison of the average and
standard deviation in terms of the accuracy, training time, and
average test time among ML-based (i.e.,k-NN, DT, NB, ANN,
and SVM) and DL-based (LSTM) HC classiï¬ers. Meanwhile,
all of the HC classiï¬ers are evaluated on uncompressed and no-
compressed datasets. Although the LSTM-based HC classiï¬er
obtains the highest accuracy, it is time-consuming for building
the model. Due to the SVM-based HC algorithm adopting the
linear kernel function, it takes more time to search the optimal
solution. In the same case, the k-NN-based approach is the
fastest method to establish the HC classiï¬er, while the DT-based
classiï¬er is the fastest algorithm to predict the activity. Moreover,
the testing accuracy displays that putting the smartphone in the
pocket acquires more noises than carrying the smartphone on
the waist. The results for the', 'Ld +Lo)=1 ,

For accuracy enhancement, the SVM model commonly utilizes
the radial basis function kernel and linear kernel commonly.
As a standard RNN method, the LSTM algorithm learns the
long-term dependencies based on the three gates, namely an
input gate, a forget gate to allow the LSTM unit to unlearn the
previous memory, and an output gate to decide the quantity of
memory transferring to the next hidden layers. However, it will
cost ample time to optimize the parameters of the LSTM network
and predict a result.

IV . METHODOLOGY
Fig. 2 shows the proposed Ada-HAR system with cre-
ation, recognition, and online learning modules. In the creation
module, the Hk-mC [6] is adopted to label the activities au-
tonomously. The HC [7] algorithms are used to establish the
classiï¬er for recognizing the 12 original activities (described in
Section I). In the recognition module, the obtained HC classiï¬er
is implemented for HAR in real time by carrying a smartphone
on the waist or putting it in the left pant pocket. In the online
learning module, a new activity that is not included in the 12
original activities will be identiï¬ed in an unsupervised learning
manner. Meanwhile, the old classiï¬er is updated. The signal
preprocessing and feature extraction models are shared in both
creation and recognition modules.
A. Signal Preprocessing and Feature Extraction

(e.g., magnetic ï¬elds and movement artifact), which affects the
recognition ability of the classiï¬er. The derived sensors signals
(e.g., gravity and linear acceleration) that are transferred by the

correlation-based ï¬lter [10], and sequential forward selection
(wrapper) [11] methods. By comparing the classiï¬cation rate of
identifying ï¬ve daily activities carrying a smartphone on ï¬ve
body positions, Khanet al.[12] proved that Kernel discriminant
analysis is better than linear discriminant analysis and signal
magnitude area. Shoaibet al. [13] demonstrated putting three
types of sensors (i.e., accelerometer, gyroscope, and linear ac-
celerometer) on the wrist and pocket to identify less-repetitive
activities, such as smoking, eating, and drinking coffee. For
solving the problem of online time series segmentation, Ignatov
et al. [14] constructed the phase trajectory matrix and applied
the PCA technique to extract features of the ï¬rst period. Sousa
et al.[15] investigated the classiï¬cation capability with different
feature sets, such as time-domain (mathematical and statis-
tical parameters), frequency-domain (wavelet transform), and
discrete-domain (symbolic representations). Although the above
works achieved signiï¬cant progress for HAR, the limitations
still existed. Most of them ignored the affection of shift changes
in position and orientation of the smartphone due to motion
artifacts.
During the past decades, many researchers have explored
various ML and DL algorithms to identify more complex ac-
tivities with higher recognition rates. Koseet al.[1] proved that
k-nearest neighbor (k-NN) could obtain a higher classiï¬cation
accuracy than NaÂ¨ive Bayes (NB) by recognizing four kinds
of activities, i.e., walking, running, sitting, and standing. Lee
and Cho [16] designed a mixture-of-experts model for dealing
with uncertain and incomplete data. Reyes-Ortiz et al. [17]
proposed a transition-aware HAR system based on the support
vector machine (SVM) algorithm to classify a broad spectrum
(up to 33 types) of activity with smartphone in real-time. Lee
and Cho [18] presented a hierarchical hidden Markov model
(HHMM) method to classify motions (standing, walking, go
stairs, and running) and daily activities (shopping, taking a
bus, and moving arms). A two-stage continuous hidden Markov
model (HMM) algorithm was proposed to reduce the number of
feature subsets because it decomposed the complex activities
into several simpler ones [19]. Reiss et al. [20] found that
the ConfAdaBoost.M1 ensemble algorithm could obtain a high
recognition accuracy, but it was necessary to extract 561 features.
Noor et al.[21] introduced an adaptive sliding window approach
to recognize physical activity by computing the probability of
signals with an adjustable window length. All of the above
contributions were limited by the length of the detected signal
segments. Some of them focused on a short segment, which
cannot express a whole activity. Some of them detected on the
long signal segment, which affected misclassiï¬cation due to a
segment including many activities. Hence, it is essential to ï¬nd a
suitable data length for classiï¬cation. However, the performance
of ML-based solutions', ' motion

V. EXPERIMENTS AND RESULTS
Three experiments were designed to validate the claims about
the Ada-HAR system in Section I. The ï¬rst experiment of the HC
algorithm evaluation aimed to compare the performance among
ML-based and DL-based HC classiï¬ers. The second experiment
was to validate the evolution ability of the Ada-HAR system.
The demonstration revealed the identiï¬cation capability of Ada-
HAR system in real time. The experiments have implemented
these methods in MATLAB 2018b with the hardware platform of
Intel(R) i7 Core, 2.80-GHz CPU, and 16.0-GB RAM. A 64-bit
iPhone 6 s (2-core CPU) was utilized for collecting data with a
50-Hz sampling frequency.
A. HC Algorithm Evaluation
Twenty-ï¬ve subjects (13 females and 12 males, age range
18â€“40 years old) were asked to perform the 12 original activities
described in Section I in a ï¬xed order (shown in Fig. 4). They
carried the smartphone on the waist or put it in their left pant
pocket, respectively. Finally, 50 datasets (25 datasets for each
position) were collected for further analysis.
We adopt the leave-one-out cross-validation strategy to vali-
date the performance of HC classiï¬ers [40]. The length of the
detection window is 150 samples (3 s), and the overlap is 1 s
(50 estimates). Table III reports a comparison of the average and
standard deviation in terms of the accuracy, training time, and
average test time among ML-based (i.e.,k-NN, DT, NB, ANN,
and SVM) and DL-based (LSTM) HC classiï¬ers. Meanwhile,
all of the HC classiï¬ers are evaluated on uncompressed and no-
compressed datasets. Although the LSTM-based HC classiï¬er
obtains the highest accuracy, it is time-consuming for building
the model. Due to the SVM-based HC algorithm adopting the
linear kernel function, it takes more time to search the optimal
solution. In the same case, the k-NN-based approach is the
fastest method to establish the HC classiï¬er, while the DT-based
classiï¬er is the fastest algorithm to predict the activity. Moreover,
the testing accuracy displays that putting the smartphone in the
pocket acquires more noises than carrying the smartphone on
the waist. The results for the', ',M ,b yt h e

Five ML algorithms (i.e.,k-NN, DT, NB, ANN, and SVM) and
a DL method (LSTM) are chosen. As a nonparametric approach,
the k-NN algorithm can search a group ofk samples that are
nearest to unknown samples based on distance functions. In this
article, we adopt the city block distance. The computed class
attributes of thek-NN in thesek samples determined the labels.

V. EXPERIMENTS AND RESULTS
Three experiments were designed to validate the claims about
the Ada-HAR system in Section I. The ï¬rst experiment of the HC
algorithm evaluation aimed to compare the performance among
ML-based and DL-based HC classiï¬ers. The second experiment
was to validate the evolution ability of the Ada-HAR system.
The demonstration revealed the identiï¬cation capability of Ada-
HAR system in real time. The experiments have implemented
these methods in MATLAB 2018b with the hardware platform of
Intel(R) i7 Core, 2.80-GHz CPU, and 16.0-GB RAM. A 64-bit
iPhone 6 s (2-core CPU) was utilized for collecting data with a
50-Hz sampling frequency.
A. HC Algorithm Evaluation
Twenty-ï¬ve subjects (13 females and 12 males, age range
18â€“40 years old) were asked to perform the 12 original activities
described in Section I in a ï¬xed order (shown in Fig. 4). They
carried the smartphone on the waist or put it in their left pant
pocket, respectively. Finally, 50 datasets (25 datasets for each
position) were collected for further analysis.
We adopt the leave-one-out cross-validation strategy to vali-
date the performance of HC classiï¬ers [40]. The length of the
detection window is 150 samples (3 s), and the overlap is 1 s
(50 estimates). Table III reports a comparison of the average and
standard deviation in terms of the accuracy, training time, and
average test time among ML-based (i.e.,k-NN, DT, NB, ANN,
and SVM) and DL-based (LSTM) HC classiï¬ers. Meanwhile,
all of the HC classiï¬ers are evaluated on uncompressed and no-
compressed datasets. Although the LSTM-based HC classiï¬er
obtains the highest accuracy, it is time-consuming for building
the model. Due to the SVM-based HC algorithm adopting the
linear kernel function, it takes more time to search the optimal
solution. In the same case, the k-NN-based approach is the
fastest method to establish the HC classiï¬er, while the DT-based
classiï¬er is the fastest algorithm to predict the activity. Moreover,
the testing accuracy displays that putting the smartphone in the
pocket acquires more noises than carrying the smartphone on
the waist. The results for the']

question: What preprocessing techniques on the included variables/features were applied in this study?
chunks_str:
['iss et al. [20] found that
the ConfAdaBoost.M1 ensemble algorithm could obtain a high
recognition accuracy, but it was necessary to extract 561 features.
Noor et al.[21] introduced an adaptive sliding window approach
to recognize physical activity by computing the probability of
signals with an adjustable window length. All of the above
contributions were limited by the length of the detected signal
segments. Some of them focused on a short segment, which
cannot express a whole activity. Some of them detected on the
long signal segment, which affected misclassiï¬cation due to a
segment including many activities. Hence, it is essential to ï¬nd a
suitable data length for classiï¬cation. However, the performance
of ML-based solutions was strongly dependent on the extracted
features from the used sensors. Different features were utilized
for achieving several kinds of HAR problems [22]. An efï¬cient
group-based context-aware classiï¬cation method has been pro-
posed to improve the classiï¬cation performance by exploiting
hierarchical group-based scheme and context awareness rather
than the intensive computation [23].
Recently, the advancement of HAR with inertial measurement
unit (IMU) sensor broadly adopts DL algorithms. Ronao and
Cho [24] designed a three-(and four-) layer convolutional neural
networks (CNN) with the short-time fast Fourier transform
method for classifying six activities with a high classiï¬cation
accuracy by comparing with the traditional ML algorithms, i.e.,
NB, ANN, and j48 decision tree (DT). Hammerlaet al. [25]
proved that bidirectional long short-term memory (Bi-LSTM)
obtained more accurate results than deep NN, CNN, and other
recurrent neural network (RNN) by testing on three public
datasets. Although the DL-based approaches were widely known
to extract features automatically, they were affected by the
selected sensors. Wang et al. [8] compared the performance
obtained using different inertial sensors in a smartphone. Using
both accelerometer and gyroscope was demonstrated to yield
accuracy enhancement. In our previous work, we compared
the recognition rate for identifying 12 activities by using dif-
ferent combined sensors, such as accelerometer, gyroscope,
magnetometer, and orientation. By combining accelerometer,
gyroscope, and direction, the designed deep CNN model could
obtain high accuracy [26], [27]. The results proved that adopting
transferred signals and more sensors can perform the results.
Moreover, the DL-based methods were time-consuming for
classiï¬er evolution in a dynamic situation [28].
III. PROBLEM STATEMENT
The following notations describe the data stream of the Ada-
HAR system through training, testing, and updating procedures,
as shown in Fig. 1. The embedded IMU sensors in a smartphone
can provide nine-dimensional (9-D) raw signalsS, including
acceleration, magnetism, and angular velocity [29].S can be
divided into M segments, namely sp,p =1 ,2,...,M ,b yt h e
sliding window method [30]. The segments can be labeled
in a supervised manner as {sp,yp},p =1 ,2,...,M . A data
compression model is adopted to remove the similar segments
from {sp,yp} with the same labels. The compressed datasets
{si,yi},i =1 ,2,...,N (usually,N â‰¤ M) can be processed by
the signal preprocessing model for information enhancement as
